CC   -!- FUNCTION: Functions in the SND pathway, a SRP (signal recognition
CC       particle) and GET (guided entry of tail-anchored proteins)
CC       independent pathway for targeting a broad range of substrate
CC       proteins to the endoplasmic reticulum. SND functions in parallel
CC       to GET in targeting proteins with downstream hydrophobic motifs.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:27905431}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with ENV10/SND2. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:27905431}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:27905431}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 195 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: GTPase-activating protein (GAP) for CDC42 and/or RHO1.
CC       Negative regulator of the pheromone-response pathway through the
CC       STE20 protein kinase; acts at a step between the G-protein and the
CC       MAP kinase module. Dominant suppressor of bud emergence defect
CC       caused by deletion of IPL2/BEM2. Involved in the control of
CC       polarized cell growth and proper bud site selection.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q12518:ENT1; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-15044, EBI-31494;
CC       Q05785:ENT2; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-15044, EBI-35928;
CC       O88339:Epn1 (xeno); NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-15044, EBI-7066728;
CC       P40073:SHO1; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-15044, EBI-18140;
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 396 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.

RN   [31]
RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (1.92 ANGSTROMS) OF 1-384.
RA   Osipiuk J., Li H., Bargassa M., Sahi C., Craig E.A., Joachimiak A.;
RT   "Crystal structure of ATPase domain of Ssb1 chaperone, member of the
RT   HSP70 family from Saccharomyces cerevisiae.";
RL   Submitted (MAR-2009) to the PDB data bank.
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Ribosome-bound, Hsp70-type chaperone that assists in the
CC       cotranslational folding of newly synthesized proteins in the
CC       cytosol. Stimulates folding by interacting with nascent chains,
CC       binding to short, largely hydrophobic sequences exposed by
CC       unfolded proteins, thereby stabilizing longer, more slowly
CC       translated, and aggregation-prone nascent polypeptides and domains
CC       that cannot fold stably until fully synthesized. The Hsp70-protein
CC       substrate interaction depends on ATP-binding and on allosteric
CC       regulation between the NBD and the SBD. The ATP-bound state is
CC       characterized by a fast exchange rate of substrate (low affinity
CC       state), while in the ADP-bound state exchange is much slower (high
CC       affinity state). During the Hsp70 cycle, the chaperone switches
CC       between the ATP-bound state (open conformation) and the ADP-bound
CC       state (closed conformation) by major conformational rearrangements
CC       involving mainly the lid domain. Ssb cooperates with a specific
CC       Hsp40/Hsp70 co-chaperone termed the ribosome-associated complex
CC       (RAC), which stimulates the ATPase activity of the ribosome-
CC       associated pool of Ssbs and switches it to the high affinity
CC       substrate binding state. Hsp110 chaperone SSE1 and FES1 act as
CC       nucleotide exchange factors that cause substrate release.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11739779, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11929994,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:1394434, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16219770,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16221677, ECO:0000269|PubMed:23332755,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8994035, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9670014}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: ATP + H(2)O = ADP + phosphate.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9860955}.
CC   -!- BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES:
CC       Kinetic parameters:
CC         KM=270 uM for ATP (at 2.5 mM potassium acetate)
CC         {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9860955};
CC         KM=147 uM for ATP (at 100 mM potassium acetate)
CC         {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9860955};
CC         Note=kcat is 0.95 min(-1) with ATP as substrate (at 2.5 mM
CC         potassium acetate) and 0.81 min(-1) with ATP as substrate (at
CC         100 mM potassium acetate). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9860955};
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Binds to ribosomes (PubMed:9670014, PubMed:1394434,
CC       PubMed:27917864). Binds close to the ribosomal tunnel exit via
CC       contacts with both ribosomal proteins RPL35, RPL39 and RPL19, and
CC       rRNA (PubMed:27882919). Directly interacts with nascent
CC       polypeptides. This interaction is dependent on the ribosome-
CC       associated complex (RAC) (PubMed:11929994, PubMed:23332755).
CC       Interacts with SSE1 (PubMed:16219770, PubMed:16221677,
CC       PubMed:23332755). Interacts with FES1 (PubMed:17132105). Interacts
CC       with NAP1 (PubMed:18086883). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11929994,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:1394434, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16219770,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16221677, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17132105,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18086883, ECO:0000269|PubMed:23332755,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:27882919, ECO:0000269|PubMed:27917864,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9670014}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P43573:BUD27; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-8627, EBI-22787;
CC       P40433:PFK26; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-8627, EBI-1956;
CC       P32589:SSE1; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-8627, EBI-8648;
CC       P38825:TOM71; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-8627, EBI-24694;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10347213,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:23332755, ECO:0000305|PubMed:1394434}.
CC       Note=About 50% of the protein is associated with translating
CC       ribosomes, but sufficient Ssb exists in the cell for each ribosome
CC       to be associated with at least one Ssb molecule.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:1394434, ECO:0000269|PubMed:23332755,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9670014}.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: Expression decreases after heat shock or during growth
CC       to stationary phase (PubMed:6761581, PubMed:2651414). Degraded
CC       during heat shock treatment (at protein level) (PubMed:7646503).
CC       Up-regulated upon carbon upshift and down-regulated upon amino
CC       acid limitation in an HSF1-dependent manner (PubMed:10322015).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10322015, ECO:0000269|PubMed:2651414,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:6761581, ECO:0000269|PubMed:7646503}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 170000 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the heat shock protein 70 family. Ssb-type
CC       Hsp70 subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   FUNCTION, AND SUBCELLULAR LOCATION.
RX   PubMed=20953064; DOI=10.1247/csf.10011;
RA   Mauchi N., Ohtake Y., Irie K.;
RT   "Stability control of MTL1 mRNA by the RNA-binding protein Khd1p in
RT   yeast.";
RL   Cell Struct. Funct. 35:95-105(2010).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: RNA-binding protein involved in the correct localization
CC       of transcripts in the cell. RNA localization is a widespread
CC       mechanism for achieving localized protein synthesis. Required for
CC       the asymmetric localization to the daughter cell nucleus of the
CC       ASH1 transcript, coding for a specific repressor of transcription.
CC       Overexpression inhibits translation of the ASH1 transcript.
CC       Involved in the stability of transcripts such as the MTL1 mRNA.
CC       Involved in structural and functional organization of telomeric
CC       chromatin and regulates silencing at the HMR locus.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11739741, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11867544,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17588515, ECO:0000269|PubMed:18067921,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18805955, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20953064}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Binds RNA.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm. Cytoplasm, P-body. Nucleus.
CC       Chromosome, telomere.
CC   -!- PTM: Phosphorylated by the plasma membrane-anchored casein kinase
CC       YCK1. Phosphorylation at its C-terminus reduces its RNA-binding
CC       capacity. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17588515}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 15600 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the HEK2 family. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   UBIQUITINATION, AND INTERACTION WITH UBR2.
RX   PubMed=15504724; DOI=10.1074/jbc.M410085200;

RN   [10]
RP   UBIQUITINATION, AND INTERACTION WITH MUB1.
RX   PubMed=18070918; DOI=10.1128/MCB.01787-07;
RA   Ju D., Wang X., Xu H., Xie Y.;
RT   "Genome-wide analysis identifies MYND-domain protein Mub1 as an
RT   essential factor for Rpn4 ubiquitylation.";
RL   Mol. Cell. Biol. 28:1404-1412(2008).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Acts as a transcriptional activator of a number of genes
CC       encoding proteasomal subunits. Binds to a PACE (proteasome-
CC       associated control element) DNA sequence 5'-GGTGGCAAA-3'. Its
CC       expression is in turn regulated by the 26S proteasome, thereby
CC       providing a negative feedback control mechanism. Required for
CC       normal growth at low temperatures. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10350051,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11248031}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Probably interacts with SEC63. Interacts with MUB1, UBR2
CC       and RPN2. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15504724,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18070918}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q03162:MUB1; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-15931, EBI-28207;
CC       Q07963:UBR2; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-15931, EBI-34338;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus.
CC   -!- PTM: Ubiquitinated by UBR2 in the presence of UBC2; which leads to
CC       proteasomal degradation. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15504724,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18070918}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Mutants grow slowly at low temperatures and
CC       show partial mislocalization of nuclear antigens.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:8514125}.
CC   -!- CAUTION: According to PubMed:9512348, it is a component of the 26S
CC       proteasome. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   FUNCTION, AND CATALYTIC ACTIVITY.

RP   TOPOLOGY [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS].
RC   STRAIN=ATCC 208353 / W303-1A;
RX   PubMed=16847258; DOI=10.1073/pnas.0604075103;
RA   Kim H., Melen K., Oesterberg M., von Heijne G.;
RT   "A global topology map of the Saccharomyces cerevisiae membrane
RT   proteome.";
RL   Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 103:11142-11147(2006).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Stearyl-CoA desaturase that utilizes O(2) and electrons
CC       from reduced cytochrome b5 to introduce the first double bond into
CC       saturated fatty acyl-CoA substrates (PubMed:1978720,
CC       PubMed:7947684). Catalyzes the insertion of a cis double bond at
CC       the delta-9 position into fatty acyl-CoA substrates including
CC       palmitoyl-CoA and stearoyl-CoA (PubMed:1978720). Required for the
CC       biosynthesis of membrane phospholipids, cholesterol esters and
CC       triglycerides (PubMed:1978720, PubMed:7947684, PubMed:16443825).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16443825, ECO:0000269|PubMed:1978720,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:7947684}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Stearoyl-CoA + 2 ferrocytochrome b5 + O(2) + 2
CC       H(+) = oleoyl-CoA + 2 ferricytochrome b5 + 2 H(2)O.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16443825, ECO:0000269|PubMed:1978720,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:7947684}.
CC   -!- COFACTOR:
CC       Name=Fe(2+); Xref=ChEBI:CHEBI:29033;
CC         Evidence={ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P13516};
CC       Note=Expected to bind 2 Fe(2+) ions per subunit.
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P13516};
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Endoplasmic reticulum membrane
CC       {ECO:0000305}; Multi-pass membrane protein {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The histidine box domains are involved in binding the
CC       catalytic metal ions. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:O00767}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the fatty acid desaturase type 1 family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Prohibitin probably acts as a holdase/unfoldase for the
CC       stabilization of newly synthesized mitochondrial proteins. Has an
CC       antiproliferative activity. Regulates replicative life span.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10835343}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: The mitochondrial prohibitin complex consists of two
CC       subunits (PHB1 and PHB2), assembled into a membrane-associated
CC       ring-shaped supercomplex of approximately 1 mDa.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10835343, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12237468}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P50085:PHB2; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-13360, EBI-23530;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Mitochondrion inner membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095, ECO:0000269|PubMed:14576278,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15525670}; Peripheral membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095, ECO:0000269|PubMed:14576278,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15525670}; Intermembrane side
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095, ECO:0000269|PubMed:14576278,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15525670}.
CC   -!- PTM: The N-terminus is blocked.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 9690 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: PHB1 subunits are targeted to mitochondria by an
CC       unconventional non-cleavable targeting sequence present at their
CC       N-terminus.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the prohibitin family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Catalyzes the first step of the methylation pathway of
CC       phosphatidylcholine biosynthesis, the SAM-dependent methylation of
CC       phosphatidylethanolamine (PE) to
CC       phosphatidylmonomethylethanolamine (PMME). Preferentially converts
CC       di-C16:1 substrates. {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03217,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15258140, ECO:0000269|PubMed:2198947,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22001639, ECO:0000269|PubMed:2445736,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:2684666, ECO:0000269|PubMed:3066687,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:6759124, ECO:0000269|PubMed:6988218}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: S-adenosyl-L-methionine +
CC       phosphatidylethanolamine = S-adenosyl-L-homocysteine +
CC       phosphatidyl-N-methylethanolamine. {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-
CC       Rule:MF_03217, ECO:0000269|PubMed:2198947,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22001639, ECO:0000269|PubMed:2445736,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:2684666}.
CC   -!- BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES:
CC       Kinetic parameters:
CC         KM=60 uM for S-adenosyl-L-methionine
CC         {ECO:0000269|PubMed:2684666};
CC         KM=110 uM for S-adenosyl-L-methionine
CC         {ECO:0000269|PubMed:2198947};

RN   [11]
RP   IDENTIFICATION BY MASS SPECTROMETRY, AND SUBCELLULAR LOCATION [LARGE
RP   SCALE ANALYSIS].
RX   PubMed=22984289; DOI=10.1074/mcp.M112.021105;
RA   Voegtle F.N., Burkhart J.M., Rao S., Gerbeth C., Hinrichs J.,
RA   Martinou J.C., Chacinska A., Sickmann A., Zahedi R.P., Meisinger C.;
RT   "Intermembrane space proteome of yeast mitochondria.";
RL   Mol. Cell. Proteomics 11:1840-1852(2012).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Mitochondrial intermembrane chaperone that participates
CC       in the import and insertion of some multi-pass transmembrane
CC       proteins into the mitochondrial inner membrane. Also required for
CC       the transfer of beta-barrel precursors from the TOM complex to the
CC       sorting and assembly machinery (SAM complex) of the outer
CC       membrane. Acts as a chaperone-like protein that protects the
CC       hydrophobic precursors from aggregation and guide them through the
CC       mitochondrial intermembrane space. The TIM8-TIM13 complex is non
CC       essential and only mediates the import of few proteins under
CC       precise conditions while the predominant TIM9-TIM10 70 kDa complex
CC       is crucial and mediates the import of much more proteins. Strictly
CC       required for import of TIM23 in some conditions, when a low
CC       membrane potential exists in the mitochondria.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10469659, ECO:0000269|PubMed:10995434,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11101512, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11509656,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12221072}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Heterohexamer; composed of 3 copies of TIM8 and 3 copies
CC       of TIM13, named soluble 70 kDa complex. Associates with the TIM22
CC       complex, whose core is composed of TIM18, TIM22 and TIM54.
CC       Interacts with the transmembrane regions of multi-pass
CC       transmembrane proteins in transit. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10469659,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12221072}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P57744:TIM8; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-9121, EBI-9013892;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Mitochondrion inner membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10469659}; Peripheral membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10469659}; Intermembrane side
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10469659}. Mitochondrion intermembrane space
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22984289}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The twin CX3C motif contains 4 conserved Cys residues that
CC       form 2 disulfide bonds in the mitochondrial intermembrane space.
CC       However, during the transit of TIM13 from cytoplasm into
CC       mitochondrion, the Cys residues probably coordinate zinc, thereby
CC       preventing folding and allowing its transfer across mitochondrial
CC       outer membrane. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12941692}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the small Tim family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Involved in the regulation of lipid homeostasis in the
CC       endoplasmic reticulum, thereby impacting nuclear pore complex
CC       biogenesis and localization, and nucleocytoplasmic mRNA transport.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15273328, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17724120,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:20016074}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus membrane; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein. Endoplasmic reticulum membrane; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the APQ12 family. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   FUNCTION, AND CATALYTIC ACTIVITY.
RX   PubMed=22001639; DOI=10.1016/j.bbalip.2011.09.018;
RA   Bilgin M., Markgraf D.F., Duchoslav E., Knudsen J., Jensen O.N.,
RA   de Kroon A.I., Ejsing C.S.;
RT   "Quantitative profiling of PE, MMPE, DMPE, and PC lipid species by

RT   metabolism.";
RL   Biochim. Biophys. Acta 1811:1081-1089(2011).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Catalyzes the second two steps of the methylation
CC       pathway of phosphatidylcholine biosynthesis, the SAM-dependent
CC       methylation of phosphatidylmonomethylethanolamine (PMME) to
CC       phosphatidyldimethylethanolamine (PDME) and of PDME to
CC       phosphatidylcholine (PC). Can also catalyze the first methylation
CC       reaction of PE to PMME in the absence of PE methyltransferase
CC       CHO2. {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03216,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:2198947, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22001639,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:2445736, ECO:0000269|PubMed:2670666,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:2684666, ECO:0000269|PubMed:6337128,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:6759124, ECO:0000269|PubMed:7047296}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: S-adenosyl-L-methionine +
CC       phosphatidylethanolamine = S-adenosyl-L-homocysteine +
CC       phosphatidyl-N-methylethanolamine. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22001639,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:2445736, ECO:0000269|PubMed:2684666}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: S-adenosyl-L-methionine + phosphatidyl-N-
CC       methylethanolamine = S-adenosyl-L-homocysteine + phosphatidyl-N-
CC       dimethylethanolamine. {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03216,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:2198947, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22001639,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:2445736, ECO:0000269|PubMed:2684666}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: S-adenosyl-L-methionine + phosphatidyl-N-
CC       dimethylethanolamine = S-adenosyl-L-homocysteine +
CC       phosphatidylcholine. {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03216,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:2198947, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22001639,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:2445736, ECO:0000269|PubMed:2684666}.
CC   -!- BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES:
CC       Kinetic parameters:
CC         KM=180 uM for S-adenosyl-L-methionine (in presence of
CC         phosphatidylethanolamine (PE) as substrate)
CC         {ECO:0000269|PubMed:2684666};
CC         KM=190 uM for S-adenosyl-L-methionine (in presence of
CC         phosphatidyl-N-methylethanolamine (PMME) as substrate)
CC         {ECO:0000269|PubMed:2684666};
CC         KM=240 uM for S-adenosyl-L-methionine (in presence of
CC         phosphatidyl-N-dimethylethanolamine (PDME) as substrate)
CC         {ECO:0000269|PubMed:2684666};
CC         KM=270 uM for phosphatidyl-N-methylethanolamine (PMME)
CC         {ECO:0000269|PubMed:2684666};
CC         KM=110 uM for phosphatidyl-N-dimethylethanolamine (PDME)
CC         {ECO:0000269|PubMed:2684666};
CC         KM=54 uM for S-adenosyl-L-methionine (in presence of
CC         phosphatidyl-N-methylethanolamine (PMME) as substrate)
CC         {ECO:0000269|PubMed:2198947};
CC         KM=59 uM for S-adenosyl-L-methionine (in presence of
CC         phosphatidyl-N-dimethylethanolamine (PDME) as substrate)
CC         {ECO:0000269|PubMed:2198947};
CC         KM=380 uM for phosphatidyl-N-methylethanolamine (PMME)
CC         {ECO:0000269|PubMed:2198947};
CC         KM=180 uM for phosphatidyl-N-dimethylethanolamine (PDME)
CC         {ECO:0000269|PubMed:2198947};
CC       pH dependence:
CC         Optimum pH is 8.1. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:2684666};
CC   -!- PATHWAY: Phospholipid metabolism; phosphatidylcholine
CC       biosynthesis. {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03216,
CC       ECO:0000305|PubMed:6337128}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Endoplasmic reticulum membrane
CC       {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03216, ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095};
CC       Multi-pass membrane protein {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03216}.
CC       Mitochondrion membrane {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03216,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:14576278}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03216}.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: Expression is repressed by inositol and choline. The 5'
CC       flanking region contains two copies of the CATRTGAA motif and a
CC       5'-AAACCCACACATG-3' GRFI site, which are involved in the
CC       regulation of expression. OPI1 and SIN3 play the role of
CC       repressors for OPI3 expression whereas UME6 is an activator of
CC       OPI3 expression. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:1650774,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:1954254, ECO:0000269|PubMed:6759124,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8614637}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 5890 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the class VI-like SAM-binding
CC       methyltransferase superfamily. PEMT/PEM2 methyltransferase family.
CC       {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03216}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Catalytic component of the inositol phosphorylceramide
CC       synthase which catalyzes the addition of a phosphorylinositol
CC       group onto ceramide to form inositol phosphorylceramide, an
CC       essential step in sphingolipid biosynthesis.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19047657, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19726565,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9092515}.
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: Inhibited by aureobasidin A (AbA), khafrefungin
CC       and rustmicin. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19047657}.
CC   -!- BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES:
CC       Kinetic parameters:
CC         KM=555 uM for phosphatidylinositol
CC         {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19047657};
CC         KM=3.0 uM for C(6)-NBD-ceramide {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19047657};
CC         Vmax=824 pmol/min/mg enzyme for phosphatidylinositol
CC         {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19047657};
CC         Vmax=367 pmol/min/mg enzyme for C(6)-NBD-ceramide
CC         {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19047657};
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the inositol phosphorylceramide synthase
CC       complex composed of at least AUR1 and KEI1.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q06346:KEI1; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-2046036, EBI-38431;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Golgi apparatus, Golgi stack membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10888667, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19726565}; Multi-
CC       pass membrane protein {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10888667,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19726565}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 4170 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the AUR1 family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Nonessential SNARE involved in targeting and fusion of
CC       ER-derived transport vesicles with the Golgi complex as well as
CC       Golgi-derived retrograde transport vesicles with the ER.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11001058, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12853481,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12893879, ECO:0000269|PubMed:1990290}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of two distinct SNARE complexes consisting of
CC       SED5, BOS1, BET1 and SEC22 or UFE1, USE1, SEC20 and SEC22. YKT6
CC       can probably replace SEC22 as subunit of either complex. Interacts
CC       with SEC24, YIF1 and YIP1. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11001058,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12657649, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12853481,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12893879, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12941276}.

CC       Q12154:GET3; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-16577, EBI-2989;

CC       P01123:YPT1; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-16577, EBI-29496;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane {ECO:0000305}; Single-pass type IV

CC       Golgi apparatus membrane {ECO:0000305}; Single-pass type IV
CC       membrane protein {ECO:0000305}.

CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.

CC       SEC22 suppresses deletion of YPT1.

RN   [12]
RP   MUTAGENESIS OF LEU-13.
RX   PubMed=15465910; DOI=10.1073/pnas.0406319101;
RA   Du H., Tardiff D.F., Moore M.J., Rosbash M.;
RT   "Effects of the U1C L13 mutation and temperature regulation of yeast
RT   commitment complex formation.";
RL   Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 101:14841-14846(2004).
RN   [13]
RP   IDENTIFICATION IN THE U1 SNRNP COMPLEX, AND IDENTIFICATION BY MASS
RP   SPECTROMETRY.
RX   PubMed=19941820; DOI=10.1016/j.molcel.2009.09.040;
RA   Fabrizio P., Dannenberg J., Dube P., Kastner B., Stark H., Urlaub H.,
RA   Luhrmann R.;
RT   "The evolutionarily conserved core design of the catalytic activation
RT   step of the yeast spliceosome.";
RL   Mol. Cell 36:593-608(2009).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Component of the spliceosomal U1 snRNP, which is
CC       essential for recognition of the pre-mRNA 5' splice-site and the
CC       subsequent assembly of the spliceosome. YHC1/U1-C is directly
CC       involved in initial 5' splice-site recognition for both
CC       constitutive and regulated alternative splicing. The interaction
CC       with the 5' splice-site seems to precede base-pairing between the
CC       pre-mRNA and the U1 snRNA. Stimulates commitment or early (E)
CC       complex formation by stabilizing the base pairing of the 5' end of
CC       the U1 snRNA and the 5' splice-site region.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10072386, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12214237,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9233817}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: U1 snRNP is composed of the 7 core Sm proteins SMB1,
CC       SMD1, SMD2, SMD3, SME1, SMX3 and SMX2 (Sm proteins B, D1, D2, D3,
CC       E, F and G, respectively) that assemble in a heptameric protein
CC       ring on the Sm site of the small nuclear RNA to form the core
CC       snRNP, and at least 10 U1 snRNP-specific proteins SNP1/U1-70K,
CC       MUD1/U1-A, YHC1/U1-C, LUC7, NAM8, PRP39, PRP40, PRP42, SNU56 and
CC       SNU71. YHC1/U1-C interacts with U1 snRNA and the 5' splice-site
CC       region of the pre-mRNA. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10072386,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19941820, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9630245}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03153,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 2140 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the U1 small nuclear ribonucleoprotein C
CC       family. {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03153}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Component of the SPOTS complex that acts as a negative
CC       regulator of sphingolipid synthesis. Acts by inhibiting serine
CC       palmitoyltransferases (LCB1 and LCB2) activity.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:20182505}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the SPOTS complex, at least composed of
CC       LCB1/2 (LCB1 and/or LCB2), ORM1/2 (ORM1 and/or ORM2), SAC1 and
CC       TSC3. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:20182505}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Self; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-34916, EBI-34916;
CC       Q05031:DFG5; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-34916, EBI-27512;
CC       P25045:LCB1; NbExp=7; IntAct=EBI-34916, EBI-10059;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Endoplasmic reticulum membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20182505}; Multi-
CC       pass membrane protein {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:20182505}.
CC   -!- PTM: Phosphorylated in case of disruption of sphingolipid
CC       synthesis. Phosphorylation regulates inhibitory activity of serine
CC       palmitoyltransferases (LCB1 and LCB2).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:20182505}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 5240 molecules/cell in log phase SD

RA   Wilson M.A., St Amour C.V., Collins J.L., Ringe D., Petsko G.A.;

RN   [5]
RP   DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE.
RX   PubMed=24706893; DOI=10.1073/pnas.1319221111;
RA   Miller-Fleming L., Antas P., Pais T.F., Smalley J.L., Giorgini F.,
RA   Outeiro T.F.;
RT   "Yeast DJ-1 superfamily members are required for diauxic-shift
RT   reprogramming and cell survival in stationary phase.";
RL   Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 111:7012-7017(2014).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Catalyzes the conversion of methylglyoxal (MG) to D-
CC       lactate in a single glutathione (GSH)-independent step. May play a
CC       role in detoxifying endogenously produced glyoxals. Involved in
CC       protection against reactive oxygen species (ROS) (By similarity).
CC       Important for viability in stationary phase. May negatively
CC       regulate TORC1 in response to nutrient limitation
CC       (PubMed:24706893). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q04432,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:24706893}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: (R)-lactate = methylglyoxal + H(2)O.
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q04432}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homodimer. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q04432}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm, P-body
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q04432}. Note=Present in processing bodies
CC       (P-bodies) and stress granule (SG) foci upon glucose starvation
CC       and heat shock. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q04432}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Results in higher sensitivity to oxidative
CC       stress, reduced thermotolerance, accumulation of higher levels of
CC       reactive oxygen species, and reduced chronological life span.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:24706893}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the peptidase C56 family. HSP31-like
CC       subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Acts as component of the peripheral membrane COG complex
CC       that is involved in intra-Golgi protein trafficking. COG is
CC       located at the cis-Golgi, and regulates tethering of retrograde
CC       intra-Golgi vesicles and possibly a number of other membrane
CC       trafficking events.

CC       Sec34/Sec35) complex which consists of eight different proteins
CC       COG1-COG8. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11703943}.

RL   Mol. Cell. Proteomics 7:1389-1396(2008).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Clathrin is the major protein of the polyhedral coat of
CC       coated pits and vesicles. In yeast, it is involved in the
CC       retention of proteins in an intracellular membrane compartment,
CC       presumably the trans-Golgi. The yeast light chain is important for
CC       cell growth. The light chain may help to properly orient the
CC       assembly/ disassembly of the clathrin coats.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Clathrin coats are formed from molecules containing 3
CC       heavy chains and 3 light chains. Interacts with the auxilin-like
CC       clathrin uncoating factor SWA2. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11084334}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P22137:CHC1; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-4758, EBI-4766;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasmic vesicle membrane; Peripheral
CC       membrane protein; Cytoplasmic side. Membrane, coated pit;
CC       Peripheral membrane protein; Cytoplasmic side. Note=Cytoplasmic
CC       face of coated pits and vesicles.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: CLC1 binds calcium, and calmodulin in presence of
CC       calcium.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 3490 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the clathrin light chain family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (2.9 ANGSTROMS) OF 24-348, FUNCTION, INTERACTION
RP   WITH NPL3, AND SUBUNIT.
RX   PubMed=11101900; DOI=10.1038/82028;
RA   Weiss V.H., McBride A.E., Soriano M.A., Filman D.J., Silver P.A.,
RA   Hogle J.M.;
RT   "The structure and oligomerization of the yeast arginine
RT   methyltransferase, Hmt1.";
RL   Nat. Struct. Biol. 7:1165-1171(2000).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: S-adenosyl-L-methionine-dependent protein-arginine N-
CC       methyltransferase that catalyzes both the mono- and asymmetric
CC       (type I) dimethylation of the guanidino nitrogens of arginine
CC       residues in a variety of RNA-binding proteins such as
CC       heterogeneous nuclear ribonucleoproteins (hnRNPs) and small
CC       nuclear ribonucleoproteins (snRNPs) (PubMed:8668183,
CC       PubMed:8647869). Methylates NAB2, NPL3, HRP1 and YRA1, shuttling
CC       hnRNPs involved in mRNA processing and export, facilitating their
CC       export out of the nucleus (PubMed:8668183, PubMed:9499403,
CC       PubMed:10652296, PubMed:11779864, PubMed:15314027). Methylation of
CC       NPL3 weakens its interaction with THO2, a component of the TREX
CC       (transcription/export) complex important for transcriptional
CC       elongation and recruitment of mRNA export factors
CC       (PubMed:15314027, PubMed:20053728). Methylates the hnRNP HRB1, but
CC       does not influence its subcellular location (PubMed:9499403).
CC       Methylates the nucleolar proteins GAR1, NOP1 and NSR1
CC       (PubMed:12756332). Methylates the snRNP SNP1 and modulates the
CC       cotranscriptional recruitment of splicing factors
CC       (PubMed:20823272). Dimethylates free histone H4 (HHF1/HHF2) at
CC       'Arg-4' (H4R3me2a) and plays a role in preservation and
CC       establishment of silent chromatin domains (PubMed:12097318,
CC       PubMed:17158743). Mono- and dimethylates ribosomal protein S2
CC       (RPS2) at 'Arg-11' (PubMed:20035717). Methylates the catalytic
CC       subunit of the SWI/SNF chromatin-remodeling complex SNF2
CC       (PubMed:22997150). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10652296,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11101900, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11779864,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12097318, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12756332,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15314027, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17158743,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:20035717, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20053728,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:20823272, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22997150,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8647869, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8668183,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9499403}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homodimer. The dimers can then associate to form a ring-
CC       shaped homohexamer. Interacts with NPL3, BRE5, MTR4, SNF2, SUM1,
CC       AND SSD1. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11101900,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22997150}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Self; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-8394, EBI-8394;
CC       P53741:BRE5; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-8394, EBI-28528;
CC       P22204:DBF2; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-8394, EBI-5569;
CC       P47047:MTR4; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-8394, EBI-11592;
CC       P32505:NAB2; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-8394, EBI-11770;
CC       Q01560:NPL3; NbExp=9; IntAct=EBI-8394, EBI-12114;
CC       P23595:PPH22; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-8394, EBI-12752;
CC       P22082:SNF2; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-8394, EBI-17526;
CC       P24276:SSD1; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-8394, EBI-18153;
CC       P46676:SUM1; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-8394, EBI-18547;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus {ECO:0000269|PubMed:8668183}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 37600 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the class I-like SAM-binding
CC       methyltransferase superfamily. Protein arginine N-
CC       methyltransferase family. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU01015}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Functions in the transition of mRNAs from translation to
CC       an mRNP complex destined for decapping. High-copy-number
CC       suppressor of decapping defects. Overexpression suppresses
CC       decapping defects in both DCP1-2 and DCP2-7 mutations. Acts to
CC       promote translational repression of mRNA in conjunction with DHH1
CC       and subsequent mRNA localization to P bodies. Promotes
CC       translational repression of mRNA during glucose deprivation.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16782896}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Associated with snR10 and snR11 small nuclear RNAs.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16782896}.
CC       Nucleus, nucleolus {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16782896,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:2121740}. Note=Found in cytoplasmic P bodies.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16782896}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 12800 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the RRM GAR family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: RNA-binding protein involved in post-transcriptional
CC       regulation. Negatively regulates expression of COX17 by binding to
CC       the 3'-UTR of COX17 mRNA. Promotes decay of COX17 mRNA by
CC       enhancing its rate of deadenylation and subsequent turnover.
CC       Predominantly binds to mRNAs encoding mitochondrial proteins and
CC       localizes them to the vicinity of mitochondria for translation.
CC       Regulates mitochondrial biogenesis, motility and morphology.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11101532, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15337848,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16244132, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16355254,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17210948, ECO:0000269|PubMed:18094119,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18523582}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Mitochondrion outer membrane; Peripheral
CC       membrane protein; Cytoplasmic side. Cytoplasm. Note=Localizes to
CC       multiple discrete foci in the cytoplasm.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 846 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the PUF3 family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: RNA-binding protein involved in post-transcriptional
CC       regulation. Negatively regulates expression of COX17 by binding to
CC       the 3'-UTR of COX17 mRNA. Promotes decay of COX17 mRNA by
CC       enhancing its rate of deadenylation and subsequent turnover.
CC       Predominantly binds to mRNAs encoding membrane-associated proteins
CC       with roles in transmembrane transport and vesicular trafficking.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11101532}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15024427}. Note=Localizes to foci enriched near
CC       the periphery of the cell.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 377 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.

RP   COMPOSITION OF OLIGOSACCHARYL TRANSFERASE COMPLEXES.
RX   PubMed=16096345; DOI=10.1093/glycob/cwj026;
RA   Yan A., Lennarz W.J.;
RT   "Two oligosaccharyl transferase complexes exist in yeast and associate
RT   with two different translocons.";
RL   Glycobiology 15:1407-1415(2005).
RN   [12]
RP   INTERACTION WITH SEC61; SBH1 AND SSS1.
RX   PubMed=15831493; DOI=10.1074/jbc.M502858200;
RA   Chavan M., Yan A., Lennarz W.J.;
RT   "Subunits of the translocon interact with components of the
RT   oligosaccharyl transferase complex.";
RL   J. Biol. Chem. 280:22917-22924(2005).
RN   [13]
RP   INTERACTION WITH OST2; OST3; OST5; OST6; WBP1 AND SWP1.
RX   PubMed=15886282; DOI=10.1073/pnas.0502669102;
RA   Yan A., Wu E., Lennarz W.J.;
RT   "Studies of yeast oligosaccharyl transferase subunits using the split-
RT   ubiquitin system: topological features and in vivo interactions.";
RL   Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 102:7121-7126(2005).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Essential subunit of the N-oligosaccharyl transferase
CC       (OST) complex which catalyzes the transfer of a high mannose
CC       oligosaccharide from a lipid-linked oligosaccharide donor to an
CC       asparagine residue within an Asn-X-Ser/Thr consensus motif in
CC       nascent polypeptide chains. N-glycosylation occurs
CC       cotranslationally and the complex associates with the Sec61
CC       complex at the channel-forming translocon complex that mediates
CC       protein translocation across the endoplasmic reticulum (ER). All
CC       subunits are required for a maximal enzyme activity.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Dolichyl diphosphooligosaccharide + [protein]-
CC       L-asparagine = dolichyl diphosphate + a glycoprotein with the
CC       oligosaccharide chain attached by N-beta-D-glycosyl linkage to a
CC       protein L-asparagine.
CC   -!- PATHWAY: Protein modification; protein glycosylation.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the oligosaccharyltransferase (OST) complex,
CC       which appears to exist in two assemblies comprising OST1, OST2,
CC       OST4, OST5, STT3, SWP1, WPB1, and either OST3 or OST6. WBP1, SWP1
CC       and OST2 probably form a subcomplex. May interact directly with
CC       OST2, OST3, OST5, OST6, WBP1 AND SWP1. Interacts with SEC61, SBH1
CC       and SSS1. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15831493,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15886282, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8175708,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9405463}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P53622:COP1; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-12658, EBI-4860;
CC       Q99380:OST4; NbExp=6; IntAct=EBI-12658, EBI-12689;
CC       P52870:SBH1; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-12658, EBI-16410;
CC       P32915:SEC61; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-12658, EBI-16400;
CC       P35179:SSS1; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-12658, EBI-16406;
CC       P39007:STT3; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-12658, EBI-18447;
CC       Q02795:SWP1; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-12658, EBI-12666;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Endoplasmic reticulum membrane; Single-pass
CC       type I membrane protein.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The cytoplasmic C-terminal domain contains a functional
CC       dilysine-retrieval motif, which is involved in the retrograde
CC       Golgi-to-ER transport of the protein.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 14900 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the DDOST 48 kDa subunit family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Acts as a component of the centromere DNA-binding
CC       protein complex CBF3, which is essential for chromosome
CC       segregation and movement of centromeres along microtubules. CBF3
CC       is required for the recruitment of other kinetochore complexes to
CC       CEN DNA. It plays a role in the attachment of chromosomes to the
CC       spindle and binds selectively to a highly conserved DNA sequence
CC       called CDEIII, found in centromers and in several promoters.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the CBF3 copmplex, which is formed of
CC       CBF3A/CBF2, CBF3B/CEP3, CBF3C/CTF13 and CBF3D.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Self; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-4077, EBI-4077;
CC       P35203:CTF13; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-4077, EBI-4085;
CC       P22216:RAD53; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-4077, EBI-17843;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus {ECO:0000305}. Chromosome,
CC       centromere.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 1900 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.

RN   [22]
RP   ELECTRON MICROSCOPY OF MEDIATOR COMPLEX IN COMPLEX WITH RNA POLYMERASE
RP   II.
RX   PubMed=12191485; DOI=10.1016/S1097-2765(02)00598-1;
RA   Davis J.A., Takagi Y., Kornberg R.D., Asturias F.J.;
RT   "Structure of the yeast RNA polymerase II holoenzyme: mediator
RT   conformation and polymerase interaction.";
RL   Mol. Cell 10:409-415(2002).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Component of the Mediator complex, a coactivator
CC       involved in the regulated transcription of nearly all RNA
CC       polymerase II-dependent genes. Mediator functions as a bridge to
CC       convey information from gene-specific regulatory proteins to the
CC       basal RNA polymerase II transcription machinery. The Mediator
CC       complex, having a compact conformation in its free form, is
CC       recruited to promoters by direct interactions with regulatory
CC       proteins and serves for the assembly of a functional preinitiation
CC       complex with RNA polymerase II and the general transcription
CC       factors. The Mediator complex unfolds to an extended conformation
CC       and partially surrounds RNA polymerase II, specifically
CC       interacting with the unphosphorylated form of the C-terminal
CC       domain (CTD) of RNA polymerase II. The Mediator complex
CC       dissociates from the RNA polymerase II holoenzyme and stays at the
CC       promoter when transcriptional elongation begins.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11555651, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16076843,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16263706}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the Mediator complex, which is composed of
CC       at least 21 subunits that form three structurally distinct
CC       submodules. The Mediator head module contains MED6, MED8, MED11,
CC       SRB4/MED17, SRB5/MED18, ROX3/MED19, SRB2/MED20 and SRB6/MED22, the
CC       middle module contains MED1, MED4, NUT1/MED5, MED7, CSE2/MED9,
CC       NUT2/MED10, SRB7/MED21 and SOH1/MED31, and the tail module
CC       contains MED2, PGD1/MED3, RGR1/MED14, GAL11/MED15 and SIN4/MED16.
CC       The head and the middle modules interact directly with RNA
CC       polymerase II, whereas the elongated tail module interacts with
CC       gene-specific regulatory proteins. MED4 interacts directly with
CC       MED1, MED7 and SRB7/MED21. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11555651,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15710619, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17192271}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q08278:MED7; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-31503, EBI-10674;
CC       P47822:SRB7; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-31503, EBI-18046;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 1617 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the Mediator complex subunit 4 family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

RP   NOMENCLATURE.
RX   PubMed=24524803; DOI=10.1016/j.sbi.2014.01.002;
RA   Ban N., Beckmann R., Cate J.H.D., Dinman J.D., Dragon F., Ellis S.R.,
RA   Lafontaine D.L.J., Lindahl L., Liljas A., Lipton J.M., McAlear M.A.,
RA   Moore P.B., Noller H.F., Ortega J., Panse V.G., Ramakrishnan V.,
RA   Spahn C.M.T., Steitz T.A., Tchorzewski M., Tollervey D., Warren A.J.,
RA   Williamson J.R., Wilson D., Yonath A., Yusupov M.;
RT   "A new system for naming ribosomal proteins.";
RL   Curr. Opin. Struct. Biol. 24:165-169(2014).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Component of the ribosome, a large ribonucleoprotein
CC       complex responsible for the synthesis of proteins in the cell. The
CC       small ribosomal subunit (SSU) binds messenger RNAs (mRNAs) and
CC       translates the encoded message by selecting cognate aminoacyl-
CC       transfer RNA (tRNA) molecules. The large subunit (LSU) contains
CC       the ribosomal catalytic site termed the peptidyl transferase
CC       center (PTC), which catalyzes the formation of peptide bonds,
CC       thereby polymerizing the amino acids delivered by tRNAs into a
CC       polypeptide chain. The nascent polypeptides leave the ribosome
CC       through a tunnel in the LSU and interact with protein factors that
CC       function in enzymatic processing, targeting, and the membrane
CC       insertion of nascent chains at the exit of the ribosomal tunnel.
CC       {ECO:0000305|PubMed:22096102}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the large ribosomal subunit (LSU). Mature
CC       yeast ribosomes consist of a small (40S) and a large (60S)
CC       subunit. The 40S small subunit contains 1 molecule of ribosomal
CC       RNA (18S rRNA) and 33 different proteins (encoded by 57 genes).
CC       The large 60S subunit contains 3 rRNA molecules (25S, 5.8S and 5S
CC       rRNA) and 46 different proteins (encoded by 81 genes)
CC       (PubMed:9559554, PubMed:22096102). The 5 acidic ribosomal P-
CC       proteins form the stalk structure of the 60S subunit. They are
CC       organized as a pentameric complex in which uL10/P0 interacts with
CC       2 heterodimers, P1A-P2B and P1B-P2A (PubMed:16573688,
CC       PubMed:11431471). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11431471,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16573688, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22096102,
CC       ECO:0000305|PubMed:9559554}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P05317:RPP0; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-15452, EBI-15447;
CC       P02400:RPP2B; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-15452, EBI-15464;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22096102}.
CC   -!- PTM: N-terminally acetylated by acetyltransferase NatA.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10601260, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8476850}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: The 4 small acidic ribosomal P-proteins from yeast
CC       can be classified into two couples of similar but not identical
CC       sequences. Each couple (P1A/P1B and P2A/P2B) is distinctly related
CC       to one of the two acidic ribosomal P-proteins P1/P2 present in
CC       multicellular organisms. {ECO:0000305|PubMed:2404943}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the eukaryotic ribosomal protein P1/P2
CC       family. {ECO:0000305}.

RN   [31]
RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (2.3 ANGSTROMS) OF 2-322, ADP-BINDING, AND
RP   FUNCTION.
RX   PubMed=22019086; DOI=10.1016/j.cmet.2011.09.009;
RA   Mayer F.V., Heath R., Underwood E., Sanders M.J., Carmena D.,
RA   McCartney R.R., Leiper F.C., Xiao B., Jing C., Walker P.A.,
RA   Haire L.F., Ogrodowicz R., Martin S.R., Schmidt M.C., Gamblin S.J.,
RA   Carling D.;
RT   "ADP regulates SNF1, the Saccharomyces cerevisiae homolog of AMP-
RT   activated protein kinase.";
RL   Cell Metab. 14:707-714(2011).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Adenine nucleotides-binding subunit gamma of AMP-
CC       activated protein kinase (AMPK), an energy sensor protein kinase
CC       that plays a key role in regulating cellular energy metabolism. In
CC       response to reduction of intracellular ATP levels, AMPK activates
CC       energy-producing pathways and inhibits energy-consuming processes:
CC       inhibits protein, carbohydrate and lipid biosynthesis, as well as
CC       cell growth and proliferation. AMPK acts via direct
CC       phosphorylation of metabolic enzymes, and by longer-term effects
CC       via phosphorylation of transcription regulators. Gamma non-
CC       catalytic subunit mediates binding to AMP, ADP and ATP, leading to
CC       activate or inhibit AMPK: AMP-binding results in allosteric
CC       activation of alpha catalytic subunit (SNF1) both by inducing
CC       phosphorylation and preventing dephosphorylation of catalytic
CC       subunits. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10099331,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:10224244, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11486005,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12393914, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12960168,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:1468623, ECO:0000269|PubMed:18474591,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:2169717, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22019086,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:2557546, ECO:0000269|PubMed:3049551,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:3939253, ECO:0000269|PubMed:6392017,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:7050076, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8224185,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8544831, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8985180,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9600950}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: AMPK is a heterotrimer of an alpha catalytic subunit
CC       (SNF1), a beta (SIP1, SIP2 or GAL83) and a gamma non-catalytic
CC       subunits (SNF4). Note=Interaction between SNF1 and SNF4 is
CC       inhibited by high levels of glucose. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12393914,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16847059, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17851534}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Self; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-17537, EBI-17537;
CC       P32578:SIP1; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-17537, EBI-17179;
CC       P34164:SIP2; NbExp=9; IntAct=EBI-17537, EBI-17187;
CC       P06782:SNF1; NbExp=21; IntAct=EBI-17537, EBI-17516;
CC       P25575:YCL046W; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-17537, EBI-21748;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17237508,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:2481228, ECO:0000269|PubMed:3049255}. Cytoplasm
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17237508, ECO:0000269|PubMed:2481228}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The 4 CBS domains mediate binding to nucleotides. Of the 4
CC       potential nucleotide-binding sites, 2 are occupied, designated as
CC       sites 2 and 3 based on the CBS modules that provide the acidic
CC       residue for coordination with the 2'- and 3'-hydroxyl groups of
CC       the ribose of AMP. Site 3 can bind either AMP, ADP or ATP (AMP,
CC       ADP or ATP 2). Site 2 binds specifically ADP (ADP 1) and is likely
CC       to be responsible for protection of a conserved threonine in the
CC       activation loop of the alpha catalytic subunit through
CC       conformational changes induced by binding of ADP
CC       (PubMed:22019086). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22019086}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Leads to a decrease in the length of G1 with
CC       respect to the wild-type strain along with a smaller difference in
CC       the cell cycle length of parent and daughter cells.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9841784}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 11700 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the 5'-AMP-activated protein kinase gamma
CC       subunit family. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   LEVEL OF PROTEIN EXPRESSION [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS].
RX   PubMed=14562106; DOI=10.1038/nature02046;
RA   Ghaemmaghami S., Huh W.-K., Bower K., Howson R.W., Belle A.,
RA   Dephoure N., O'Shea E.K., Weissman J.S.;
RT   "Global analysis of protein expression in yeast.";
RL   Nature 425:737-741(2003).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Component of the COP9 signalosome (CSN) complex that
CC       acts as an regulator of the ubiquitin (Ubl) conjugation pathway by
CC       mediating the deneddylation of the cullin subunit of SCF-type E3
CC       ubiquitin-protein ligase complexes. The CSN complex is involved in
CC       the regulation of the mating pheromone response. CSN12 forms a
CC       complex with THP3 that is recruited to transcribed genes and
CC       required for transcription elongation.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12446563, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19061648,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19289793, ECO:0000269|PubMed:21149575}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of a COP9 signalosome-like (CSN) complex,
CC       composed of RRI1/CSN5, CSN9, RRI2/CSN10, PCI8/CSN11, CSN12 and
CC       CSI1. In the complex, it probably interacts directly with
CC       RRI1/CSN5, CSN9, RRI2/CSN10 and CSI1. Interacts with SEM1 and
CC       THP3. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12446563, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12672462,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19061648, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19289793,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:21149575}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q12468:RRI1; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-763, EBI-37511;
CC       Q12049:THP3; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-763, EBI-34263;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095}.
CC       Nucleus {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 1510 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the CSN12 family. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   UBIQUITINATION [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS] AT LYS-154, AND IDENTIFICATION

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Has phosphatase activity in vitro. Involved in the
CC       response to sodium and lithium ion stress (but not to potassium or
CC       sorbitol stress) by inducing transcription of the sodium pump
CC       ENA1/PMR2. Acts through a calcineurin-independent pathway and is
CC       functionally redundant with PSR2. Also involved in the general
CC       stress response; acts together with WHI2 to activate stress
CC       response element (STRE)-mediated gene expression, possibly through
CC       dephosphorylation of MSN2. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10777497,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12090248, ECO:0000303|PubMed:12090248}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with WHI2. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12090248}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P12611:WHI2; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-31129, EBI-20530;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10777497,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 5620 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Catalyzes the introduction of a C-5 double bond in the B
CC       ring of ergosterol. May contribute to the regulation of ergosterol
CC       biosynthesis. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:1864507}.

CC       O(2) + 2 H(+) = a Delta(5,7)-sterol + 2 ferricytochrome b5 + 2
CC       H(2)O. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:1864507}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Component of the ESCRT-I complex, a regulator of
CC       vesicular trafficking process. Required for normal endocytic and
CC       biosynthetic traffic to the yeast vacuole.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the ESCRT-I complex (endosomal sorting
CC       complex required for transport I) which consists of STP22, VPS28,
CC       SRN2 and MVB12 in a 1:1:1:1 stoichiometry. Interacts with STP22
CC       and MVB12. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16615893,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16615894, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17442384,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9790597}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Alternate catalytic subunit of the 1,3-beta-glucan
CC       synthase (GS). Synthesizes 1,3-beta-glucan, a major structural
CC       component of the yeast cell wall. Involved in cell wall synthesis,
CC       maintenance and cell wall remodeling.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11856368}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: UDP-glucose + ((1->3)-beta-D-glucosyl)(n) =
CC       UDP + ((1->3)-beta-D-glucosyl)(n+1). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12185837,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12399379, ECO:0000269|PubMed:7528927,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:7592316, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8662910}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the 1,3-beta-glucan synthase (GS), composed
CC       of two alternate catalytic subunits FKS1 or GSC2, and a regulatory
CC       subunit RHO1. Interacts with RHO1, which is a GTP-binding protein.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:8602515, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8662910}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P06780:RHO1; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-7708, EBI-15121;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Mitochondrion {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11856368,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12185837, ECO:0000269|PubMed:14576278,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16823961, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8602515}. Cell
CC       membrane {ECO:0000305}; Multi-pass membrane protein {ECO:0000305}.
CC       Note=Localizes to the sites of polarized growth. Colocalizes with
CC       cortical actin patches and moves on the cell surface at the sites
CC       of cell wall remodeling. Actin patch motility is required for the
CC       movement. Early at the cell cycle, localizes at the presumed bud
CC       site of the mother cell and at the tip of the small bud. As the
CC       bud enlarges, appears as discernible spots in the medium-sized bud
CC       and these spots colocalize with actin patches. Late in the cell
CC       cycle, disappears in large budded cells, while the actin patches
CC       disperse over the cell. During cytokinesis, is concentrated in the
CC       neck, overlapping with the location of cortical actin patches.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: During vegetative growth. Expressed periodically during
CC       the cell cycle. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:7565718}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Cells are hypersensitive to
CC       immunosuppressant drugs FK506 and cyclosporin A (CsA) due to the
CC       inhibition of calcineurin phosphatase activity by the receptor-
CC       drug complexes and is dependent on calcineurin for vegetative
CC       growth. It confers a slow growth phenotype which is partially
CC       suppressed by exogenously added Ca(2+) and exacerbated by EGTA.
CC       Simultaneous disruption of CNA1 and CNA2 or CNB1 is lethal in
CC       FKS1-1. Disruption of FPR1 or CPR1 results in the loss of
CC       hypersensitivity. Overexpression of CNA1 or CNA2, in conjunction
CC       with CNB1, results in a significant decrease in hypersensitivity
CC       to FK506 and CsA. FKS1-8 mutant is sensitive to FK506 and
CC       cyclosporin A, has increased tendency to lyse and exhibits slow
CC       growth that is improved by the addition of osmotic stabilizing
CC       agents. It is more sensitive to the drugs when grown on galactose
CC       compared to dextrose. ETG1-1 mutant is resistant to the cell wall
CC       active echinocandins, which are inhibitors of 1,3-beta-D-glucan
CC       synthase. ETG1-4 mutant is hypersensitive to the chitin synthase
CC       inhibitor nikkomycin Z. Deletion of FKS1 leads to hypersensitivity
CC       to echinocandin-like antifungal lipopeptide caspofungin, a 1,3-
CC       beta-glucan synthase inhibitor. Deletion mutant also displays a
CC       30% reduction in 1,3-beta-glucan and 15% reduction in alkali-
CC       insoluble 1,6-beta-glucan compared to wild-type.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14693557, ECO:0000269|PubMed:7510323,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:7528927, ECO:0000269|PubMed:7530227,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:7542741, ECO:0000269|PubMed:7592316}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the glycosyltransferase 48 family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

RT   "Structural and functional analysis of the killer element pPin1-3 from
RT   Pichia inositovora.";
RL   Mol. Genet. Genomics 270:190-199(2003).
RN   [12]
RP   SUBCELLULAR LOCATION [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS].
RX   PubMed=14562095; DOI=10.1038/nature02026;
RA   Huh W.-K., Falvo J.V., Gerke L.C., Carroll A.S., Howson R.W.,
RA   Weissman J.S., O'Shea E.K.;
RT   "Global analysis of protein localization in budding yeast.";
RL   Nature 425:686-691(2003).
RN   [13]
RP   LEVEL OF PROTEIN EXPRESSION [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS].
RX   PubMed=14562106; DOI=10.1038/nature02046;
RA   Ghaemmaghami S., Huh W.-K., Bower K., Howson R.W., Belle A.,
RA   Dephoure N., O'Shea E.K., Weissman J.S.;
RT   "Global analysis of protein expression in yeast.";
RL   Nature 425:737-741(2003).
RN   [14]
RP   FUNCTION IN EXOCYTOSIS REGULATION, INTERACTION WITH SEC2, AND
RP   SUBCELLULAR LOCATION.
RX   PubMed=15780940; DOI=10.1016/j.molcel.2005.02.018;
RA   Rahl P.B., Chen C.Z., Collins R.N.;
RT   "Elp1p, the yeast homolog of the FD disease syndrome protein,
RT   negatively regulates exocytosis independently of transcriptional
RT   elongation.";
RL   Mol. Cell 17:841-853(2005).
RN   [15]
RP   FUNCTION IN TRNA MODIFICATION.
RX   PubMed=15769872; DOI=10.1261/rna.7247705;
RA   Huang B., Johansson M.J.O., Bystroem A.S.;
RT   "An early step in wobble uridine tRNA modification requires the
RT   Elongator complex.";
RL   RNA 11:424-436(2005).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Acts as component of the RNA polymerase II elongator
CC       complex, which is a major histone acetyltransferase component of
CC       the RNA polymerase II (RNAPII) holoenzyme and is involved in
CC       transcriptional elongation. Association with elongating RNAPII
CC       requires a hyperphosphorylated state of the RNAPII C-terminal
CC       domain (CTD). Elongator binds to both naked and nucleosomal DNA,
CC       can acetylate both core and nucleosomal histones, and is involved
CC       in chromatin remodeling. It acetylates histones H3, preferentially
CC       at 'Lys-14', and H4, preferentially at 'Lys-8'. It functions as a
CC       gamma-toxin target (TOT); disruption of the complex confers
CC       resistance to Kluyveromyces lactis toxin zymocin (pGKL1 killer
CC       toxin). May also be involved in sensitiviy to Pichia inositovora
CC       toxin. May be involved in tRNA modification. Independently, ELP3
CC       may be involved in polarized exocytosis. It is required for the
CC       polarized localization of GTPase-activating protein SEC2. Is
CC       required for an early step in synthesis of 5-methoxycarbonylmethyl
CC       (mcm5) and 5-carbamoylmethyl (ncm5) groups present on uridines at
CC       the wobble position in tRNA. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10024884,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11296232, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11689709,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11904415, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12424236,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:13680368, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15769872,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15780940}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the RNA polymerase II elongator complex,
CC       which consists of IKI3, ELP2, ELP3, ELP4, IKI1 and ELP6. IKI3,
CC       ELP2, and ELP3 form the elongator core complex. In the complex,
CC       IKI3 interacts with ELP2. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11435442,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11689709, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12139626,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15780940}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Self; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-9068, EBI-9068;
CC       P42935:ELP2; NbExp=11; IntAct=EBI-9068, EBI-23459;
CC       Q02884:ELP4; NbExp=12; IntAct=EBI-9068, EBI-35277;
CC       Q04868:ELP6; NbExp=7; IntAct=EBI-9068, EBI-27653;
CC       P38874:IKI1; NbExp=10; IntAct=EBI-9068, EBI-9061;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15780940}.
CC       Nucleus {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10024884}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 10500 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ELP1/IKA1 family. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   ERRATUM.
RA   Jeong H.-S., Backlund P.S., Chen H.-C., Karavanov A.A., Crouch R.J.;
RL   Nucleic Acids Res. 32:1616-1616(2004).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Catalytic subunit of RNase HII, an endonuclease that
CC       specifically degrades the RNA of RNA:DNA hybrids. Participates in
CC       DNA replication, possibly by mediating the removal of lagging-
CC       strand Okazaki fragment RNA primers during DNA replication.
CC       Mediates the excision of single ribonucleotides from DNA:RNA
CC       duplexes.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Endonucleolytic cleavage to 5'-
CC       phosphomonoester.
CC   -!- COFACTOR:
CC       Name=Mn(2+); Xref=ChEBI:CHEBI:29035; Evidence={ECO:0000250};
CC       Name=Mg(2+); Xref=ChEBI:CHEBI:18420; Evidence={ECO:0000250};
CC       Note=Manganese or magnesium. Binds 1 divalent metal ion per
CC       monomer in the absence of substrate. May bind a second metal ion
CC       after substrate binding. {ECO:0000250};
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: The RNase 2 complex is a heterotrimer composed of the
CC       catalytic subunit RNH201 and of the non-catalytic subunits RNH202
CC       and RNH203.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q05635:RNH202; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-15663, EBI-33940;
CC       Q12338:RNH203; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-15663, EBI-33805;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095}.
CC       Nucleus {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 623 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the RNase HII family. Eukaryotic subfamily.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (1.45 ANGSTROMS) OF 301-320, AND INTERACTION
RP   WITH UBIQUITIN.
RX   PubMed=12750381; DOI=10.1074/jbc.M302596200;
RA   Fisher R.D., Wang B., Alam S.L., Higginson D.S., Robinson H.,
RA   Sundquist W.I., Hill C.P.;
RT   "Structure and ubiquitin binding of the ubiquitin-interacting motif.";
RL   J. Biol. Chem. 278:28976-28984(2003).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Component of the ESCRT-0 complex which is the sorting
CC       receptor for ubiquitinated cargo proteins at the multivesicular
CC       body (MVB) and recruits ESCRT-I to the MVB outer membrane.
CC       Controls exit from the prevacuolar compartment (PVC) in both the
CC       forward direction to the vacuole and the return to the Golgi.
CC       Allows VPS10 to return to the (trans-Golgi network) TGN from the
CC       PVC. Might also function as an alternate adapter in the COPIb
CC       clathrin-like coat. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11208109,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11416128, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11872141,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12055639, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12900393,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:14581452, ECO:0000269|PubMed:1493335,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15086794, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15107463,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15166140, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17101773,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17135292, ECO:0000269|PubMed:3062374,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8649377, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9015300,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9265642}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the ESCRT-0 complex composed of HSE1 and
CC       VPS27. Interacts with ENT3 and ENT5, the ESCRT-I subunits VPS23
CC       and VPS28 and with the COPIb subunits SEC27, SEC28 and SEC33.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11988742, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12055639,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12750381, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12900393,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:14581452, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15086794,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15107463, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17101773}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P38753:HSE1; NbExp=8; IntAct=EBI-20380, EBI-1382;
CC       P40509:SEC28; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-20380, EBI-4884;
CC       P25604:STP22; NbExp=7; IntAct=EBI-20380, EBI-411625;
CC       P0CG53:UBB (xeno); NbExp=6; IntAct=EBI-20380, EBI-5333021;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Endosome membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12006563, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12900393,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15169871,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17101773, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17101785};
CC       Peripheral membrane protein {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12006563,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12900393, ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15169871, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17101773,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17101785}; Cytoplasmic side
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12006563, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12900393,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15169871,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17101773, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17101785}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The FYVE domain is involved in the binding to
CC       phosphatidylinositol 3-phosphate (PtdIns(3)P) which is required
CC       for the association to endosomal membranes.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: Both IUM domains are necessary for efficient binding to
CC       ubiquitin.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 172 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the VPS27 family. {ECO:0000305}.

RN   [12]
RP   STRUCTURE BY ELECTRON MICROSCOPY (3.20 ANGSTROMS), AND SUBUNIT.
RX   PubMed=24675956; DOI=10.1126/science.1249410;
RA   Amunts A., Brown A., Bai X.C., Llacer J.L., Hussain T., Emsley P.,
RA   Long F., Murshudov G., Scheres S.H., Ramakrishnan V.;
RT   "Structure of the yeast mitochondrial large ribosomal subunit.";
RL   Science 343:1485-1489(2014).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Component of the mitochondrial ribosome (mitoribosome),
CC       a dedicated translation machinery responsible for the synthesis of
CC       mitochondrial genome-encoded proteins, including at least some of
CC       the essential transmembrane subunits of the mitochondrial
CC       respiratory chain. The mitoribosomes are attached to the
CC       mitochondrial inner membrane and translation products are
CC       cotranslationally integrated into the membrane.
CC       {ECO:0000305|PubMed:24675956, ECO:0000305|PubMed:25609543}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the mitochondrial large ribosomal subunit
CC       (mt-LSU). Mature yeast 74S mitochondrial ribosomes consist of a
CC       small (37S) and a large (54S) subunit. The 37S small subunit
CC       contains a 15S ribosomal RNA (15S mt-rRNA) and 34 different
CC       proteins. The 54S large subunit contains a 21S rRNA (21S mt-rRNA)
CC       and 46 different proteins. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12392552,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:24675956}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Mitochondrion {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:14576278}. Note=Mitoribosomes are tethered to
CC       the mitochondrial inner membrane and spatially aligned with the
CC       membrane insertion machinery through two distinct membrane contact
CC       sites, formed by the 21S rRNA expansion segment 96-ES1 and the
CC       inner membrane protein MBA1. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:25609543}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Although this protein has evidently no
CC       mitochondrial targeting pre-sequence, it is efficiently
CC       transported into mitochondria.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 3000 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the bacterial ribosomal protein bL17
CC       family. {ECO:0000305}.

RX   PubMed=8910557; DOI=10.1074/jbc.271.46.29043;

RT   excretion of inositol by Saccharomyces cerevisiae.";
RL   J. Biol. Chem. 271:29043-29048(1996).
RN   [9]
RP   SUBCELLULAR LOCATION.
RX   PubMed=23623749; DOI=10.1016/j.cmet.2013.03.018;
RA   Tamura Y., Harada Y., Nishikawa S., Yamano K., Kamiya M., Shiota T.,
RA   Kuroda T., Kuge O., Sesaki H., Imai K., Tomii K., Endo T.;
RT   "Tam41 is a CDP-diacylglycerol synthase required for cardiolipin
RT   biosynthesis in mitochondria.";
RL   Cell Metab. 17:709-718(2013).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Supplies CDP-diacylglycerol, which may play an important
CC       role as both a precursor to phosphoinositide biosynthesis in the
CC       plasma membrane and as a negative effector of phosphatidylinositol
CC       4-kinase activity, thereby exerting an effect on cell
CC       proliferation via a lipid-dependent signal transduction cascade.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:2822695, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8557688}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: CTP + phosphatidate = diphosphate + CDP-
CC       diacylglycerol. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:2822695}.
CC   -!- COFACTOR:
CC       Name=Mg(2+); Xref=ChEBI:CHEBI:18420;
CC         Evidence={ECO:0000269|PubMed:2822695};
CC   -!- BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES:
CC       Kinetic parameters:
CC         KM=1 mM for CTP {ECO:0000269|PubMed:2822695};
CC         KM=0.5 mM for phosphatidate {ECO:0000269|PubMed:2822695};
CC         Vmax=4700 nmol/min/mg enzyme {ECO:0000269|PubMed:2822695};
CC       pH dependence:
CC         Optimum pH is 6.5. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:2822695};
CC   -!- PATHWAY: Phospholipid metabolism; CDP-diacylglycerol biosynthesis;
CC       CDP-diacylglycerol from sn-glycerol 3-phosphate: step 3/3.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homodimer.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Endoplasmic reticulum membrane; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein. Cytoplasmic vesicle, secretory vesicle.
CC       Note=Exclusively present in the ER, and not in mitochondria. Also
CC       associated with post-Golgi apparatus secretory vesicles destined
CC       for the plasma membrane.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the CDS family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Catalytic component of the TFIIK complex (KIN28-CCL1
CC       dimer) which is the protein kinase component of transcription
CC       factor IIH (TFIIH) and phosphorylates the C-terminal domain of RNA
CC       polymerase II during transition from transcription to elongation
CC       after preinitiation complex (PIC) formation, thereby positively
CC       regulating transcription. TFIIH (or factor B) is essential for
CC       both basal and activated transcription, and is involved in
CC       nucleotide excision repair (NER) of damaged DNA. TFIIH has DNA-
CC       dependent ATPase activity and is essential for polymerase II
CC       transcription in vitro. Essential for cell proliferation.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10594013}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: ATP + [DNA-directed RNA polymerase] = ADP +
CC       [DNA-directed RNA polymerase] phosphate.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: CCL1 and KIN28 form the TFIIK complex, a component of the
CC       TFIIH holo complex. Component of a complex consisting of KIN28,
CC       CCL1 and TFB3. Interacts with TFB3. Also interacts with HNT1 and
CC       HOG1. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10958787, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11839796,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12743037, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8230216,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9235928}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P37366:CCL1; NbExp=7; IntAct=EBI-9691, EBI-4385;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095}.
CC   -!- PTM: Phosphorylation of Thr-162 regulates the affinity of
CC       interaction between CCL1, KIN28 and TFB3. Thr-162 phosphorylation
CC       does not vary through the cell cycle and is necessary for full
CC       kinase activity. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10373527,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11839796, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9774652}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 4400 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the protein kinase superfamily. CMGC
CC       Ser/Thr protein kinase family. CDC2/CDKX subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

RT   "Mutation of Nogo-B receptor, a subunit of cis-prenyltransferase,
RT   causes a congenital disorder of glycosylation.";
RL   Cell Metab. 20:448-457(2014).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: With SRT1 or RER2, forms the dehydrodolichyl diphosphate
CC       synthase (DDS) complex, an essential component of the dolichol
CC       monophosphate (Dol-P) biosynthetic machinery. Adds multiple copies
CC       of isopentenyl pyrophosphate (IPP) to farnesyl pyrophosphate (FPP)
CC       to produce dehydrodolichyl diphosphate (Dedol-PP), a precursor of
CC       dolichol which is utilized as a sugar carrier in protein
CC       glycosylation in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:25066056}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: (2E,6E)-farnesyl diphosphate + n isopentenyl
CC       diphosphate = n diphosphate + ditrans,polycis-polyprenyl
CC       diphosphate (n = 10-55). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:25066056}.
CC   -!- PATHWAY: Protein modification; protein glycosylation.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Forms an active dehydrodolichyl diphosphate synthase
CC       complex with either SRT1 or RER2. {ECO:0000303|PubMed:25066056}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Endoplasmic reticulum membrane
CC       {ECO:0000305}; Single-pass membrane protein {ECO:0000305}. Lipid
CC       droplet {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10515935, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11086160,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095, ECO:0000269|PubMed:14690591}. Nucleus
CC       membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14690591}; Single-pass membrane
CC       protein {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the UPP synthase family. {ECO:0000305}.

RA   Olzhausen J., Schuebbe S., Schueller H.-J.;

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Reversibly transfers an adenylyl group from ATP to 4'-
CC       phosphopantetheine, yielding dephospho-CoA (dPCoA) and
CC       pyrophosphate (By similarity). Plays a role in the physiological
CC       regulation of the intracellular CoA concentration. {ECO:0000250,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19266201}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: ATP + pantetheine 4'-phosphate = diphosphate +
CC       3'-dephospho-CoA.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: May be involved in the late step of 60S ribosomal
CC       subunit assembly or modification in the cytoplasm.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts strongly with QSR1. Part of an oligomeric
CC       protein complex that is loosely associated with ribosomes.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 19700 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
