RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (2.6 ANGSTROMS) OF 80-105 IN COMPLEX WITH PAP1,
RP   SUBUNIT, DOMAIN, AND CIRCULAR DICHROISM.
RX   PubMed=18537269; DOI=10.1021/bi800204k;
RA   Meinke G., Ezeokonkwo C., Balbo P., Stafford W., Moore C., Bohm A.;
RT   "Structure of yeast poly(A) polymerase in complex with a peptide from
RT   Fip1, an intrinsically disordered protein.";
RL   Biochemistry 47:6859-6869(2008).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Polymerase-regulating component of the cleavage and
CC       polyadenylation factor (CPF) complex, which plays a key role in
CC       polyadenylation-dependent pre-mRNA 3'-end formation and cooperates
CC       with cleavage factors including the CFIA complex and NAB4/CFIB.
CC       Pre-mRNA polyadenylation factor that directly interacts with
CC       poly(A) polymerase PAP1. This inhibits the extension of an
CC       oligo(A) primer by limiting access of the RNA substrate to the C-
CC       terminal RNA binding domain of PAP1. Seems to tether PAP1 to the
CC       cleavage factor I. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11238938}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the cleavage and polyadenylation factor
CC       (CPF) complex, which is composed of PTI1, SYC1, SSU72, GLC7, MPE1,
CC       REF2, PFS2, PTA1, YSH1/BRR5, SWD2, CFT2/YDH1, YTH1, CFT1/YHH1,
CC       FIP1 and PAP1. In the CPF complex probably interacts directly with
CC       PAP1 and YTH1. Interacts with RNA14. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10619842,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11238938, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12626716,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12819204, ECO:0000269|PubMed:18537269,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:7736590}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P29468:PAP1; NbExp=9; IntAct=EBI-6940, EBI-12917;
CC       Q01329:PTA1; NbExp=5; IntAct=EBI-6940, EBI-14145;
CC       Q06102:YTH1; NbExp=5; IntAct=EBI-6940, EBI-38049;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12819204}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: Circular dichroism measurements suggest that the protein
CC       is largely unstructured in the absence of interaction with PAP1.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18537269}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 1310 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the FIP1 family. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (2.3 ANGSTROMS).
RX   PubMed=9145106; DOI=10.1038/nsb0597-366;
RA   Fedorov A.A., Lappalainen P., Fedorov E.V., Drubin D.G., Almo S.C.;
RT   "Structure determination of yeast cofilin.";
RL   Nat. Struct. Biol. 4:366-369(1997).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Controls reversibly actin polymerization and
CC       depolymerization in a pH-sensitive manner. It has the ability to
CC       bind G- and F-actin in a 1:1 ratio of cofilin to actin. Binding to
CC       F-actin is regulated by tropomyosin. It is the major component of
CC       intranuclear and cytoplasmic actin rods. Required for accumulation
CC       of actin at the cell division site via depolymerizing actin at the
CC       cell ends. In association with myosin II has a role in the
CC       assembly of the contractile ring via severing actin filaments.
CC       Involved in the maintenance of the contractile ring once formed.
CC       In association with profilin and capping protein, has a role in
CC       the mitotic reorganization of the actin cytoskeleton. In effect,
CC       yeast cofilin increases the rate of actin polymerization by making
CC       new ends available for actin subunit addition. Such a protein
CC       complex is important for the polarized growth of yeast cells.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10231390, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11747431}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with actin and AIP1 in a ternary complex.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10366597}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P60010:ACT1; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-4853, EBI-2169;
CC       P68135:ACTA1 (xeno); NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-4853, EBI-367540;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10231390}.
CC       Cytoplasm, cytoskeleton {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10231390}. Nucleus
CC       matrix {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10231390}. Note=Throughout the
CC       cytoplasm (but not on the cytoplasmic cables) and major component
CC       of the cortical actin cytoskeleton.
CC   -!- PTM: The N-terminus is blocked.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 19600 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the actin-binding proteins ADF family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (4.0 ANGSTROMS) OF 80S RIBOSOME.
RX   PubMed=21109664; DOI=10.1126/science.1194294;
RA   Ben-Shem A., Jenner L., Yusupova G., Yusupov M.;

RN   [12]
RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (3.0 ANGSTROMS) OF 80S RIBOSOME, SUBUNIT, AND
RP   SUBCELLULAR LOCATION.
RX   PubMed=22096102; DOI=10.1126/science.1212642;
RA   Ben-Shem A., Garreau de Loubresse N., Melnikov S., Jenner L.,
RA   Yusupova G., Yusupov M.;
RT   "The structure of the eukaryotic ribosome at 3.0 A resolution.";
RL   Science 334:1524-1529(2011).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Component of the ribosome, a large ribonucleoprotein
CC       complex responsible for the synthesis of proteins in the cell. The
CC       small ribosomal subunit (SSU) binds messenger RNAs (mRNAs) and
CC       translates the encoded message by selecting cognate aminoacyl-
CC       transfer RNA (tRNA) molecules. The large subunit (LSU) contains
CC       the ribosomal catalytic site termed the peptidyl transferase
CC       center (PTC), which catalyzes the formation of peptide bonds,
CC       thereby polymerizing the amino acids delivered by tRNAs into a
CC       polypeptide chain. The nascent polypeptides leave the ribosome
CC       through a tunnel in the LSU and interact with protein factors that
CC       function in enzymatic processing, targeting, and the membrane
CC       insertion of nascent chains at the exit of the ribosomal tunnel.
CC       {ECO:0000305|PubMed:22096102}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the large ribosomal subunit (LSU). Mature
CC       yeast ribosomes consist of a small (40S) and a large (60S)
CC       subunit. The 40S small subunit contains 1 molecule of ribosomal
CC       RNA (18S rRNA) and 33 different proteins (encoded by 57 genes).
CC       The large 60S subunit contains 3 rRNA molecules (25S, 5.8S and 5S
CC       rRNA) and 46 different proteins (encoded by 81 genes)
CC       (PubMed:9559554, PubMed:22096102). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22096102,
CC       ECO:0000305|PubMed:9559554}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22096102}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: There are 2 genes for eL15 in yeast. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the eukaryotic ribosomal protein eL15
CC       family. {ECO:0000305}.

RN   [13]
RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (2.2 ANGSTROMS) OF 34-455 IN COMPLEX WITH
RP   MYRISTOYL-COA AND SUBSTRATE.
RX   PubMed=11371195; DOI=10.1021/bi0101401;
RA   Farazi T.A., Waksman G., Gordon J.I.;
RT   "Structures of Saccharomyces cerevisiae N-myristoyltransferase with
RT   bound myristoylCoA and peptide provide insights about substrate
RT   recognition and catalysis.";
RL   Biochemistry 40:6335-6343(2001).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Adds a myristoyl group to the N-terminal glycine residue
CC       of certain cellular proteins. Substrate specificity requires an N-
CC       terminal glycine in the nascent polypeptide substrates. Uncharged
CC       amino acids are preferred at position 2 while neutral residues are
CC       favored at positions 3 and 4. Ser is present at position 5 in
CC       almost all known N-myristoyl proteins and Lys is commonly
CC       encountered at postion 6.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Tetradecanoyl-CoA + glycylpeptide = CoA + N-
CC       tetradecanoylglycylpeptide.
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: Inhibited by diethylpyrocarbonate.
CC       Competitively inhibited by S-(2-oxo)pentadecyl-CoA, a non
CC       hydrolysable myristoyl-CoA analog, and by SC-58272, a
CC       peptidomimetic derived from the N-terminal sequence of a natural
CC       substrate.
CC   -!- BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES:
CC       Kinetic parameters:
CC         KM=1.4 uM for myristoyl-CoA {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11478885,
CC         ECO:0000269|PubMed:3106975};
CC       pH dependence:
CC         Optimum pH is 7.5-8.0. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11478885,
CC         ECO:0000269|PubMed:3106975};
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Monomer. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11371195,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9846880}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095}.
CC   -!- PTM: The N-terminus is blocked.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Has an ordered Bi-Bi kinetic mechanism, with
CC       myristoyl-CoA binding taking place prior to peptide binding and
CC       CoA release occurring before acylated peptide release. Cooperative
CC       interactions between the acyl-CoA and peptide binding sites of NMT
CC       contribute to its extraordinary chain-length specificity.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the NMT family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Acts on phosphatidylinositol (PI) in the first committed
CC       step in the production of the second messenger inositol 1,4,5,-
CC       trisphosphate. STT4 functions in PKC1 protein kinase pathway.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: ATP + 1-phosphatidyl-1D-myo-inositol = ADP +
CC       1-phosphatidyl-1D-myo-inositol 4-phosphate.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P46951:YPP1; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-18454, EBI-23455;
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 846 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the PI3/PI4-kinase family. Type III PI4K
CC       subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   CHARACTERIZATION.
RX   PubMed=1313947; DOI=10.1038/356532a0;
RA   Hann B.C., Stirling C.J., Walter P.;
RT   "SEC65 gene product is a subunit of the yeast signal recognition
RT   particle required for its integrity.";
RL   Nature 356:532-533(1992).
RN   [6]
RP   IDENTIFICATION IN THE SRP COMPLEX.
RX   PubMed=7925282;
RA   Brown J.D., Hann B.C., Medzihradszky K.F., Niwa M., Burlingame A.L.,
RA   Walter P.;
RT   "Subunits of the Saccharomyces cerevisiae signal recognition particle
RT   required for its functional expression.";
RL   EMBO J. 13:4390-4400(1994).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Signal-recognition-particle (SRP) assembly has a crucial
CC       role in targeting secretory proteins to the rough endoplasmic
CC       reticulum (ER) membrane. SRP is required for the cotranslational
CC       protein translocation for ER import and preferentially recognizes
CC       strongly hydrophobic signal sequences. It is involved in targeting
CC       the nascent chain-ribosome (RNC) complex to the ER and is proposed
CC       to participate in the arrest of nascent chain elongation during
CC       membrane targeting. SEC65 is required for SRP integrity.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Fungal signal recognition particle (SRP) complex consists
CC       of a 7S RNA molecule (scR1) and at least six protein subunits:
CC       SRP72, SRP68, SRP54, SEC65, SRP21 and SRP14.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:7925282}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P38985:SRP14; NbExp=7; IntAct=EBI-16641, EBI-17977;
CC       P32342:SRP21; NbExp=5; IntAct=EBI-16641, EBI-17984;
CC       P38688:SRP72; NbExp=8; IntAct=EBI-16641, EBI-18011;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000250}.

RP   PHOSPHORYLATION [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS] AT SER-110 AND SER-149, AND
RP   IDENTIFICATION BY MASS SPECTROMETRY [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS].
RX   PubMed=18407956; DOI=10.1074/mcp.M700468-MCP200;
RA   Albuquerque C.P., Smolka M.B., Payne S.H., Bafna V., Eng J., Zhou H.;

RN   [14]
RP   PHOSPHORYLATION [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS] AT SER-110, AND IDENTIFICATION
RP   BY MASS SPECTROMETRY [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS].
RX   PubMed=19779198; DOI=10.1126/science.1172867;
RA   Holt L.J., Tuch B.B., Villen J., Johnson A.D., Gygi S.P., Morgan D.O.;
RT   "Global analysis of Cdk1 substrate phosphorylation sites provides
RT   insights into evolution.";
RL   Science 325:1682-1686(2009).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: t-SNARE found in various SNARE complexes involved in
CC       multiple transport pathways. The composition of the t-SNARE
CC       complexes is specific for a limited number of v-SNAREs and
CC       therefore allows only the vesicles carrying the matching v-SNARE
CC       to fuse. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10385523,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11739407, ECO:0000269|PubMed:14981247}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Forms SNARE complexes with the t-SNAREs VAM3 and VAM7,
CC       and the v-SNAREs NYV1 and YKT6 on vacuolar membranes, which are
CC       involved in biosynthetic transport pathways to the vacuole and in
CC       homotypic vacuole fusion. Forms SNARE complexes with the cis-Golgi
CC       t-SNARE SED5 and the v-SNAREs SFT1 and YTK6, which are involved in
CC       retrograde traffic to the cis-Golgi compartment. Forms SNARE
CC       complexes with the t-SNAREs TLG1 and TLG2, and either the v-SNARE
CC       SNC1 or SNC2, which are involved in traffic from early endosomes
CC       to the trans-Golgi network (TGN). Forms SNARE complexes with the
CC       t-SNAREs PEP12 and either SYN8 or TLG1, and the v-SNARE SNC1,
CC       which are involved in traffic from the TGN to the prevacuolar
CC       compartment (PVC). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10385523}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P47160:ENT3; NbExp=7; IntAct=EBI-20519, EBI-25662;
CC       Q12255:NYV1; NbExp=11; IntAct=EBI-20519, EBI-35465;
CC       Q12241:VAM3; NbExp=12; IntAct=EBI-20519, EBI-20227;
CC       P36015:YKT6; NbExp=6; IntAct=EBI-20519, EBI-26982;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Prevacuolar compartment membrane; Single-
CC       pass type IV membrane protein. Golgi apparatus membrane; Single-
CC       pass type IV membrane protein. Note=A small portion is localized
CC       in the Golgi apparatus, the majority is localized in the PVC.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the VTI1 family. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   FUNCTION.
RX   PubMed=16413259; DOI=10.1016/S0076-6879(05)04008-5;
RA   Futai E., Schekman R.W.;

RL   Methods Enzymol. 404:74-82(2005).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Guanine nucleotide-exchange factor (GEF) required for
CC       the formation or budding of transport vesicles from the ER. This
CC       function involves the cytoplasmic domain of the protein, which is
CC       thought to interact with the small GTP-binding protein SAR1.
CC       Required for autophagy. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11694599,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12655150, ECO:0000269|PubMed:1327759,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16413259, ECO:0000269|PubMed:1649197,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:1907973, ECO:0000269|PubMed:1907974,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:1922074, ECO:0000269|PubMed:2512296,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:3047151, ECO:0000269|PubMed:6996832,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:7865879, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8106544,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8377826, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8583945,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9023343}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Endoplasmic reticulum membrane; Single-pass
CC       type II membrane protein. Golgi apparatus, cis-Golgi network
CC       membrane; Single-pass type II membrane protein. Note=Cycling
CC       between endoplasmic reticulum and the early Golgi.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: In the process of transport, SEC12 itself may
CC       migrate to the Golgi apparatus and function in subsequent
CC       transport events.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 6160 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the WD repeat SEC12 family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Possesses 5'->3' exoribonuclease activity. Required for
CC       the processing of nuclear mRNA, rRNA and small nucleolar RNA
CC       (snoRNA) precursors. May promote termination of transcription by
CC       RNA polymerase II via the recruitment of 3'-end processing factors
CC       to the poly(A) site and by the degradation of nascent RNA
CC       downstream of the poly(A) site. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10805743,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11030620, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11142370,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11238889, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12769851,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:14561886, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15565157,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16131592, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16598041,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:7608167, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8417335,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9207242, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9384595,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9488433, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9584178,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9891049}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Exonucleolytic cleavage in the 5'- to 3'-
CC       direction to yield nucleoside 5'-phosphates.
CC   -!- COFACTOR:
CC       Name=Mg(2+); Xref=ChEBI:CHEBI:18420;
CC         Evidence={ECO:0000269|PubMed:7608167,
CC         ECO:0000269|PubMed:8417335};
CC       Name=Mn(2+); Xref=ChEBI:CHEBI:29035;
CC         Evidence={ECO:0000269|PubMed:7608167,
CC         ECO:0000269|PubMed:8417335};
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: Inhibited by nucleoside 3', 5'-bisphosphates.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9384595}.
CC   -!- BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES:
CC       pH dependence:
CC         Optimum pH is 8.0-8.8. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:7608167};
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with RAI1 and RTT103.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10805743, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12612077,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15565157}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P53063:RAI1; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-14845, EBI-24206;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12612077,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8417335, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9315672}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 623 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the 5'-3' exonuclease family. XRN2/RAT1
CC       subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Part of the complex catalyzing the transfer of N-
CC       acetylglucosamine from UDP-N-acetylglucosamine to
CC       phosphatidylinositol, the first step of GPI biosynthesis.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:7768896}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: UDP-N-acetyl-D-glucosamine + 1-phosphatidyl-
CC       1D-myo-inositol = UDP + 6-(N-acetyl-alpha-D-glucosaminyl)-1-
CC       phosphatidyl-1D-myo-inositol.
CC   -!- PATHWAY: Glycolipid biosynthesis; glycosylphosphatidylinositol-
CC       anchor biosynthesis. {ECO:0000305|PubMed:7768896}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the phosphatidylinositol N-
CC       acetylglucosaminyltransferase (GPI-GlcNAc transferase) complex
CC       composed of at least GPI1, GPI2, GPI3, GPI15, GPI19 and ERI1
CC       (Probable). Interacts with ERI1 (PubMed:15163411).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15163411, ECO:0000305|PubMed:15163411}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane {ECO:0000305}; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the PIGC family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: May act as a molecular switch during maturation of the
CC       40S ribosomal subunit in the nucleolus. The depletion of BMS1
CC       interferes with processing of the 35S pre-rRNA at sites A0, A1,
CC       and A2, and the formation of 40S subunits.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11565748, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11565749}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Associates with RCL1.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q08096:RCL1; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-3683, EBI-14892;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11565749}.
CC       Nucleus, nucleolus {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11565749}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the TRAFAC class translation factor GTPase
CC       superfamily. Bms1-like GTPase family. BMS1 subfamily.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

RP   COMPOSITION OF THE COG COMPLEX, AND INTERACTION WITH COG1; COG2; COG5
RP   AND COG7.
RX   PubMed=15047703; DOI=10.1074/jbc.M400662200;
RA   Loh E., Hong W.;
RT   "The binary interacting network of the conserved oligomeric Golgi
RT   tethering complex.";
RL   J. Biol. Chem. 279:24640-24648(2004).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Acts as essential component of the peripheral membrane
CC       COG complex that is involved in intra-Golgi protein trafficking.
CC       COG is located at the cis-Golgi, and regulates tethering of
CC       retrograde intra-Golgi vesicles and possibly a number of other
CC       membrane trafficking events. COG4 is required for normal
CC       endoplasmic reticulum function and is also involved in calcium
CC       regulation. Possesses ATPase activity.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12006647, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12011112,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12058017}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the conserved oligomeric Golgi (COG or
CC       Sec34/Sec35) complex which consists of eight different proteins
CC       COG1-COG8. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11703943,

RN   [13]
RP   IDENTIFICATION BY MASS SPECTROMETRY [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS].
RX   PubMed=19779198; DOI=10.1126/science.1172867;
RA   Holt L.J., Tuch B.B., Villen J., Johnson A.D., Gygi S.P., Morgan D.O.;
RT   "Global analysis of Cdk1 substrate phosphorylation sites provides
RT   insights into evolution.";
RL   Science 325:1682-1686(2009).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Cleavable component of the cohesin complex involved in
CC       chromosome cohesion during cell cycle. The cohesin complex is
CC       required for the cohesion of sister chromatids after DNA
CC       replication. The cohesin complex apparently forms a large
CC       proteinaceous ring within which sister chromatids can be trapped.
CC       At metaphase-anaphase transition, this protein is cleaved by ESP1
CC       and dissociates from chromatin, allowing sister chromatids to
CC       segregate. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10403247,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9335333, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9335334,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9491073}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts directly with IRR1/SCC3 in cohesin complex.
CC       Cohesin complexes are composed of the SMC1 and SMC3 heterodimer
CC       attached via their hinge domain, MCD1/SCC1 which link them, and
CC       IRR1, which interacts with MCD1. The cohesin complex also
CC       interacts with SCC2, which is required for its association with
CC       chromosomes. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11983169,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9990856}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P40541:IRR1; NbExp=6; IntAct=EBI-16655, EBI-16667;
CC       P32908:SMC1; NbExp=8; IntAct=EBI-16655, EBI-17402;
CC       P47037:SMC3; NbExp=13; IntAct=EBI-16655, EBI-17423;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9335333,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9335334, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9990856}.
CC       Chromosome {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9335333,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9990856}. Chromosome, centromere
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9990856}. Note=Associates with chromatin.
CC       Before prophase it is scattered along chromosome arms. During
CC       prophase, most of cohesin complexes dissociate from chromatin
CC       except at centromeres, where cohesin complexes remain. At
CC       anaphase, it is cleaved by ESP1, leading to the dissociation of
CC       the complex from chromosomes, allowing chromosome separation.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9990856}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The C-terminal part associates with the head of SMC1,
CC       while the N-terminal part binds to the head of SMC3.
CC   -!- PTM: Cleaved by ESP1 at the onset of anaphase.
CC   -!- PTM: Phosphorylated by CDC5/Polo-like kinase at the onset of
CC       anaphase. Phosphorylation takes places at proximity to cleavage
CC       sites and is required for an efficient cleavage by ESP1.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10403247, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11371343}.
CC   -!- PTM: Acetylated by ECO1. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11864574}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 1040 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the rad21 family. {ECO:0000305}.

RN   [12]
RP   FUNCTION, CATALYTIC ACTIVITY, AND MUTAGENESIS OF VAL-87; GLU-103;
RP   ALA-175 AND PRO-219.
RX   PubMed=24352239; DOI=10.1038/nature12819;
RA   Tessarz P., Santos-Rosa H., Robson S.C., Sylvestersen K.B.,
RA   Nelson C.J., Nielsen M.L., Kouzarides T.;
RT   "Glutamine methylation in histone H2A is an RNA-polymerase-I-dedicated
RT   modification.";
RL   Nature 505:564-568(2014).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: S-adenosyl-L-methionine-dependent methyltransferase that
CC       has the ability to methylate both RNAs and proteins. Involved in
CC       pre-rRNA processing by catalyzing the site-specific 2'-hydroxyl
CC       methylation of ribose moieties in pre-ribosomal RNA
CC       (PubMed:1825809). Site specificity is provided by a guide RNA that
CC       base pairs with the substrate. Methylation occurs at a
CC       characteristic distance from the sequence involved in base pairing
CC       with the guide RNA. Involved in the biogenesis of the 18S rRNA.
CC       Also acts as a protein methyltransferase by mediating methylation
CC       of 'Gln-105' of histone H2A (H2AQ105me), a modification that
CC       impairs binding of the FACT complex and is specifically present at
CC       35S ribosomal DNA locus (PubMed:24352239).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:1825809, ECO:0000269|PubMed:24352239,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:2686980}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: S-adenosyl-L-methionine + L-glutamine-
CC       [histone] = S-adenosyl-L-homocysteine + N(5)-methyl-L-glutamine-
CC       [histone]. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:24352239}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of box C/D small nucleolar ribonucleoprotein
CC       (snoRNP) particles that contain SNU13, NOP1, SIK1/NOP56 and NOP58,
CC       plus a guide RNA. Interacts with snoRNA U3. Interacts with MPP10,
CC       NOP58, SIK1 and SOF1. Component of the ribosomal small subunit
CC       (SSU) processome composed of at least 40 protein subunits and
CC       snoRNA U3. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12068309,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:2686980, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8508778,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9372940}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P38333:ENP1; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-6838, EBI-6482;
CC       P25586:KRR1; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-6838, EBI-21773;
CC       Q12460:NOP56; NbExp=5; IntAct=EBI-6838, EBI-17148;
CC       Q12499:NOP58; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-6838, EBI-12126;
CC       P39990:SNU13; NbExp=6; IntAct=EBI-6838, EBI-12032;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus, nucleolus
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12756332, ECO:0000269|PubMed:2298745,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:2686980}. Note=Fibrillar region of the
CC       nucleolus.
CC   -!- PTM: Methylated by HMT1, forming asymmetric dimethylarginines
CC       (DMA) within a domain referred to as an RGG box, made up of
CC       repeated Gly-Gly dipeptides interspersed with Arg and aromatic
CC       residues. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12756332}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the methyltransferase superfamily.
CC       Fibrillarin family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Functions as ATP-binding component of the Arp2/3 complex
CC       which is involved in regulation of actin polymerization and
CC       together with an activating nucleation-promoting factor (NPF)
CC       mediates the formation of branched actin networks. Seems to
CC       contact the pointed end of the daughter actin filament (By
CC       similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the Arp2/3 complex composed of ARP2, ARP3,
CC       ARC40/p41-ARC, ARC35/p34-ARC, ARC18/p21-ARC, ARC19/p20-ARC and
CC       ARC16/p16-ARC. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9210376}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q05933:ARC18; NbExp=7; IntAct=EBI-2927, EBI-2764;
CC       P53731:ARC35; NbExp=6; IntAct=EBI-2927, EBI-2770;
CC       P38328:ARC40; NbExp=6; IntAct=EBI-2927, EBI-2777;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm, cytoskeleton, actin patch
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11248049, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9210376}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 6650 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the actin family. ARP2 subfamily.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Catalyzes the adenylation of flavin mononucleotide (FMN)
CC       to form flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD) coenzyme.

CC       step 1/1.

RX   PubMed=16765890; DOI=10.1016/j.str.2006.04.003;

CC   -!- FUNCTION: DNA-dependent RNA polymerase catalyzes the transcription
CC       of DNA into RNA using the four ribonucleoside triphosphates as
CC       substrates. Component of RNA polymerase II which synthesizes mRNA
CC       precursors and many functional non-coding RNAs. Pol II is the
CC       central component of the basal RNA polymerase II transcription
CC       machinery. It is composed of mobile elements that move relative to
CC       each other. RPB7 is part of a subcomplex with RPB4 that binds to a
CC       pocket formed by RPB1, RPB2 and RPB6 at the base of the clamp
CC       element. The RBP4-RPB7 subcomplex seems to lock the clamp via RPB7
CC       in the closed conformation thus preventing double-stranded DNA to
CC       enter the active site cleft. The RPB4-RPB7 subcomplex binds
CC       single-stranded DNA and RNA. The RPB4-RPB7 subcomplex recruits
CC       FCP1 to Pol II. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11087726,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15304220, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17875743}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the RNA polymerase II (Pol II) complex
CC       consisting of 12 subunits. RPB4 and RPB7 form a subcomplex that
CC       protrudes from the 10-subunit Pol II core complex. The RPB4-RPB7
CC       subcomplex probably associates with TFG1. Interacts with NRD1 and
CC       PAT1. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12907709, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12914699,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:14580350, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16341226,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17875743}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P20433:RPB4; NbExp=8; IntAct=EBI-15790, EBI-15777;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus. Cytoplasm. Cytoplasm, P-body.
CC       Note=Seems to shuttle between nucleus and cytoplasm in a complex
CC       with RPB4.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 6420 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the eukaryotic RPB7/RPC8 RNA polymerase
CC       subunit family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Component of the SWR1 complex which mediates the ATP-
CC       dependent exchange of histone H2A for the H2A variant HZT1 leading
CC       to transcriptional regulation of selected genes by chromatin
CC       remodeling. Component of the NuA4 histone acetyltransferase
CC       complex which is involved in transcriptional activation of
CC       selected genes principally by acetylation of nucleosomal histone
CC       H4 and H2A. The NuA4 complex is also involved in DNA repair.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14645854, ECO:0000269|PubMed:14690608,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15045029}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the SWR1 chromatin-remodeling complex
CC       composed of at least ACT1, ARP4, RVB1, RVB2, ARP6, YAF9, VPS71,
CC       VPS72, SWC3, SWC4, SWC5, SWC7 and SWR1, and perhaps BDF1.
CC       Component of the NuA4 histone acetyltransferase complex composed
CC       of at least ACT1, ARP4, YAF9, VID21, SWC4, EAF3, EAF5, EAF6, EAF7,
CC       EPL1, ESA1, TRA1 and YNG2. Interacts with YAF9. Interacts with
CC       EAF1. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14645854, ECO:0000269|PubMed:14690591,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:14690608, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15045029,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15302830, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15353583,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15485911}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q06337:EAF1; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-23061, EBI-35867;
CC       Q12464:RVB2; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-23061, EBI-31814;
CC       Q05471:SWR1; NbExp=7; IntAct=EBI-23061, EBI-22102;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 2230 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the SWC4 family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Binds preferentially to the U4/U6 hybrid snRNAs. Can
CC       stimulate the annealing of U4 and U6. Could participate in both
CC       the formation and disassembly of the U4/U6 hybrid during splicing.

RN   [15]
RP   STRUCTURE BY ELECTRON MICROSCOPY (7.4 ANGSTROMS) OF THE 26S
RP   PROTEASOME.
RX   PubMed=22927375; DOI=10.1073/pnas.1213333109;
RA   Beck F., Unverdorben P., Bohn S., Schweitzer A., Pfeifer G.,
RA   Sakata E., Nickell S., Plitzko J.M., Villa E., Baumeister W.,
RA   Forster F.;
RT   "Near-atomic resolution structural model of the yeast 26S
RT   proteasome.";
RL   Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 109:14870-14875(2012).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: The proteasome degrades poly-ubiquitinated proteins in
CC       the cytoplasm and in the nucleus. It is essential for the
CC       regulated turnover of proteins and for the removal of misfolded
CC       proteins. The proteasome is a multicatalytic proteinase complex
CC       that is characterized by its ability to cleave peptides with Arg,
CC       Phe, Tyr, Leu, and Glu adjacent to the leaving group at neutral or
CC       slightly basic pH. It has an ATP-dependent proteolytic activity.
CC       This unit is responsible of the chymotrypsin-like activity of the
CC       proteasome and is one of the principal target of the proteasome
CC       inhibitor bortezomib.
CC   -!- FUNCTION: This subunit is necessary for chymotryptic activity and
CC       degradation of ubiquitinated proteins.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Cleavage of peptide bonds with very broad
CC       specificity.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: The 26S proteasome consists of a 20S proteasome core and
CC       two 19S regulatory subunits. The 20S proteasome core is composed
CC       of 28 subunits that are arranged in four stacked rings, resulting
CC       in a barrel-shaped structure. The two end rings are each formed by
CC       seven alpha subunits, and the two central rings are each formed by
CC       seven beta subunits. The catalytic chamber with the active sites
CC       is on the inside of the barrel. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:20227375}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P43583:BLM10; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-14001, EBI-22761;
CC       P22141:PRE1; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-14001, EBI-13988;
CC       P21242:PRE10; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-14001, EBI-13963;
CC       P30657:PRE4; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-14001, EBI-13997;
CC       P40302:PRE5; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-14001, EBI-13955;
CC       P40303:PRE6; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-14001, EBI-13980;
CC       P23724:PRE7; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-14001, EBI-13984;
CC       P23638:PRE9; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-14001, EBI-13967;
CC       P21243:SCL1; NbExp=7; IntAct=EBI-14001, EBI-13975;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm. Nucleus.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: The side chain of Thr-76 acts as nucleophile, and
CC       the N-terminal amino group acts as proton acceptor.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 8530 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the peptidase T1B family.
CC       {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU00809}.
CC   -!- SEQUENCE CAUTION:
CC       Sequence=CAA82203.1; Type=Erroneous initiation; Evidence={ECO:0000305};

RP   FUNCTION.
RX   PubMed=16487579; DOI=10.1016/j.cell.2005.12.036;
RA   Pan X., Ye P., Yuan D.S., Wang X., Bader J.S., Boeke J.D.;
RT   "A DNA integrity network in the yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae.";
RL   Cell 124:1069-1081(2006).
RN   [11]
RP   FUNCTION, AND INTERACTION WITH NUR1.
RX   PubMed=18997772; DOI=10.1038/nature07460;
RA   Mekhail K., Seebacher J., Gygi S.P., Moazed D.;
RT   "Role for perinuclear chromosome tethering in maintenance of genome
RT   stability.";
RL   Nature 456:667-670(2008).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Component of the monopolin complex which promotes
CC       monoorientation during meiosis I, required for chromosome
CC       segregation during meiosis. Plays also a mitotic role in DNA
CC       replication. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11470404,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12689592, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15023545,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16487579, ECO:0000269|PubMed:18997772}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the monopolin complex composed of at least
CC       CSM1, LRS4 and MAM1. The complex associates with the kinetochore.
CC       Interacts with CDC46, CDC47, GIC1, GIC2, MCM3 and NUR1.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11489916, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12689592,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15023545, ECO:0000269|PubMed:18997772}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Self; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-22001, EBI-22001;
CC       P40568:DSN1; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-22001, EBI-25398;
CC       Q04087:LRS4; NbExp=16; IntAct=EBI-22001, EBI-32189;
CC       P40065:MAM1; NbExp=7; IntAct=EBI-22001, EBI-22643;
CC       P24279:MCM3; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-22001, EBI-10541;
CC       P29496:MCM5; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-22001, EBI-10549;
CC       P38132:MCM7; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-22001, EBI-4300;
CC       Q02208:TOF2; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-22001, EBI-27048;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus, nucleolus. Chromosome, centromere.
CC       Note=Transiently released from the nucleolus and localizes to the
CC       centromere regions during late pachytene.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 1920 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Adds the first Dol-P-Man derived mannose in an alpha-1,3
CC       linkage to Man(5)GlcNAc(2)-PP-Dol. Sensitive to H.mrakii HM-1
CC       killer toxin. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11308030,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9108275}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Dolichyl beta-D-mannosyl phosphate + D-Man-
CC       alpha-(1->2)-D-Man-alpha-(1->2)-D-Man-alpha-(1->3)-(D-Man-alpha-
CC       (1->6))-D-Man-beta-(1->4)-D-GlcNAc-beta-(1->4)-D-GlcNAc-
CC       diphosphodolichol = D-Man-alpha-(1->2)-D-Man-alpha-(1->2)-D-Man-
CC       alpha-(1->3)-(D-Man-alpha-(1->3)-D-Man-alpha-(1->6))-D-Man-beta-
CC       (1->4)-D-GlcNAc-beta-(1->4)-D-GlcNAc-diphosphodolichol + dolichyl
CC       phosphate. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11308030}.
CC   -!- PATHWAY: Protein modification; protein glycosylation.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Endoplasmic reticulum membrane
CC       {ECO:0000305}; Multi-pass membrane protein {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the glycosyltransferase 58 family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

RP   BY MASS SPECTROMETRY [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS].
RX   PubMed=18407956; DOI=10.1074/mcp.M700468-MCP200;

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Catalyzes the NADPH-dependent reduction of trans-2-enoyl
CC       thioesters in mitochondrial fatty acid synthesis (fatty acid
CC       synthesis type II). Fatty acid chain elongation in mitochondria
CC       uses acyl carrier protein (ACP) as an acyl group carrier, but the
CC       enzyme accepts both ACP and CoA thioesters as substrates in vitro.
CC       Required for respiration and the maintenance of the mitochondrial
CC       compartment. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11509667,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12614607}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: An acyl-[acyl-carrier protein] + NADP(+) = a
CC       trans-2,3-dehydroacyl-[acyl-carrier protein] + NADPH.
CC       {ECO:0000305|PubMed:11509667, ECO:0000305|PubMed:12614607}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homodimer or in a complex with other proteins
CC       (PubMed:11509667). Interacts with ARS1 (PubMed:8195160).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11509667, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8195160}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Mitochondrion matrix
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11502169, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11509667,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:14576278}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 1560 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the zinc-containing alcohol dehydrogenase
CC       family. Quinone oxidoreductase subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- CAUTION: Was originally (PubMed:8195160) thought to be a nuclear
CC       protein involved in transcriptional regulation of genes required
CC       for the functional assembly of mitochondrial respiratory proteins.
CC       This was later proven not to be the case (PubMed:11509667).
CC       {ECO:0000305|PubMed:11509667, ECO:0000305|PubMed:8195160}.

RX   PubMed=22106047; DOI=10.1002/pmic.201100166;

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Involved in the recombinational repair of double-strand
CC       breaks (DSB) in DNA during mitosis and meiosis. Has DNA dependent
CC       ATPase activity. Promotes D-loop (displacement loop) formation
CC       with RAD51 recombinase. Modifies the topology of double-stranded
CC       DNA during the D-loop reaction to facilitate the invasion of the
CC       homologous duplex molecule by the initiating single-stranded DNA
CC       substrate. Required for adaptation from G2/M checkpoint arrest
CC       induced by a double strand break, by participating in monitoring
CC       the extent of single-stranded DNA produced by resection of DNA
CC       ends. This role is distinct from its roles in recombination.
CC       Promotes colocalization of RAD51 and DMC1 during meiotic
CC       recombination. Involved in crossover interference.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10970884, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11005857,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11470411, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12702674,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9409819, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9409820}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: ATP + H(2)O = ADP + phosphate.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with RAD51 and DMC1.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10970884, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9335591}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 1270 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the SNF2/RAD54 helicase family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- CAUTION: It is uncertain whether Met-1 or Met-35 is the initiator.
CC       In many S.cerevisiae strains, it is not possible to extend the
CC       sequence at the N-terminus beyond Met-35 because of a framshift in
CC       the upstream sequence when compared to strain S288c. However,
CC       experimental evidence indicates that the longer protein is made in
CC       S288c. {ECO:0000305}.

RA   Shi Y., Stefan C.J., Rue S.M., Teis D., Emr S.D.;
RT   "Two novel WD40 domain-containing proteins, Ere1 and Ere2, function in
RT   the retromer-mediated endosomal recycling pathway.";
RL   Mol. Biol. Cell 22:4093-4107(2011).
RN   [8]
RP   FUNCTION.
RX   PubMed=22188241; DOI=10.1021/ja208870a;
RA   Su X., Chen W., Lee W., Jiang H., Zhang S., Lin H.;
RT   "YBR246W is required for the third step of diphthamide biosynthesis.";
RL   J. Am. Chem. Soc. 134:773-776(2012).
RN   [9]
RP   FUNCTION, AND DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE.
RX   PubMed=23468660; DOI=10.1371/journal.pgen.1003334;
RA   Uthman S., Bar C., Scheidt V., Liu S., ten Have S., Giorgini F.,
RA   Stark M.J., Schaffrath R.;
RT   "The amidation step of diphthamide biosynthesis in yeast requires
RT   DPH6, a gene identified through mining the DPH1-DPH5 interaction
RT   network.";
RL   PLoS Genet. 9:E1003334-E1003334(2013).
RN   [10]
RP   FUNCTION, AND CATALYTIC ACTIVITY.
RX   PubMed=24739148; DOI=10.1021/ja5009272;
RA   Lin Z., Su X., Chen W., Ci B., Zhang S., Lin H.;
RT   "Dph7 catalyzes a previously unknown demethylation step in diphthamide
RT   biosynthesis.";
RL   J. Am. Chem. Soc. 136:6179-6182(2014).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Catalyzes the demethylation of diphthine methyl ester to
CC       form diphthine, an intermediate in diphthamide biosynthesis, a
CC       post-translational modification of histidine which occurs in
CC       translation elongation factor 2 (EFT1 and EFT2). Also plays a role
CC       in the regulation of the retromer complex and is required for the
CC       recycling from endosomes of plasma membrane proteins like CAN1 and
CC       MUP1. Identified in a screen for mutants with decreased levels of
CC       rDNA transcription. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19270272,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19965467, ECO:0000269|PubMed:21880895,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22188241, ECO:0000269|PubMed:23468660,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:24739148}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Diphthine methyl ester-[translation elongation
CC       factor 2] + H(2)O = diphthine-[translation elongation factor 2] +
CC       methanol. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:24739148}.
CC   -!- PATHWAY: Protein modification; peptidyl-diphthamide biosynthesis.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with CAN1 and RTT10.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21880895}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21880895}.
CC       Endosome {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21880895}. Note=Recruited to
CC       endosomes in cells in which increased recycling of internalized
CC       plasma membrane proteins occurs.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Accumulates diphthine, the last intermediate
CC       in the diphthamide biosynthesis pathway. Increases the interaction
CC       of DPH5 with elongation factor 2. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:23468660}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 2640 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the DPH7 family. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- CAUTION: Was originally (PubMed:19965467) thought to be required
CC       for the first step of diphthamide biosynthesis but further studies
CC       (PubMed:22188241, PubMed:23468660) clearly suggest that it is
CC       involved in the third step of diphthamide biosynthesis.
CC       {ECO:0000305|PubMed:19965467, ECO:0000305|PubMed:22188241,
CC       ECO:0000305|PubMed:23468660}.

RN   [14]
RP   FUNCTION.
RX   PubMed=24307402; DOI=10.1093/jb/mvt108;
RA   Kamata K., Goswami G., Kashio S., Urano T., Nakagawa R., Uchida H.,
RA   Oki M.;
RT   "The N-terminus and Tudor domains of Sgf29 are important for its
RT   heterochromatin boundary formation function.";
RL   J. Biochem. 155:159-171(2014).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Chromatin reader component of the transcription
CC       regulatory histone acetylation (HAT) complexes SAGA and SLIK
CC       (PubMed:10026213, PubMed:15647753, PubMed:21685874,
CC       PubMed:24307402). In the SAGA complex, SGF29 specifically
CC       recognizes and binds methylated 'Lys-4' of histone H3 (H3K4me),
CC       with a preference for trimethylated form (H3K4me3)
CC       (PubMed:21685874). SGF29 is also required for heterochromatin
CC       boundary formation function (PubMed:24307402). SAGA is involved in
CC       RNA polymerase II-dependent transcriptional regulation of
CC       approximately 10% of yeast genes At the promoters, SAGA is
CC       required for recruitment of the basal transcription machinery
CC       (PubMed:10026213). It influences RNA polymerase II transcriptional
CC       activity through different activities such as TBP interaction
CC       (SPT3, SPT8 and SPT20) and promoter selectivity, interaction with
CC       transcription activators (GCN5, ADA2, ADA3 and TRA1), and
CC       chromatin modification through histone acetylation (GCN5) and
CC       deubiquitination (UBP8) (PubMed:10026213). SAGA acetylates
CC       nucleosomal histone H3 to some extent (to form H3K9ac, H3K14ac,
CC       H3K18ac and H3K23ac). SAGA interacts with DNA via upstream
CC       activating sequences (UASs) (PubMed:10026213). SLIK is proposed to
CC       have partly overlapping functions with SAGA (PubMed:15647753). It
CC       preferentially acetylates methylated histone H3, at least after
CC       activation at the GAL1-10 locus (PubMed:15647753).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10026213, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15647753,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:21685874, ECO:0000269|PubMed:24307402}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the 1.8 MDa SAGA complex, which consists of
CC       at least of TRA1, CHD1, SPT7, TAF5, ADA3, SGF73, SPT20/ADA5, SPT8,
CC       TAF12, TAF6, HFI1/ADA1, UBP8, GCN5, ADA2, SPT3, SGF29, TAF10,
CC       TAF9, SGF11 and SUS1. TAF5, TAF6, TAF9, TAF19, TAF12 and ADA1 seem
CC       to be present in 2 copies. SAGA is built of 5 distinct domains
CC       with specialized functions. Domain I (containing TRA1) probably
CC       represents the activator interaction surface. Domain II
CC       (containing TAF5 and TAF6, and probably TAF9 and TAF10), domain
CC       III (containing GCN5, TAF10, SPT7, TAF5 and ADA1, and probably
CC       ADA2, ADA3 and TAF12), and domain IV (containing HFI1/ADA1 and
CC       TAF6, and probably TAF9) are believed to play primarily an
CC       architectural role. Domain III also harbors the HAT activity.
CC       Domain V (containing SPT3 and SPT20, and probably SPT8) represents
CC       the TBP-interacting module, which may be associated transiently
CC       with SAGA. Interacts with dimethylated and trimethylated 'Lys-4'
CC       of histone H3 (H3K4me2 and H3K4me3), with a preference for the
CC       trimethylated form (H3K4me3). Component of the SLIK complex, which
CC       consists of at least TRA1, CHD1, SPT7, TAF5, ADA3, SPT20, RTG2,
CC       TAF12, TAF6, HFI1, UBP8, GCN5, ADA2, SPT3, SGF29, TAF10 and TAF9.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12052880, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15647753,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:21685874}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q12060:HFI1; NbExp=9; IntAct=EBI-21678, EBI-8287;
CC       P68431:HIST1H3D (xeno); NbExp=11; IntAct=EBI-21678, EBI-79722;
CC       P32494:NGG1; NbExp=5; IntAct=EBI-21678, EBI-2192;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The SGF29 C-terminal (also named tudor-like) domain
CC       mediates binding to methylated 'Lys-4' of histone H3 (H3K4me).
CC       {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU00851,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:21685874}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 1750 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the SGF29 family. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00851}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Component of the RPD3C(L) histone deacetylase complex
CC       (HDAC) responsible for the deacetylation of lysine residues on the
CC       N-terminal part of the core histones (H2A, H2B, H3 and H4).
CC       Histone deacetylation gives a tag for epigenetic repression and
CC       plays an important role in transcriptional regulation, cell cycle
CC       progression and developmental events.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the RPD3C(L) complex composed of at least
CC       ASH1, CTI6, DEP1, PHO23, RPD3, RXT2, RXT3, SAP30, SDS3, SIN3, UME1
CC       and UME6. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16314178}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 3060 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the RXT3 family. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   AND SUBUNIT.
RX   PubMed=21719644; DOI=10.1126/science.1207125;
RA   Stefer S., Reitz S., Wang F., Wild K., Pang Y.Y., Schwarz D.,

RN   [19]
RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (3.0 ANGSTROMS).
RX   PubMed=22684149; DOI=10.1016/j.jmb.2012.05.045;
RA   Kubota K., Yamagata A., Sato Y., Goto-Ito S., Fukai S.;
RT   "Get1 stabilizes an open dimer conformation of get3 ATPase by binding
RT   two distinct interfaces.";
RL   J. Mol. Biol. 422:366-375(2012).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: ATPase required for the post-translational delivery of
CC       tail-anchored (TA) proteins to the endoplasmic reticulum.
CC       Recognizes and selectively binds the transmembrane domain of TA
CC       proteins in the cytosol. This complex then targets to the
CC       endoplasmic reticulum by membrane-bound receptors GET1 and GET2,
CC       where the tail-anchored protein is released for insertion. This
CC       process is regulated by ATP binding and hydrolysis. ATP binding
CC       drives the homodimer towards the closed dimer state, facilitating
CC       recognition of newly synthesized TA membrane proteins. ATP
CC       hydrolysis is required for insertion. Subsequently, the homodimer
CC       reverts towards the open dimer state, lowering its affinity for
CC       the GET1-GET2 receptor, and returning it to the cytosol to
CC       initiate a new round of targeting. Cooperates with the HDEL
CC       receptor ERD2 to mediate the ATP-dependent retrieval of resident
CC       ER proteins that contain a C-terminal H-D-E-L retention signal
CC       from the Golgi to the ER. Involved in low-level resistance to the
CC       oxyanions arsenite and arsenate, and in heat tolerance.
CC       {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03112, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12680698,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16269340, ECO:0000269|PubMed:18724936,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:21719644, ECO:0000269|PubMed:21866104}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homodimer. Component of the Golgi to ER traffic (GET)
CC       complex, which is composed of GET1, GET2 and GET3. Interacts with
CC       the chloride channel protein GEF1. {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-
CC       Rule:MF_03112, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11805837,

RP   FUNCTION, AND SUBCELLULAR LOCATION.
RX   PubMed=14688790; DOI=10.1038/ncb1078;
RA   Moffat J., Andrews B.J.;
RT   "Late-G1 cyclin-CDK activity is essential for control of cell
RT   morphogenesis in budding yeast.";
RL   Nat. Cell Biol. 6:59-66(2004).
RN   [12]
RP   FUNCTION, AND PHOSPHORYLATION OF LCB4.
RX   PubMed=15598647; DOI=10.1074/jbc.M410908200;
RA   Iwaki S., Kihara A., Sano T., Igarashi Y.;
RT   "Phosphorylation by Pho85 cyclin-dependent kinase acts as a signal for
RT   the down-regulation of the yeast sphingoid long-chain base kinase Lcb4
RT   during the stationary phase.";
RL   J. Biol. Chem. 280:6520-6527(2005).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: G1/S-specific cyclin partner of the cyclin-dependent
CC       kinase (CDK) PHO85. Essential for the control of the cell cycle at
CC       the G1/S (start) transition. Together with cyclin PCL1, positively
CC       controls degradation of sphingoid long chain base kinase LCB4. The
CC       PCL2-PHO85 cyclin-CDK holoenzyme phosphorylates LCB4, which is
CC       required for its ubiquitination and degradation. PCL2-PHO85 also
CC       phosphorylates RVS167, linking cyclin-CDK activity with
CC       organization of the actin cytoskeleton.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14688790, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15598647,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9843683}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Forms a cyclin-CDK complex with PHO85. Interacts with
CC       RVS167. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:7973731, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9032248,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9843683}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P17157:PHO85; NbExp=8; IntAct=EBI-4499, EBI-13327;
CC       P10591:SSA1; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-4499, EBI-8591;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14688790}.
CC       Nucleus {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14688790}. Note=Localizes to sites of
CC       polarized growth, namely the incipient bud site, the bud tip and
CC       the bud neck.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: By transcription factors SBF (SWI4-SWI6 cell-cycle box
CC       binding factor) and SWI5 in a cell cycle-regulated manner. Peaks
CC       in G1 phase. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:7973731,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9529390}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the cyclin family. PCL1,2 subfamily.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SEQUENCE CAUTION:
CC       Sequence=CAA98695.1; Type=Frameshift; Positions=263; Evidence={ECO:0000305};

RT   "The yeast E4 ubiquitin ligase Ufd2 interacts with the ubiquitin-like
RT   domains of Rad23 and Dsk2 via a novel and distinct ubiquitin-like
RT   binding domain.";
RL   J. Biol. Chem. 285:20390-20398(2010).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: E4 ubiquitin chain-elongation enzyme specifically
CC       involved in polyubiquitin chain assembly. Binds to CDC48 and
CC       elongates mono- and diubiquitinated ERAD substrates presented by
CC       the UFD1-NPL4-CDC48/p97 (UNC) AAA ATPase complex to a chain length
CC       of 4 to 6 ubiquitin moieties. Delivers these polyubiquitinated
CC       substrates to RAD23 and DSK2, which target them to the proteasome.
CC       Has E3 ubiquitin-protein ligase activity, accepting ubiquitin from
CC       its cognate E2 ubiquitin-conjugating enzyme UBC4. Enhances
CC       ubiquitination at 'Lys-48', but not at 'Lys-29' of the Ub moiety.
CC       Promotes ubiquitin chain elongation at 'Lys-48' on the DOA10
CC       substrate PEX29. Also involved in the proteolytic processing of
CC       the ER-bound transcription factor SPT23.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10089879, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15240124,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15652483, ECO:0000269|PubMed:18191224,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:20159987}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: S-ubiquitinyl-[E2 ubiquitin-conjugating
CC       enzyme]-L-cysteine + [acceptor protein]-L-lysine = [E2 ubiquitin-
CC       conjugating enzyme]-L-cysteine + N(6)-ubiquitinyl-[acceptor
CC       protein]-L-lysine. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10089879}.
CC   -!- PATHWAY: Protein modification; protein ubiquitination.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10089879}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with CDC48. Interacts with the ubiquitin-like
CC       domain of RAD23 and DSK2. Interacts with PEX29.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10089879, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15121879,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16427015, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17890322,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:20159987, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20427284}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P25694:CDC48; NbExp=6; IntAct=EBI-20003, EBI-4308;
CC       P32628:RAD23; NbExp=7; IntAct=EBI-20003, EBI-14668;
CC       P33202:UFD4; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-20003, EBI-20010;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095}.
CC       Nucleus {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The U-box domain is required for the ubiquitin protein
CC       ligase activity. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17890322}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 2600 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ubiquitin conjugation factor E4 family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

RP   IDENTIFICATION BY MASS SPECTROMETRY [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS].
RX   PubMed=22814378; DOI=10.1073/pnas.1210303109;
RA   Van Damme P., Lasa M., Polevoda B., Gazquez C., Elosegui-Artola A.,
RA   Kim D.S., De Juan-Pardo E., Demeyer K., Hole K., Larrea E.,
RA   Timmerman E., Prieto J., Arnesen T., Sherman F., Gevaert K.,

RT   "N-terminal acetylome analyses and functional insights of the N-
RT   terminal acetyltransferase NatB.";
RL   Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 109:12449-12454(2012).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: High-affinity glucose transporter. Can function as a
CC       negative regulator of glucose transport. SNF3 is involved as well
CC       in the transport of mannose and fructose. Serves as a sensor that
CC       generates an intracellular signal in the presence of low level of
CC       glucose. Inhibition of RGT1 by low levels of glucose, and hence
CC       induction of HTX2 and HTX4 expression, requires SNF3.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:3281163};
CC       Multi-pass membrane protein {ECO:0000269|PubMed:3281163}.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: Glucose-repressible.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The C-terminal cytoplasmic domain seems to be important
CC       for SNF3 regulatory function.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Glucose transport is thought to be mediated by two
CC       kinetically distinct systems, a glucose-repressible high-affinity
CC       system and a constitutive low-affinity system.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the major facilitator superfamily. Sugar
CC       transporter (TC 2.A.1.1) family. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SEQUENCE CAUTION:
CC       Sequence=CAA58253.1; Type=Erroneous initiation; Evidence={ECO:0000305};

RP   FUNCTION, SUBCELLULAR LOCATION, AND DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE.
RC   STRAIN=DBY2057;
RX   PubMed=10766779; DOI=10.1074/jbc.275.16.11626;
RA   Soutourina J., Blanquet S., Plateau P.;
RT   "D-tyrosyl-tRNA(Tyr) metabolism in Saccharomyces cerevisiae.";
RL   J. Biol. Chem. 275:11626-11630(2000).
RN   [4]
RP   FUNCTION, AND DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE.
RC   STRAIN=DBY2057;
RX   PubMed=10918062; DOI=10.1074/jbc.M005166200;
RA   Soutourina J., Plateau P., Blanquet S.;
RT   "Metabolism of D-aminoacyl-tRNAs in Escherichia coli and Saccharomyces
RT   cerevisiae cells.";
RL   J. Biol. Chem. 275:32535-32542(2000).
RN   [5]
RP   LEVEL OF PROTEIN EXPRESSION [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS].
RX   PubMed=14562106; DOI=10.1038/nature02046;
RA   Ghaemmaghami S., Huh W.-K., Bower K., Howson R.W., Belle A.,
RA   Dephoure N., O'Shea E.K., Weissman J.S.;
RT   "Global analysis of protein expression in yeast.";
RL   Nature 425:737-741(2003).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: An aminoacyl-tRNA editing enzyme that deacylates
CC       mischarged D-aminoacyl-tRNAs (Probable). Hydrolyzes D-tyrosyl-
CC       tRNA(Tyr) into D-tyrosine and free tRNA(Tyr) (PubMed:10766779).
CC       May also deacylate mischarged D-leucyl-tRNA(Leu)
CC       (PubMed:10918062). Also deacylates mischarged glycyl-tRNA(Ala),
CC       protecting cells against glycine mischarging by AlaRS (By
CC       similarity). Acts via tRNA-based rather than protein-based
CC       catalysis; rejects L-amino acids rather than detecting D-amino
CC       acids in the active site (By similarity). By recycling D-
CC       aminoacyl-tRNA to D-amino acids and free tRNA molecules, this
CC       enzyme counteracts the toxicity associated with the formation of
CC       D-aminoacyl-tRNA entities in vivo and helps enforce protein L-
CC       homochirality (By similarity). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q8IIS0,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:10766779, ECO:0000305|PubMed:10918062}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Glycyl-tRNA(Ala) + H(2)O = glycine +
CC       tRNA(Ala). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q8IIS0}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: A D-aminoacyl-tRNA + H(2)O = a D-amino acid +
CC       tRNA. {ECO:0000305|PubMed:10766779}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homodimer. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q8IIS0}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000305|PubMed:10766779}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: A Gly-cisPro motif from one monomer fits into the active
CC       site of the other monomer to allow specific chiral rejection of L-
CC       amino acids. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q8IIS0}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: 10-fold decrease in D-tyrosyl-tRNA(Tyr)
CC       deacylase activity, growth becomes more sensitive to D-tyrosine
CC       and is inhibited at 0.1 mM D-Tyr (PubMed:10766779,
CC       PubMed:10918062). Growth is also inhibited in the presence of 0.3
CC       mM D-leucine; wild-type cells grow well in up to 0.3 mM D-Tyr and
CC       10 mM D-Leu (PubMed:10918062). No growth differences observed in
CC       the presence of the other D-amino acids (PubMed:10918062).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10766779, ECO:0000269|PubMed:10918062}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 4610 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the DTD family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Plasma membrane signaling mucin that promotes activation
CC       of the MAPK for the filamentous growth pathway. May regulate beta-
CC       glucan synthesis. Overexpression provides resistance to HM-1
CC       killer toxin. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19439450,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8550469}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:8550469};
CC       Single-pass type I membrane protein {ECO:0000269|PubMed:8550469}.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: Expression is highly increased during spheroplast
CC       regeneration. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10564805}.
CC   -!- PTM: Could be O-glycosylated in the serine/threonine-rich domain.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the HKR1/MSB2 family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Catalyzes the hydrolysis of N-formyl-L-kynurenine to L-
CC       kynurenine, the second step in the kynurenine pathway of
CC       tryptophan degradation. Kynurenine may be further oxidized to
CC       nicotinic acid, NAD(H) and NADP(H). Required for elimination of
CC       toxic metabolites. {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03014,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18205391}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: N-formyl-L-kynurenine + H(2)O = formate + L-
CC       kynurenine. {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03014,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18205391}.
CC   -!- PATHWAY: Amino-acid degradation; L-tryptophan degradation via
CC       kynurenine pathway; L-kynurenine from L-tryptophan: step 2/2.
CC       {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03014, ECO:0000269|PubMed:18205391}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homodimer. {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03014}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The main chain amide nitrogen atoms of the second glycine
CC       and its adjacent residue in the HGGXW motif define the oxyanion
CC       hole, and stabilize the oxyanion that forms during the
CC       nucleophilic attack by the catalytic serine during substrate
CC       cleavage. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18205391}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Cells exhibit slow growth in the absence of
CC       nicotinate. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18205391}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the kynurenine formamidase family.
CC       {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03014}.

RP   NOMENCLATURE.
RX   PubMed=24524803; DOI=10.1016/j.sbi.2014.01.002;
RA   Ban N., Beckmann R., Cate J.H.D., Dinman J.D., Dragon F., Ellis S.R.,
RA   Lafontaine D.L.J., Lindahl L., Liljas A., Lipton J.M., McAlear M.A.,
RA   Moore P.B., Noller H.F., Ortega J., Panse V.G., Ramakrishnan V.,
RA   Spahn C.M.T., Steitz T.A., Tchorzewski M., Tollervey D., Warren A.J.,
RA   Williamson J.R., Wilson D., Yonath A., Yusupov M.;
RT   "A new system for naming ribosomal proteins.";
RL   Curr. Opin. Struct. Biol. 24:165-169(2014).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Component of the ribosome, a large ribonucleoprotein
CC       complex responsible for the synthesis of proteins in the cell. The
CC       small ribosomal subunit (SSU) binds messenger RNAs (mRNAs) and
CC       translates the encoded message by selecting cognate aminoacyl-
CC       transfer RNA (tRNA) molecules. The large subunit (LSU) contains
CC       the ribosomal catalytic site termed the peptidyl transferase
CC       center (PTC), which catalyzes the formation of peptide bonds,
CC       thereby polymerizing the amino acids delivered by tRNAs into a
CC       polypeptide chain. The nascent polypeptides leave the ribosome
CC       through a tunnel in the LSU and interact with protein factors that
CC       function in enzymatic processing, targeting, and the membrane
CC       insertion of nascent chains at the exit of the ribosomal tunnel.
CC       {ECO:0000305|PubMed:22096102}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the small ribosomal subunit (SSU). Mature
CC       yeast ribosomes consist of a small (40S) and a large (60S)
CC       subunit. The 40S small subunit contains 1 molecule of ribosomal
CC       RNA (18S rRNA) and 33 different proteins (encoded by 57 genes).
CC       The large 60S subunit contains 3 rRNA molecules (25S, 5.8S and 5S
CC       rRNA) and 46 different proteins (encoded by 81 genes). eS26
CC       interacts with eS1 forming part of the mRNA exit tunnel
CC       (PubMed:9559554, PubMed:22096102). eS26 interacts with TSR2
CC       (PubMed:10688190, PubMed:12837249). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10688190,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12837249, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22096102,
CC       ECO:0000305|PubMed:9559554}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22096102}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 503000 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: There are 2 genes for eS26 in yeast. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the eukaryotic ribosomal protein eS26
CC       family. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   FUNCTION, CATALYTIC ACTIVITY, BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES, AND
RP   MUTAGENESIS OF GLU-115.
RX   PubMed=23070364; DOI=10.1038/embor.2012.156;
RA   Kumar A., Tikoo S., Maity S., Sengupta S., Sengupta S., Kaur A.,
RA   Bachhawat A.K.;
RT   "Mammalian proapoptotic factor ChaC1 and its homologues function as
RT   gamma-glutamyl cyclotransferases acting specifically on glutathione.";
RL   EMBO Rep. 13:1095-1101(2012).
RN   [7]
RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (1.34 ANGSTROMS) IN COMPLEX WITH BENZOATE.
RX   PubMed=27913623; DOI=10.1074/jbc.M116.727479;
RA   Kaur A., Gautam R., Srivastava R., Chandel A., Kumar A.,
RA   Karthikeyan S., Bachhawat A.K.;
RT   "ChaC2, an enzyme for slow turnover of cytosolic glutathione.";
RL   J. Biol. Chem. 292:638-651(2017).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Catalyzes the cleavage of glutathione into 5-oxo-L-
CC       proline and a Cys-Gly dipeptide. Acts specifically on glutathione,
CC       but not on other gamma-glutamyl peptides. Allows utilization of
CC       gluthathione through subsequent cleavage of the Cys-Gly dipeptide
CC       by Cys-Gly metallodipeptidase DUG1. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:23070364}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Glutathione = L-cysteinylglycine + 5-oxo-L-
CC       proline. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:23070364}.
CC   -!- BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES:
CC       Kinetic parameters:
CC         KM=1.52 mM for glutathione {ECO:0000269|PubMed:23070364};
CC         Vmax=110 umol/h/mg enzyme {ECO:0000269|PubMed:23070364};
CC         Note=kcat is 50.8 min(-1) for glutathione.
CC         {ECO:0000269|PubMed:23070364};
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095}.
CC       Nucleus {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 1300 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.

RP   COMPOSITION OF THE COG COMPLEX, AND INTERACTION WITH COG4.
RX   PubMed=15047703; DOI=10.1074/jbc.M400662200;
RA   Loh E., Hong W.;
RT   "The binary interacting network of the conserved oligomeric Golgi
RT   tethering complex.";
RL   J. Biol. Chem. 279:24640-24648(2004).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Acts as component of the peripheral membrane COG complex
CC       that is involved in intra-Golgi protein trafficking. COG is
CC       located at the cis-Golgi, and regulates tethering of retrograde
CC       intra-Golgi vesicles and possibly a number of other membrane
CC       trafficking events.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the conserved oligomeric Golgi (COG or
CC       Sec34/Sec35) complex which consists of eight different proteins
CC       COG1-COG8. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11703943}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P53271:COG2; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-4847, EBI-16614;
CC       P40094:COG3; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-4847, EBI-16605;
CC       Q06096:COG4; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-4847, EBI-4823;
CC       P53951:COG5; NbExp=6; IntAct=EBI-4847, EBI-4841;
CC       P53959:COG6; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-4847, EBI-4829;
CC       Q04632:COG8; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-4847, EBI-6035;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Golgi apparatus membrane {ECO:0000250};
CC       Peripheral membrane protein {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 1360 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.

RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (3.3 ANGSTROMS) OF 19-103 IN COMPLEX WITH GET2
RP   AND GET3, FUNCTION, SUBUNIT, SUBCELLULAR LOCATION, AND TOPOLOGY.
RX   PubMed=21719644; DOI=10.1126/science.1207125;
RA   Stefer S., Reitz S., Wang F., Wild K., Pang Y.Y., Schwarz D.,
RA   Bomke J., Hein C., Lohr F., Bernhard F., Denic V., Dotsch V.,
RA   Sinning I.;
RT   "Structural basis for tail-anchored membrane protein biogenesis by the
RT   Get3-receptor complex.";
RL   Science 333:758-762(2011).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Required for the post-translational delivery of tail-
CC       anchored (TA) proteins to the endoplasmic reticulum. Together with
CC       GET2, acts as a membrane receptor for soluble GET3, which
CC       recognizes and selectively binds the transmembrane domain of TA
CC       proteins in the cytosol. The GET complex cooperates with the HDEL
CC       receptor ERD2 to mediate the ATP-dependent retrieval of resident
CC       ER proteins that contain a C-terminal H-D-E-L retention signal
CC       from the Golgi to the ER. Involved in mitochondrial distribution
CC       and morphology. {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03113,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11907266, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16269340,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18724936, ECO:0000269|PubMed:21719644,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:21835666}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the Golgi to ER traffic (GET) complex, which
CC       is composed of GET1, GET2 and GET3. {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-
CC       Rule:MF_03113, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11805837,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16269340, ECO:0000269|PubMed:21719644,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:21835666}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P40056:GET2; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-23722, EBI-22604;
CC       Q12154:GET3; NbExp=12; IntAct=EBI-23722, EBI-2989;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Endoplasmic reticulum membrane; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein. Golgi apparatus membrane; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 2250 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the WRB/GET1 family. {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-
CC       Rule:MF_03113}.

RN   [6]
RP   LEVEL OF PROTEIN EXPRESSION [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS].
RX   PubMed=14562106; DOI=10.1038/nature02046;
RA   Ghaemmaghami S., Huh W.-K., Bower K., Howson R.W., Belle A.,
RA   Dephoure N., O'Shea E.K., Weissman J.S.;
RT   "Global analysis of protein expression in yeast.";
RL   Nature 425:737-741(2003).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Could regulate export of the bud site and axial growth
CC       sites selection protein AXL2 and possibly other secretory proteins
CC       from the endoplasmic reticulum in COPII-coated vesicles. Seems to
CC       be required for axial budding pattern in haploid cells.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9732282}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Endoplasmic reticulum membrane; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein. Golgi apparatus membrane; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein. Note=Resides in the endoplasmic and Golgi compartments,
CC       and then packaged into endoplasmic reticulum derived vesicles.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Defects in cell polarity. Strains homozygous
CC       for ERV14 deletion do not sporulate. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9732282}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 7110 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the cornichon family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC       exist as structural reinforcement on the surface of the vacuolar

CC       osmotic pressure.

RP   FUNCTION.
RX   PubMed=22573892; DOI=10.1091/mbc.E12-01-0033;
RA   Oh Y., Chang K.J., Orlean P., Wloka C., Deshaies R., Bi E.;
RT   "Mitotic exit kinase Dbf2 directly phosphorylates chitin synthase Chs2

RL   Mol. Biol. Cell 23:2445-2456(2012).
RN   [28]
RP   FUNCTION.
RX   PubMed=23447700; DOI=10.1091/mbc.E12-08-0608;
RA   Meitinger F., Palani S., Hub B., Pereira G.;
RT   "Dual function of the NDR-kinase Dbf2 in the regulation of the F-BAR
RT   protein Hof1 during cytokinesis.";
RL   Mol. Biol. Cell 24:1290-1304(2013).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Ser/Thr-protein kinase involved in the mitotic exit
CC       network (MEN) and required after the metaphase to anaphase cell
CC       cycle transition. Phosphorylates CHS2 to regulate its dynamics and
CC       chitin synthesis at the division site during cytokinesis.
CC       Coordinates septin and actomyosin ring (AMR) functions during
CC       cytokinesis through the phosphorylation of HOF1. In complex with
CC       MOB1, phosphorylates CDC14 at sites adjacent to its nuclear
CC       localization sequence, thereby retaining CDC14 in the cytoplasm.
CC       Binds also to SWI5 and CLB2 mRNAs cotranscriptionally to regulate
CC       their decay. In the nucleus, the DBF2-MOB1 complex regulates
CC       passenger protein localization during anaphase. Mediates sorbic
CC       acid stress tolerance through promoting vacuolar H(+)-ATPase
CC       function, probably through phosphorylation of VMA1 and VMA2
CC       subunits. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10228157,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:10984431, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11378390,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11404483, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11598184,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12832486, ECO:0000269|PubMed:14551257,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16176976, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16242037,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18048916, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19221193,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:20123997, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20442249,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22196726, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22573892,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:23447700, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8131744,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9528782, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9613578}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: ATP + a protein = ADP + a phosphoprotein.
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: Kinase activity is regulated by BUB2, CDC15 and
CC       CDC5, and is maximal during nuclear division. CDK1 kinase inhibits
CC       cellular DBF2-MOB1 kinase activity via phosphorylation of both
CC       CDC15 and MOB1. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10228157,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11404483, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12832486,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:14551257, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20123997}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with MOB1. MOB1-binding is required for a late
CC       mitotic event. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9528782}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P38074:HMT1; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-5569, EBI-8394;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm, cytoskeleton, microtubule
CC       organizing center, spindle pole body. Bud neck. Nucleus.
CC       Note=Localizes on spindle ole body (SPB) for much of the cell
CC       cycle and migrates from there to the bud neck in late mitosis. SPB
CC       localization during anaphase coincides with activation kinase
CC       activity and depends on TEM1 and CDC15. In absence of BUB2,
CC       localizes to SPB in cell cycle stages other than anaphase and
CC       telophase.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: Periodically expressed in the cell cycle, with a peak
CC       before the onset of budding. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:2181271,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8131744}.
CC   -!- PTM: Phosphorylation of Ser-374 and Thr-544 by CDC15 is essential
CC       for activation of DBF2 kinase activity.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11404483, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8131744}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 3500 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the protein kinase superfamily. Ser/Thr
CC       protein kinase family. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU00159}.
CC   -!- SEQUENCE CAUTION:
CC       Sequence=AAA34559.1; Type=Erroneous initiation; Note=Translation N-terminally extended.; Evidence={ECO:0000305};

RP   LEVEL OF PROTEIN EXPRESSION [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS].
RX   PubMed=14562106; DOI=10.1038/nature02046;
RA   Ghaemmaghami S., Huh W.-K., Bower K., Howson R.W., Belle A.,
RA   Dephoure N., O'Shea E.K., Weissman J.S.;
RT   "Global analysis of protein expression in yeast.";
RL   Nature 425:737-741(2003).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Essential for the control of the cell cycle at the G2/M
CC       (mitosis) transition. Interacts with the CDC2 protein kinase to
CC       form MPF. G2/M cyclins accumulate steadily during G2 and are
CC       abruptly destroyed at mitosis.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P20486:CKS1; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-4508, EBI-4746;
CC   -!- DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE: Maximally expressed before mitosis. The
CC       levels peak late in the G2 phase of the cell cycle and are at a
CC       minimum in G1 phase.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 300 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the cyclin family. Cyclin AB subfamily.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.
