RN   [14]
RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (3.00 ANGSTROMS) OF 80S RIBOSOME, SUBUNIT, AND
RP   SUBCELLULAR LOCATION.
RX   PubMed=22096102; DOI=10.1126/science.1212642;
RA   Ben-Shem A., Garreau de Loubresse N., Melnikov S., Jenner L.,
RA   Yusupova G., Yusupov M.;
RT   "The structure of the eukaryotic ribosome at 3.0 A resolution.";
RL   Science 334:1524-1529(2011).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Component of the ribosome, a large ribonucleoprotein
CC       complex responsible for the synthesis of proteins in the cell. The
CC       small ribosomal subunit (SSU) binds messenger RNAs (mRNAs) and
CC       translates the encoded message by selecting cognate aminoacyl-
CC       transfer RNA (tRNA) molecules. The large subunit (LSU) contains
CC       the ribosomal catalytic site termed the peptidyl transferase
CC       center (PTC), which catalyzes the formation of peptide bonds,
CC       thereby polymerizing the amino acids delivered by tRNAs into a
CC       polypeptide chain. The nascent polypeptides leave the ribosome
CC       through a tunnel in the LSU and interact with protein factors that
CC       function in enzymatic processing, targeting, and the membrane
CC       insertion of nascent chains at the exit of the ribosomal tunnel.
CC       {ECO:0000305|PubMed:22096102}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the small ribosomal subunit (SSU). Mature
CC       yeast ribosomes consist of a small (40S) and a large (60S)
CC       subunit. The 40S small subunit contains 1 molecule of ribosomal
CC       RNA (18S rRNA) and 33 different proteins (encoded by 57 genes).
CC       The large 60S subunit contains 3 rRNA molecules (25S, 5.8S and 5S
CC       rRNA) and 46 different proteins (encoded by 81 genes)
CC       (PubMed:9559554, PubMed:22096102). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22096102,
CC       ECO:0000305|PubMed:9559554}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22096102}.
CC   -!- PTM: Hydroxylation at Pro-64 affects translation termination
CC       efficiency. The stereochemistry of the 3,4-dihydroxyproline has
CC       not yet been determined. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:24550462}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 10600 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: There are 2 genes for uS12 in yeast. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the universal ribosomal protein uS12
CC       family. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   NOMENCLATURE.
RX   PubMed=24524803; DOI=10.1016/j.sbi.2014.01.002;
RA   Ban N., Beckmann R., Cate J.H.D., Dinman J.D., Dragon F., Ellis S.R.,
RA   Lafontaine D.L.J., Lindahl L., Liljas A., Lipton J.M., McAlear M.A.,
RA   Moore P.B., Noller H.F., Ortega J., Panse V.G., Ramakrishnan V.,
RA   Spahn C.M.T., Steitz T.A., Tchorzewski M., Tollervey D., Warren A.J.,

RT   "A new system for naming ribosomal proteins.";

RN   [10]
RP   HYDROXYLATION AT PRO-64, AND MUTAGENESIS OF PRO-64 AND ASN-65.
RX   PubMed=24550462; DOI=10.1073/pnas.1311750111;
RA   Loenarz C., Sekirnik R., Thalhammer A., Ge W., Spivakovsky E.,
RA   Mackeen M.M., McDonough M.A., Cockman M.E., Kessler B.M.,
RA   Ratcliffe P.J., Wolf A., Schofield C.J.;
RT   "Hydroxylation of the eukaryotic ribosomal decoding center affects
RT   translational accuracy.";
RL   Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 111:4019-4024(2014).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Component of the ribosome, a large ribonucleoprotein
CC       complex responsible for the synthesis of proteins in the cell. The
CC       small ribosomal subunit (SSU) binds messenger RNAs (mRNAs) and
CC       translates the encoded message by selecting cognate aminoacyl-
CC       transfer RNA (tRNA) molecules. The large subunit (LSU) contains
CC       the ribosomal catalytic site termed the peptidyl transferase
CC       center (PTC), which catalyzes the formation of peptide bonds,
CC       thereby polymerizing the amino acids delivered by tRNAs into a
CC       polypeptide chain. The nascent polypeptides leave the ribosome
CC       through a tunnel in the LSU and interact with protein factors that
CC       function in enzymatic processing, targeting, and the membrane
CC       insertion of nascent chains at the exit of the ribosomal tunnel.
CC       {ECO:0000305|PubMed:22096102}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the small ribosomal subunit (SSU). Mature
CC       yeast ribosomes consist of a small (40S) and a large (60S)
CC       subunit. The 40S small subunit contains 1 molecule of ribosomal
CC       RNA (18S rRNA) and 33 different proteins (encoded by 57 genes).
CC       The large 60S subunit contains 3 rRNA molecules (25S, 5.8S and 5S
CC       rRNA) and 46 different proteins (encoded by 81 genes)
CC       (PubMed:9559554, PubMed:22096102). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22096102,
CC       ECO:0000305|PubMed:9559554}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22096102}.
CC   -!- PTM: Hydroxylation at Pro-64 affects translation termination
CC       efficiency. The stereochemistry of the 3,4-dihydroxyproline has
CC       not yet been determined. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:24550462}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 3340 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: There are 2 genes for uS12 in yeast. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the universal ribosomal protein uS12
CC       family. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   SUBCELLULAR LOCATION, IDENTIFICATION IN THE SEA COMPLEX, AND FUNCTION.
RX   PubMed=21454883; DOI=10.1074/mcp.M110.006478;
RA   Dokudovskaya S., Waharte F., Schlessinger A., Pieper U., Devos D.P.,
RA   Cristea I.M., Williams R., Salamero J., Chait B.T., Sali A.,
RA   Field M.C., Rout M.P., Dargemont C.;

RT   dynamically associates with the vacuole in Saccharomyces cerevisiae.";
RL   Mol. Cell. Proteomics 10:M110.006478.1-M110.006478.17(2011).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Component of the SEA complex which coats the vacuolar
CC       membrane and is involved in intracellular trafficking, autophagy,
CC       response to nitrogen starvation, and amino acid biogenesis.
CC       Mediates inactivation of the TORC1 complex in response to amino
CC       acid starvation. Required for meiotic nuclear division.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12586695, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19521502,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:21454883}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the SEA complex composed of at least
CC       IML1/SEA1, RTC1/SEA2, MTC5/SEA3, NPR2, NPR3, SEA4, SEC13 and SEH1.
CC       Forms a heterodimer with NPR2. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21454883}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P39923:NPR2; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-24336, EBI-12212;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Vacuole membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21454883}; Peripheral membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21454883}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the NPR3 family. {ECO:0000305}.

RA   Van Damme P., Lasa M., Polevoda B., Gazquez C., Elosegui-Artola A.,

RL   Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 109:12449-12454(2012).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Involved in transport from the ER to the Golgi apparatus
CC       as well as in intra-Golgi transport. It belongs to a super-family
CC       of proteins called t-SNAREs or soluble NSF (N-ethylmaleimide-
CC       sensitive factor) attachment protein receptor. Rescues alpha-
CC       factor maturation defects. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11160819,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11959998, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9755865}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of several multiprotein Golgi SNARE complexes.
CC       Identified in a Golgi SNARE complex consisting of t-SNARES SED5,
CC       YKT6, and the v-SNARE SFT1. Interacts with BET1. Interacts with
CC       BOS1. Interacts with SEC22. Interacts with PEP12. Interacts with
CC       self. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10591633, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11959998,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9211930, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9755865}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q01590:SED5; NbExp=5; IntAct=EBI-24365, EBI-16930;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Golgi apparatus membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16107716, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16699523,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9755865}; Single-pass type IV membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16107716, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16699523,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9755865}. Note=Punctate localization pattern.
CC       Localization affected by loss of SVP26, a membrane protein, and is
CC       shifted to the ER.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Lack of late Golgi SNARE proteins, TLG1 and
CC       TLG2. Spores are temperature sensitive and fail to germinate at 37
CC       degrees Celsius. 10 to 20% of cells possess a variety of aberrant
CC       structures, including fragmentation of the vacuole, a common
CC       occurrence in secretory defects, and substantial accumulation of
CC       membranes in some cells. These structures are considered to be
CC       abnormal Golgi remnants. Endoplasmic reticulum (ER) retention
CC       defective, erd phenotype, which is characterized by hypersecretion
CC       of ER-resident proteins. This results from a defect in retrograde
CC       directed vesicles. Severely compromised viability when another
CC       Golgi protein, COY1P is overexpressed. Incomplete maturation of
CC       alpha-factor via defective localization of KEX2.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11160819, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11689439,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12429822, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9755865}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the GOSR1 family. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- CAUTION: Formerly referred to as a v-SNARE. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: PPIases accelerate the folding of proteins. It catalyzes
CC       the cis-trans isomerization of proline imidic peptide bonds in
CC       oligopeptides. Acts as a regulatory subunit for TAP42-associated
CC       PP2A-like phosphatases modulating their activity or substrate
CC       specificity, probably by inducing a conformational change in the
CC       catalytic subunit, a direct target of the PPIase. Can reactivate
CC       inactive phosphatase PP2A-phosphatase methylesterase complexes
CC       (PP2Ai) in presence of ATP and Mg(2+) by dissociating the inactive
CC       form from the complex. Involved in the regulation of cell cycle
CC       progression, mitotic spindle formation, bud morphogenesis and DNA
CC       repair. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11134337, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11262194,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12952889, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15150670,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15689491, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16380387}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Peptidylproline (omega=180) = peptidylproline
CC       (omega=0).
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with the phosphatase PP2A-like catalytic
CC       subunits PPG1, PPH3 and SIT4. Forms a ternary complex with SIT4-
CC       TAP42. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11134337, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15150670,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15447631, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15689491}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P40164:PSY2; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-25278, EBI-29107;
CC       P20604:SIT4; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-25278, EBI-13707;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm. Nucleus.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 4590 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the PTPA-type PPIase family. {ECO:0000305}.

RX   PubMed=9799240; DOI=10.1093/emboj/17.21.6327;
RA   Blaiseau P.L., Thomas D.;
RT   "Multiple transcriptional activation complexes tether the yeast
RT   activator Met4 to DNA.";
RL   EMBO J. 17:6327-6336(1998).
RN   [6]
RP   SUBCELLULAR LOCATION [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS].
RX   PubMed=14562095; DOI=10.1038/nature02026;
RA   Huh W.-K., Falvo J.V., Gerke L.C., Carroll A.S., Howson R.W.,
RA   Weissman J.S., O'Shea E.K.;
RT   "Global analysis of protein localization in budding yeast.";
RL   Nature 425:686-691(2003).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Acts as an accessory factor in the activation of sulfur
CC       amino acids metabolism genes. Possesses no intrinsic transcription
CC       activation abilities. Binds to the MET16 promoter as a complex
CC       with MET4 and CBF1. Enhances the DNA-binding activity of CBF1.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:8665859, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9171357}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with MET4 to form a heteromeric complex which
CC       also includes CBF1. Forms two alternate complexes associating
CC       MET28 with MET4 and either MET31 or MET32. Binds to DNA through
CC       the MET4-MET28-CBF1 complex. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:8665859,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9171357, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9799240}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P32389:MET4; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-11503, EBI-10757;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095}.
CC       Nucleus {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU00978,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095}.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: Expression requires MET4, and is repressed by an
CC       increase of intracellular S-adenosylmethionine (AdoMet).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9171357}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the bZIP family. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SEQUENCE CAUTION:
CC       Sequence=AAC49425.1; Type=Erroneous initiation; Evidence={ECO:0000305};

RP   NOMENCLATURE.
RX   PubMed=24524803; DOI=10.1016/j.sbi.2014.01.002;
RA   Ban N., Beckmann R., Cate J.H.D., Dinman J.D., Dragon F., Ellis S.R.,
RA   Lafontaine D.L.J., Lindahl L., Liljas A., Lipton J.M., McAlear M.A.,
RA   Moore P.B., Noller H.F., Ortega J., Panse V.G., Ramakrishnan V.,
RA   Spahn C.M.T., Steitz T.A., Tchorzewski M., Tollervey D., Warren A.J.,
RA   Williamson J.R., Wilson D., Yonath A., Yusupov M.;
RT   "A new system for naming ribosomal proteins.";
RL   Curr. Opin. Struct. Biol. 24:165-169(2014).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Component of the ribosome, a large ribonucleoprotein
CC       complex responsible for the synthesis of proteins in the cell. The
CC       small ribosomal subunit (SSU) binds messenger RNAs (mRNAs) and
CC       translates the encoded message by selecting cognate aminoacyl-
CC       transfer RNA (tRNA) molecules. The large subunit (LSU) contains
CC       the ribosomal catalytic site termed the peptidyl transferase
CC       center (PTC), which catalyzes the formation of peptide bonds,
CC       thereby polymerizing the amino acids delivered by tRNAs into a
CC       polypeptide chain. The nascent polypeptides leave the ribosome
CC       through a tunnel in the LSU and interact with protein factors that
CC       function in enzymatic processing, targeting, and the membrane
CC       insertion of nascent chains at the exit of the ribosomal tunnel.
CC       {ECO:0000305|PubMed:22096102}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the large ribosomal subunit (LSU). Mature
CC       yeast ribosomes consist of a small (40S) and a large (60S)
CC       subunit. The 40S small subunit contains 1 molecule of ribosomal
CC       RNA (18S rRNA) and 33 different proteins (encoded by 57 genes).
CC       The large 60S subunit contains 3 rRNA molecules (25S, 5.8S and 5S
CC       rRNA) and 46 different proteins (encoded by 81 genes). uL22 is
CC       associated with the polypeptide exit tunnel (PubMed:9559554,
CC       PubMed:22096102). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22096102,
CC       ECO:0000305|PubMed:9559554}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22096102}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 21100 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: There are 2 genes for uL22 in yeast. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the universal ribosomal protein uL22
CC       family. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------
CC   Copyrighted by the UniProt Consortium, see https://www.uniprot.org/terms
CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Involved in recycling plasma membrane proteins
CC       internalized by endocytosis. Required for recycling of the v-SNARE
CC       SNC1. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10769031, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11287615}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with SKP1. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11287615}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11287615}. Bud
CC       neck {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11287615}. Cell tip
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11287615}. Note=In unpolarized G1 cells this
CC       protein is found in patches in the cytoplasm, while after bud
CC       emergence it is concentrated in nascent buds and at the mother-bud
CC       neck. Accumulates at the shmoo tips of cells treated with
CC       pheromone. Localization depends on an intact actin cytoskeleton
CC       and a functional secretory pathway.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 2700 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.

RL   Science 325:1682-1686(2009).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Component of the RAVE complex, which is required for
CC       stable assembly of the vacuolar ATPase complex V-ATPase under many
CC       conditions. Required for transport between the early endosome and
CC       the late endosome/prevacuolar compartment (PVC), suggesting that
CC       assembly of vacuolar ATPase at the early endosome is required for
CC       transport from the early endosome to the PVC.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11283612, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11844802,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15090613}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the RAVE complex composed of RAV1, RAV2 and
CC       CBF3D/SKP1. Within the complex, it interacts directly with RAV2
CC       and CBF3D. Interacts with the V-ATPase V1 subunits VMA1, VMA2 and
CC       VMA8. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11283612}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P52286:SKP1; NbExp=5; IntAct=EBI-25471, EBI-4090;
CC       P17255:VMA1; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-25471, EBI-20245;
CC       P16140:VMA2; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-25471, EBI-20254;
CC       P22203:VMA4; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-25471, EBI-20268;
CC       P32610:VMA8; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-25471, EBI-20264;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Endomembrane system
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15090613}. Note=Probably membrane-associated,
CC       associates with high density membrane compartment like early
CC       endosomes.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 149 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Required for the first step of diphthamide biosynthesis,
CC       the transfer of 3-amino-3-carboxypropyl from S-adenosyl-L-
CC       methionine to a histidine residue. Diphthamide is a post-
CC       translational modification of histidine which occurs in elongation
CC       factor 2. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15485916}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Required for mitochondrial cytochrome c oxidase (COX)
CC       assembly and respiration. Binds copper. May be involved in copper
CC       trafficking and distribution to mitochondrial COX and SOD1.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18443040, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20220131}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with CMC2. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:20220131}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Mitochondrion inner membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18443040, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19703468};
CC       Peripheral membrane protein {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18443040,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19703468}; Intermembrane side
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18443040, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19703468}.
CC       Mitochondrion intermembrane space {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22984289}.
CC       Note=Imported into the mitochondria via the mitochondrial MIA40-
CC       ERV1 machinery.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The twin Cx9C motifs are involved in the recognition by
CC       the mitochondrial MIA40-ERV1 disulfide relay system and the
CC       subsequent transfer of disulfide bonds by dithiol/disulfide
CC       exchange reactions to the newly imported protein. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 259 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the CMC family. {ECO:0000305}.

RN   [21]
RP   FUNCTION IN H3K4 METHYLATION.
RX   PubMed=17088384; DOI=10.1128/MCB.01628-06;
RA   Xiao T., Shibata Y., Rao B., Laribee R.N., O'Rourke R., Buck M.J.,
RA   Greenblatt J.F., Krogan N.J., Lieb J.D., Strahl B.D.;
RT   "The RNA polymerase II kinase Ctk1 regulates positioning of a 5'
RT   histone methylation boundary along genes.";
RL   Mol. Cell. Biol. 27:721-731(2007).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Catalytic subunit of the CTDK-I complex, which
CC       hyperphosphorylates the C-terminal heptapeptide repeat domain
CC       (CTD) of the largest RNA polymerase II subunit. CTDK-I
CC       phosphorylates 'Ser-5' if the CTD substrate is not phosphorylated
CC       at 'Ser-5', but will phosphorylate 'Ser-2' of a CTD substrate if
CC       'Ser-5' is already phosphorylated. CTDK-I is also more reactive
CC       toward substrates that are prephosphorylated at 'Ser-2' or 'Ser-5'
CC       compared with an unphosphorylated CTD substrate, therefore
CC       efficiently creating doubly phosphorylated CTD repeats. Involved
CC       in RNA polymerase II transcriptional elongation, and through PTI1,
CC       pre-mRNA 3'-end processing. Participates in both positive and
CC       negative regulation of CTD phosphorylation. Required for DNA
CC       damage induced transcription, including the expression of the RNR
CC       genes, and reprogramming of gene expression upon amino acid
CC       starvation. Required for SET2 mediated H3K36 methylation. Also
CC       regulates H3K4 methylation. Controls the maintenance of
CC       suppressive chromatin in the coding regions of genes by both
CC       promoting H3K36 methylation, which leads to histone deacetylation,
CC       and catalyzing phosphorylation of the CTD required to localize
CC       H3K4 chromatin modification specifically to the 5' ends of genes,
CC       thereby creating a boundary for H3K4 methylation that prevents a
CC       mark associated with transcriptional initiation from spreading
CC       into the bodies of genes. Involved in RNA polymerase I
CC       transcription. Involved in telomere maintenance. Acts together
CC       with SNF1 to induce GSY2 transcription in response to glucose
CC       limitation. Involved in the adaptation to alternative carbon
CC       sources, including galactose, glycerol and ethanol, but not
CC       raffinose. Required for the integrity of the rDNA locus. Functions
CC       in translation elongation by enhancing decoding fidelity. Needed
CC       for translational accuracy by phosphorylating RPS2.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10488128, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12504017,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12629047, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12684377,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15047695, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15161972,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15520468, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16182287,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16984969, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17088384,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17545469, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9110987}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: ATP + [DNA-directed RNA polymerase] = ADP +
CC       [DNA-directed RNA polymerase] phosphate.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: CTDK-I consists of three subunits, CTK1, CTK2 and CTK3
CC       (also called alpha, beta and gamma). Interacts directly with the
CC       CTK2 and CTK3 subunits, this interaction is required for kinase
CC       activity. Interacts with RNA polymerase I. Interacts with SNF1,
CC       but only at low glucose concentrations. Interacts with translating
CC       ribosomes. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11118453,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15520468, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16182287,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17545469, ECO:0000269|PubMed:7565723}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P46962:CTK2; NbExp=9; IntAct=EBI-5230, EBI-5236;
CC       P46963:CTK3; NbExp=7; IntAct=EBI-5230, EBI-5241;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus, nucleolus. Cytoplasm.
CC   -!- PTM: Phosphorylated on Thr-338 by CAK1. Phosphorylation is
CC       essential for the elevated CTD Ser-2 phosphorylation and required
CC       to activate transcription of stationary-phase genes during the
CC       diauxic shift. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15870265}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Null mutants are viable, but grow more
CC       slowly than wild-type cells at 30 degrees Celsius. They are cold-
CC       sensitive, failing to grow at 12 degrees Celsius. They display
CC       flocculent growth in liquid media and they show abnormal cell
CC       morphologies, for example, a significant fraction of the cells are
CC       greatly enlarged. Deletion mutant has increased phosphorylation of
CC       'Ser-5' of the CTD repeat during logarithmic growth. Deletion
CC       eliminates transient increase in CTD 'Ser-2' phosphorylation
CC       observed during diauxic shift. Deletion mutant is synthetically
CC       lethal when combined with deletion of DST1 or ELP genes. Deletion
CC       mutants are modestly sensitive to the uracil analog 6-azauracil
CC       (6AU), which inhibits elongation by depleting nucleotide pools.
CC       Deletion mutant is sensitive to the DNA synthesis inhibitor
CC       hydroxyurea (HU) and UV irradiation. 'Ser-2' phosphorylation
CC       within the CTD repeats is not increased in deletion mutants upon
CC       treatment with DNA-damaging agents. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10488128,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11311553, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12684377,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:7565723}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 125 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the protein kinase superfamily. CMGC
CC       Ser/Thr protein kinase family. CDC2/CDKX subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Phosphoinositide phosphatase that hydrolyzes PtdIns(3)P
CC       and PtdIns(4)P. Has low activity towards PtdIns(3,5)P2. May be
CC       involved in the coordination of the activities of the secretory
CC       pathway and the actin cytoskeleton. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10625610,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11514624}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the SPOTS complex, at least composed of
CC       LCB1/2 (LCB1 and/or LCB2), ORM1/2 (ORM1 and/or ORM2), SAC1 and
CC       TSC3. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:20182505}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P38713:OSH3; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-16210, EBI-12630;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Endoplasmic reticulum membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11514624}; Single-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11514624}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 48000 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- CAUTION: It is uncertain whether Met-1 or Met-59 is the initiator.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Ubiquitin exists either covalently attached to another
CC       protein, or free (unanchored). When covalently bound, it is
CC       conjugated to target proteins via an isopeptide bond either as a
CC       monomer (monoubiquitin), a polymer linked via different Lys
CC       residues of the ubiquitin (polyubiquitin chains) or a linear
CC       polymer linked via the initiator Met of the ubiquitin (linear
CC       polyubiquitin chains). Polyubiquitin chains, when attached to a
CC       target protein, have different functions depending on the Lys
CC       residue of the ubiquitin that is linked: Lys-6-linked may be
CC       involved in DNA repair; Lys-11-linked is involved in ERAD
CC       (endoplasmic reticulum-associated degradation) and in cell-cycle
CC       regulation; Lys-29-linked is involved in lysosomal degradation;
CC       Lys-33-linked is involved in kinase modification; Lys-48-linked is
CC       involved in protein degradation via the proteasome; Lys-63-linked
CC       is involved in endocytosis, and DNA-damage responses. Linear
CC       polymer chains formed via attachment by the initiator Met lead to
CC       cell signaling. Ubiquitin is usually conjugated to Lys residues of
CC       target proteins, however, in rare cases, conjugation to Cys or Ser
CC       residues has been observed. When polyubiquitin is free
CC       (unanchored-polyubiquitin), it also has distinct roles, such as in
CC       activation of protein kinases, and in signaling (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P40087:DDI1; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-7000452, EBI-5717;
CC       P48510:DSK2; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-7000452, EBI-6174;
CC       P48365:GYP7; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-7000452, EBI-8018;
CC       P32628:RAD23; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-7000452, EBI-14668;
CC       P00358:TDH2; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-7000452, EBI-7212;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000250}. Nucleus
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Ubiquitin is encoded by 4 different genes. UBI1 and
CC       UBI2 genes code for a single copy of ubiquitin fused to the
CC       ribosomal proteins L40. UBI3 is a polyprotein with one copy of
CC       ubiquitin fused to ribosomal protein S37. UBI4 is a polyprotein
CC       containing 5 exact head to tail repeats of ubiquitin.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ubiquitin family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Vacuolar class C ABC transporter which regulates the
CC       translocation of phosphatidylcholine to the vacuole lumen, the
CC       release of lumenal calcium stores, and acts as a negative
CC       regulator of vacuole fusion. Exhibits ATP-dependent bile acid
CC       transport. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21649806,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22970809}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Vacuole membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21649806, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22970809}; Multi-
CC       pass membrane protein {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU00441,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:21649806, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22970809}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 3000 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ABC transporter superfamily. ABCC
CC       family. Conjugate transporter (TC 3.A.1.208) subfamily.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: The COMPASS (Set1C) complex specifically mono-, di- and
CC       trimethylates histone H3 to form H3K4me1/2/3, which subsequently
CC       plays a role in telomere length maintenance and transcription
CC       elongation regulation. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11742990,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11805083}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the COMPASS (Set1C) complex which consists
CC       of SET1(2), BRE2(2), SPP1(2), SDC1(1), SHG1(1), SWD1(1), SWD2(1),
CC       and SWD3(1). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11687631,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11742990}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q03323:SDC1; NbExp=7; IntAct=EBI-27115, EBI-38307;
CC       P38827:SET1; NbExp=7; IntAct=EBI-27115, EBI-16977;

CC       {ECO:0000305}.

CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.

RN   [8]
RP   LEVEL OF PROTEIN EXPRESSION [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS].
RX   PubMed=14562106; DOI=10.1038/nature02046;
RA   Ghaemmaghami S., Huh W.-K., Bower K., Howson R.W., Belle A.,
RA   Dephoure N., O'Shea E.K., Weissman J.S.;
RT   "Global analysis of protein expression in yeast.";
RL   Nature 425:737-741(2003).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: The RIC1-RGP1 complex acts as a guanine nucleotide
CC       exchange factor (GEF), which activates YPT6 by exchanging bound
CC       GDP for free GTP. It is thereby required for efficient fusion of
CC       endosome-derived vesicles with the Golgi. The RIC1-RGP1
CC       participates in the recycling of SNC1, presumably by mediating
CC       fusion of endosomal vesicles with the Golgi compartment. May also
CC       be indirectly involved in the transcription of both ribosomal
CC       protein genes and ribosomal RNA. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10990452,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11160819, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11689439}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Forms a complex with RGP1. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10990452}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P16664:RGP1; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-15183, EBI-15080;
CC       Q99260:YPT6; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-15183, EBI-29503;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Golgi apparatus membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10990452, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11160819,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11689439, ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095};
CC       Peripheral membrane protein {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10990452,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11160819, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11689439,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 78 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the RIC1 family. Highly divergent.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Required for the uptake of Fe(3+) ions. May participate
CC       in the transport of electrons from cytoplasm to an extracellular
CC       substrate (Fe(3+) ion) via FAD and heme intermediates (By
CC       similarity). Involved in iron homeostasis. {ECO:0000250,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:14534306}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: 2 Fe(II)-siderophore + NAD(+) + H(+) = 2
CC       Fe(III)-siderophore + NADH.
CC   -!- COFACTOR:
CC       Name=FAD; Xref=ChEBI:CHEBI:57692; Evidence={ECO:0000305};
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: Expression decreased by the copper-sensing
CC       transcription factor MAC1. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14534306}.

RP   DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE, AND FUNCTION.
RX   PubMed=21912603; DOI=10.1371/journal.pone.0023696;
RA   Ricarte F., Menjivar R., Chhun S., Soreta T., Oliveira L., Hsueh T.,

RN   [6]
RP   FUNCTION, SUBCELLULAR LOCATION, AND INTERACTION WITH SND1; PHO88 AND
RP   SEC61.
RX   PubMed=27905431; DOI=10.1038/nature20169;
RA   Aviram N., Ast T., Costa E.A., Arakel E.C., Chuartzman S.G., Jan C.H.,
RA   Hassdenteufel S., Dudek J., Jung M., Schorr S., Zimmermann R.,
RA   Schwappach B., Weissman J.S., Schuldiner M.;
RT   "The SND proteins constitute an alternative targeting route to the
RT   endoplasmic reticulum.";
RL   Nature 540:134-138(2016).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Functions in the SND pathway, a SRP (signal recognition
CC       particle) and GET (guided entry of tail-anchored proteins)
CC       independent pathway for targeting a broad range of substrate
CC       proteins to the endoplasmic reticulum. SND functions in parallel
CC       to GET in targeting proteins with downstream hydrophobic motifs
CC       (PubMed:27905431). Involved in vacuolar processing and morphology
CC       (PubMed:21912603). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21912603,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:27905431}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with SND1, PHO88/SND3 and the translocon
CC       complex subunit SEC61. ENV10/SND2 and PHO88/SND3 form a complex
CC       with the translocon in the endoplasmic reticulum membrane.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:27905431}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Endoplasmic reticulum membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:27905431}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000255}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Exhibits cold sensitivity and leads to
CC       internal accumulation of precursor CPY.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21912603}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the TMEM208 family. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   INTERACTION WITH RAX1, SUBCELLULAR LOCATION, AND GLYCOSYLATION.
RX   PubMed=15356260; DOI=10.1091/mbc.E04-07-0600;
RA   Kang P.J., Angerman E., Nakashima K., Pringle J.R., Park H.-O.;
RT   "Interactions among Rax1p, Rax2p, Bud8p, and Bud9p in marking cortical
RT   sites for bipolar bud-site selection in yeast.";
RL   Mol. Biol. Cell 15:5145-5157(2004).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Required for the maintenance of the bipolar budding
CC       pattern. Involved in selecting bud sites at both the distal and
CC       proximal poles of daughter cells as well as near previously used
CC       division sites on mother cells. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11110666}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with RAX1. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15356260}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane; Single-pass type I membrane
CC       protein. Bud neck. Bud tip. Note=Before cytokinesis, RAX2
CC       concentrates as a ring at the mother-bud neck and to the tip of
CC       the bud. The RAX2 ring splits at cytokinesis, endowing each
CC       progeny cell with a RAX2 ring and additional RAX2 localization at
CC       the distal bud pole of the newborn daughter cell. The rings
CC       persist at the cell cortex for several generations, giving rise to
CC       cells decorated by multiple rings.
CC   -!- PTM: Glycosylated. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15356260}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 3670 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Acts as component of the peripheral membrane COG complex
CC       that is involved in intra-Golgi protein trafficking. COG is
CC       located at the cis-Golgi, and regulates tethering of retrograde
CC       intra-Golgi vesicles and possibly a number of other membrane
CC       trafficking events. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11703943}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the conserved oligomeric Golgi (COG or
CC       Sec34/Sec35) complex which consists of eight different proteins
CC       COG1-COG8. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11703943}.

RC   STRAIN=ATCC 208353 / W303-1A;

RP   LEVEL OF PROTEIN EXPRESSION [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS].
RX   PubMed=14562106; DOI=10.1038/nature02046;
RA   Ghaemmaghami S., Huh W.-K., Bower K., Howson R.W., Belle A.,
RA   Dephoure N., O'Shea E.K., Weissman J.S.;
RT   "Global analysis of protein expression in yeast.";
RL   Nature 425:737-741(2003).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Mitochondrial membrane ATP synthase (F(1)F(0) ATP
CC       synthase or Complex V) produces ATP from ADP in the presence of a
CC       proton gradient across the membrane which is generated by electron
CC       transport complexes of the respiratory chain. F-type ATPases
CC       consist of two structural domains, F(1) - containing the
CC       extramembraneous catalytic core and F(0) - containing the membrane
CC       proton channel, linked together by a central stalk and a
CC       peripheral stalk. During catalysis, ATP synthesis in the catalytic
CC       domain of F(1) is coupled via a rotary mechanism of the central
CC       stalk subunits to proton translocation. Part of the complex F(0)
CC       domain. Minor subunit located with subunit a in the membrane.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: F-type ATPases have 2 components, CF(1) - the catalytic
CC       core - and CF(0) - the membrane proton channel. In yeast, the
CC       dimeric form of ATP synthase consists of 17 polypeptides: alpha,
CC       beta, gamma, delta, epsilon, 4 (B), 5 (OSCP), 6 (A), 8, 9 (C), d,
CC       E (Tim11), f, g, h, i/j and k.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Mitochondrion membrane {ECO:0000305};
CC       Single-pass membrane protein {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- MASS SPECTROMETRY: Mass=6687.1; Mass_error=2; Method=Electrospray;
CC       Range=1-59; Evidence={ECO:0000269|PubMed:9867878};
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 6540 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.

RP   IDENTIFICATION BY MASS SPECTROMETRY [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS].
RX   PubMed=19779198; DOI=10.1126/science.1172867;
RA   Holt L.J., Tuch B.B., Villen J., Johnson A.D., Gygi S.P., Morgan D.O.;
RT   "Global analysis of Cdk1 substrate phosphorylation sites provides
RT   insights into evolution.";
RL   Science 325:1682-1686(2009).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Required for DNA mismatch repair (MMR), correcting base-
CC       base mismatches and insertion-deletion loops (IDLs) resulting from
CC       DNA replication, DNA damage or from recombination events between
CC       non-identical sequences during meiosis. Component of different
CC       MutL heterodimers that form a ternary complex with the MutS
CC       heterodimers, which initially recognize the DNA mismatches. This
CC       complex is thought to be responsible for directing the downsteam
CC       MMR events, including strand discrimination, excision, and
CC       resynthesis. Plays a major role in maintaining the genetic
CC       stability of simple sequence repeats, the repair of heteroduplex
CC       sites present in meiotic recombination intermediates, and the
CC       promotion of meiotic crossing-over. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10570173,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12529393, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9545323}.
CC   -!- BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES:
CC       Kinetic parameters:
CC         KM=69 uM for ATP {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11717305};
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Heterodimer of MLH1 and PMS1, called MutLalpha, which is
CC       the major MMR MutL activity correcting base-base mismatches as
CC       well as IDLs. The heterodimer binds double strand DNA
CC       independently of a mismatch with positive cooperativity and has
CC       more than one DNA binding site. Forms a ternary complex with
CC       either the MSH2-MSH6 (MutSalpha) or the MSH2-MSH3 heterodimer
CC       (MutSbeta), which recognize and bind to mismatch DNA. Ternary
CC       complex formation is promoted by ATP binding. Heterodimer of MLH1
CC       and MLH3, called MutLbeta, which is involved in correction of a
CC       specific subset of IDLs when associated with MutSbeta. Heterodimer
CC       of MLH1 and MLH2. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9545323}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P39875:EXO1; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-11003, EBI-6738;
CC       Q07980:MLH2; NbExp=5; IntAct=EBI-11003, EBI-33369;
CC       Q12083:MLH3; NbExp=5; IntAct=EBI-11003, EBI-31634;
CC       Q08214:NTG2; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-11003, EBI-12303;
CC       P14242:PMS1; NbExp=12; IntAct=EBI-11003, EBI-13561;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 319 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the DNA mismatch repair MutL/HexB family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: The glycine cleavage system (glycine decarboxylase
CC       complex) catalyzes the degradation of glycine. The P protein binds
CC       the alpha-amino group of glycine through its pyridoxal phosphate
CC       cofactor; CO(2) is released and the remaining methylamine moiety
CC       is then transferred to the lipoamide cofactor of the H protein.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Glycine + [glycine-cleavage complex H
CC       protein]-N(6)-lipoyl-L-lysine = [glycine-cleavage complex H
CC       protein]-S-aminomethyl-N(6)-dihydrolipoyl-L-lysine + CO(2).
CC   -!- COFACTOR:
CC       Name=pyridoxal 5'-phosphate; Xref=ChEBI:CHEBI:597326;
CC         Evidence={ECO:0000250};
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the glycine decarboxylase complex (GDC),
CC       which is composed of four proteins: P, T, L and H.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Mitochondrion {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: By glycine. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:8830251}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 12000 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the GcvP family. {ECO:0000305}.

RA   Ghaemmaghami S., Huh W.-K., Bower K., Howson R.W., Belle A.,
RA   Dephoure N., O'Shea E.K., Weissman J.S.;
RT   "Global analysis of protein expression in yeast.";
RL   Nature 425:737-741(2003).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Responsible for the deacetylation of lysine residues on
CC       the N-terminal part of the core histones (H2A, H2B, H3 and H4).
CC       Histone deacetylation gives a tag for epigenetic repression and
CC       plays an important role in transcriptional regulation, cell cycle
CC       progression and developmental events. Histone deacetylases act via
CC       the formation of large multiprotein complexes.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Hydrolysis of an N(6)-acetyl-lysine residue of
CC       a histone to yield a deacetylated histone.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Self; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-8206, EBI-8206;
CC       Q06629:HDA2; NbExp=6; IntAct=EBI-8206, EBI-32800;
CC       Q06623:HDA3; NbExp=6; IntAct=EBI-8206, EBI-38663;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 3050 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the histone deacetylase family. HD type 2
CC       subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   STRUCTURE BY ELECTRON MICROSCOPY (3.30 ANGSTROMS), AND SUBUNIT.
RX   PubMed=28154081; DOI=10.1126/science.aal2415;
RA   Desai N., Brown A., Amunts A., Ramakrishnan V.;
RT   "The structure of the yeast mitochondrial ribosome.";
RL   Science 355:528-531(2017).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Component of the mitochondrial ribosome (mitoribosome),
CC       a dedicated translation machinery responsible for the synthesis of
CC       mitochondrial genome-encoded proteins, including at least some of
CC       the essential transmembrane subunits of the mitochondrial
CC       respiratory chain. The mitoribosomes are attached to the
CC       mitochondrial inner membrane and translation products are
CC       cotranslationally integrated into the membrane.
CC       {ECO:0000305|PubMed:25609543, ECO:0000305|PubMed:28154081}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the mitochondrial small ribosomal subunit
CC       (mt-SSU). Mature yeast 74S mitochondrial ribosomes consist of a
CC       small (37S) and a large (54S) subunit. The 37S small subunit
CC       contains a 15S ribosomal RNA (15S mt-rRNA) and 34 different
CC       proteins. The 54S large subunit contains a 21S rRNA (21S mt-rRNA)
CC       and 46 different proteins. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:28154081}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Mitochondrion {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10649453,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095}. Note=Mitoribosomes are tethered to
CC       the mitochondrial inner membrane and spatially aligned with the
CC       membrane insertion machinery through two distinct membrane contact
CC       sites, formed by the 21S rRNA expansion segment 96-ES1 and the
CC       inner membrane protein MBA1. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:25609543}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 259 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the universal ribosomal protein uS13
CC       family. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   PHOSPHORYLATION [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS] AT SER-206, AND IDENTIFICATION
RP   BY MASS SPECTROMETRY [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS].
RX   PubMed=18407956; DOI=10.1074/mcp.M700468-MCP200;
RA   Albuquerque C.P., Smolka M.B., Payne S.H., Bafna V., Eng J., Zhou H.;
RT   "A multidimensional chromatography technology for in-depth
RT   phosphoproteome analysis.";
RL   Mol. Cell. Proteomics 7:1389-1396(2008).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: E3 ubiquitin-protein ligase which functions in cell
CC       cycle retarding in conjonction with the UBC4 and UBC13/MMS2
CC       complex, 2 E2 ubiquitin conjugationg enzymes. Involved in
CC       nutritional control of the cell cycle. Required for proper spindle
CC       positioning, likely regulating septin ring deposition at the bud
CC       neck. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15146058, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15319434,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18202552}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: S-ubiquitinyl-[E2 ubiquitin-conjugating
CC       enzyme]-L-cysteine + [acceptor protein]-L-lysine = [E2 ubiquitin-
CC       conjugating enzyme]-L-cysteine + N(6)-ubiquitinyl-[acceptor
CC       protein]-L-lysine. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18202552}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095}.
CC   -!- PTM: UBC4-dependent autoubiquitination occurs at Lys-211, Lys-258,
CC       Lys-288, Lys-310, Lys-333, Lys-343, Lys-346, Lys-366, Lys-406,
CC       Lys-412 and Lys-423. UBC4-dependent autoubiquitination is
CC       responsible for DMA2 turnover. UBC13/MMS2-dependent
CC       autoubiquitination occurs at Lys-258, Lys-310, Lys-346 and Lys-
CC       366. Lys-211, Lys-256, Lys-288, Lys-310, Lys-343, Lys-258, Lys-366
CC       and Lys-412 are also ubiquitinated in trans by DMA1 E3 ligase in
CC       association with UBC4. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18202552}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 1750 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the DMA1 family. {ECO:0000305}.

RN   [9]
RP   FUNCTION, AND BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES.
RX   PubMed=18673302; DOI=10.1042/BSR20080081;
RA   Pospisilova H., Sebela M., Novak O., Frebort I.;
RT   "Hydrolytic cleavage of N6-substituted adenine derivatives by
RT   eukaryotic adenine and adenosine deaminases.";
RL   Biosci. Rep. 28:335-347(2008).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Catalyzes the hydrolytic deamination of adenine to
CC       hypoxanthine. Plays an important role in the purine salvage
CC       pathway and in nitrogen catabolism. Also exhibits a low activity
CC       towards N(6)-substituted adenines that are commonly known as the
CC       plant hormones cytokinins. {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03145,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:14643670, ECO:0000269|PubMed:1577682,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17517885, ECO:0000269|PubMed:18673302}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Adenine + H(2)O = hypoxanthine + NH(3).
CC       {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03145}.
CC   -!- COFACTOR:
CC       Name=Zn(2+); Xref=ChEBI:CHEBI:29105;
CC         Evidence={ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03145};
CC       Note=Binds 1 zinc ion per subunit. {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-
CC       Rule:MF_03145};
CC   -!- BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES:
CC       Kinetic parameters:
CC         KM=55 uM for adenine {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18673302};
CC       pH dependence:
CC         Optimum pH is 7.0. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18673302};
CC       Temperature dependence:
CC         Optimum temperature is 30-37 degrees Celsius.
CC         {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18673302};
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P38352:SAF1; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-2197, EBI-21172;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03145,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095}. Nucleus {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-
CC       Rule:MF_03145, ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095}.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: Reduced when grown in a poor nitrogen source medium and
CC       strongly down-regulated when cells enter quiescence under
CC       nutrient-limiting conditions. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:1577682}.
CC   -!- PTM: Probably ubiquitinated when cells enter quiescence in
CC       response to nutrient limitation, since it is specifically degraded
CC       via a process requiring the F-box protein SAF1 and components of
CC       the SKP1-Cullin-F-box complex. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17517885}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 20700 molecules/cell in log phase SD

RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (1.6 ANGSTROMS) IN COMPLEX WITH MAGNESIUM IONS
RP   AND AMP.
RX   PubMed=10656801; DOI=10.1006/jmbi.1999.3408;
RA   Albert A., Yenush L., Gil-Mascarell M.R., Rodriguez P.L., Patel S.,
RA   Martinez-Ripoll M., Blundell T.L., Serrano R.;
RT   "X-ray structure of yeast Hal2p, a major target of lithium and sodium
RT   toxicity, and identification of framework interactions determining
RT   cation sensitivity.";
RL   J. Mol. Biol. 295:927-938(2000).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Converts adenosine 3'-phosphate 5'-phosphosulfate (PAPS)
CC       to adenosine 5'-phosphosulfate (APS) and 3'(2')-phosphoadenosine
CC       5'- phosphate (PAP) to AMP. Regulates the flux of sulfur in the
CC       sulfur-activation pathway by converting PAPS to APS. Involved in
CC       salt tolerance. Confers resistance to lithium.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Adenosine 3',5'-bisphosphate + H(2)O =
CC       adenosine 5'-phosphate + phosphate.
CC   -!- COFACTOR:
CC       Name=Mg(2+); Xref=ChEBI:CHEBI:18420;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095}.
CC       Nucleus {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095}.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: By salt stress.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 7330 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the inositol monophosphatase superfamily.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Required for vacuolar assembly. Provides the t-SNARE
CC       function in a late step of the vacuolar assembly. Required for
CC       homotypic vacuole membrane fusion, autophagy and fusion of
CC       biosynthetic transport vesicles with the vacuole. Required for the
CC       delivery of alpha-factor receptor-ligand complexes to the vacuole.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Associates with VAM7.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q12255:NYV1; NbExp=21; IntAct=EBI-20227, EBI-35465;
CC       P32912:VAM7; NbExp=11; IntAct=EBI-20227, EBI-20232;
CC       P20795:VPS33; NbExp=12; IntAct=EBI-20227, EBI-20395;
CC       Q04338:VTI1; NbExp=12; IntAct=EBI-20227, EBI-20519;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Vacuole membrane; Single-pass type IV
CC       membrane protein.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 414 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the syntaxin family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Subunit of the integral membrane V0 complex of vacuolar
CC       ATPase essential for assembly and catalytic activity. Is present
CC       only in vacuolar V-ATPase complexes. Enzymes containing this
CC       subunit have a 4-fold higher ratio of proton transport to ATP
CC       hydrolysis than complexes containing the Golgi/endosomal isoform
CC       and undergo reversible dissociation of V1 and V0 in response to
CC       glucose depletion. V-ATPase is responsible for acidifying a
CC       variety of intracellular compartments in eukaryotic cells.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11278748, ECO:0000269|PubMed:1491220,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8798414}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: V-ATPase is a heteromultimeric enzyme composed of a
CC       peripheral catalytic V1 complex (components A to H) attached to an
CC       integral membrane V0 proton pore complex (components: a, c, c',
CC       c'', d and e). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:1491220}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P41807:VMA13; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-20455, EBI-20281;
CC       P32366:VMA6; NbExp=8; IntAct=EBI-20455, EBI-20201;
CC       P39111:VMA7; NbExp=5; IntAct=EBI-20455, EBI-20272;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Vacuole membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095}.
CC   -!- PTM: Glycosylated.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 55714 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the V-ATPase 116 kDa subunit family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

RX   PubMed=10428786; DOI=10.1074/jbc.274.32.22208;
RA   Baumgartner U., Hamilton B., Piskacek M., Ruis H., Rottensteiner H.;

RP   DNA-BINDING.
RX   PubMed=12709061; DOI=10.1046/j.1432-1033.2003.03575.x;
RA   Rottensteiner H., Hartig A., Hamilton B., Ruis H., Erdmann R.,
RA   Gurvitz A.;

RL   Eur. J. Biochem. 270:2013-2022(2003).
RN   [8]
RP   DOMAIN.
RX   PubMed=17467953; DOI=10.1016/j.ygeno.2007.02.003;
RA   Piskacek S., Gregor M., Nemethova M., Grabner M., Kovarik P.,
RA   Piskacek M.;
RT   "Nine-amino-acid transactivation domain: establishment and prediction
RT   utilities.";
RL   Genomics 89:756-768(2007).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: The PIP2-OAF1 heterodimer acts as a transcriptional
CC       activator to induce the transcription of genes encoding proteins
CC       involved in fatty acid beta-oxidation, a response called oleic
CC       acid induction, when cells grow on fatty acids as sole carbon
CC       source. Recognizes and binds to the oleate response element (ORE)
CC       (or peroxisome box), two inverted CGG triplets spaced by 14 to 18
CC       intervening nucleotides, in the promoter region of a number of
CC       genes (such as CTA1, FOX1 to FOX3, FAA2, PAS8, PAS10, etc.) for
CC       peroxisomal proteins. Activity is inhibited by OAF1 under non-
CC       inducing conditions. Activity is repressed by glucose.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10428786, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8670793,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8972187, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9288897}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Heterodimer of PIP2 and OAF1.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: Autoregulated. Induced upon growth on fatty acids.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:8972187, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9288897}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: the 9aaTAD motif (residues 985 to 993) is a
CC       transactivation domain present in a large number of yeast and
CC       animal transcription factors. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17467953}.

RN   [8]
RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (1.98 ANGSTROMS) IN COMPLEX WITH MAGNESIUM IONS,
RP   AND SUBUNIT.
RX   PubMed=16554305; DOI=10.1074/jbc.M512886200;
RA   Chang T.-H., Guo R.-T., Ko T.-P., Wang A.H.-J., Liang P.-H.;
RT   "Crystal structure of type-III geranylgeranyl pyrophosphate synthase
RT   from Saccharomyces cerevisiae and the mechanism of product chain
RT   length determination.";
RL   J. Biol. Chem. 281:14991-15000(2006).
RN   [9]
RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (1.8 ANGSTROMS) IN COMPLEXES WITH ISOPENTENYL
RP   DIPHOSPHATE; FARNESYL DIPHOSPHATE AND MAGNESIUM, COFACTOR, AND
RP   SUBUNIT.
RX   PubMed=17535895; DOI=10.1073/pnas.0702254104;
RA   Guo R.-T., Cao R., Liang P.-H., Ko T.-P., Chang T.-H., Hudock M.P.,
RA   Jeng W.-Y., Chen C.K.-M., Zhang Y., Song Y., Kuo C.-J., Yin F.,
RA   Oldfield E., Wang A.H.-J.;
RT   "Bisphosphonates target multiple sites in both cis- and trans-
RT   prenyltransferases.";
RL   Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 104:10022-10027(2007).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Catalyzes the trans-addition of the 3 molecules of IPP
CC       onto DMAPP to form geranylgeranyl pyrophosphate. Required for the
CC       membrane attachment of YPT1 and SEC4. May be involved in vesicle
CC       trafficking and protein sorting. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15296494,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:7665600}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Dimethylallyl diphosphate + isopentenyl
CC       diphosphate = diphosphate + geranyl diphosphate.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Geranyl diphosphate + isopentenyl diphosphate
CC       = diphosphate + (2E,6E)-farnesyl diphosphate.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: (2E,6E)-farnesyl diphosphate + isopentenyl
CC       diphosphate = diphosphate + geranylgeranyl diphosphate.
CC   -!- COFACTOR:
CC       Name=Mg(2+); Xref=ChEBI:CHEBI:18420;
CC         Evidence={ECO:0000269|PubMed:17535895};
CC       Note=Binds 3 Mg(2+) ions per subunit.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17535895};
CC   -!- BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES:
CC       Kinetic parameters:
CC         KM=3.2 uM for farnesyl diphosphate;
CC         KM=0.8 uM for isopentenyl diphosphate;
CC   -!- PATHWAY: Isoprenoid biosynthesis; farnesyl diphosphate
CC       biosynthesis; farnesyl diphosphate from geranyl diphosphate and
CC       isopentenyl diphosphate: step 1/1.
CC   -!- PATHWAY: Isoprenoid biosynthesis; geranyl diphosphate
CC       biosynthesis; geranyl diphosphate from dimethylallyl diphosphate
CC       and isopentenyl diphosphate: step 1/1.
CC   -!- PATHWAY: Isoprenoid biosynthesis; geranylgeranyl diphosphate
CC       biosynthesis; geranylgeranyl diphosphate from farnesyl diphosphate
CC       and isopentenyl diphosphate: step 1/1.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 2840 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the FPP/GGPP synthase family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: May be involved in the mRNA export process (By
CC       similarity). Forms the [NU+] prion and induces [PSI+] prion
CC       formation. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095}.
CC       Nucleus {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The N-terminal 153 residues are responsible for the prion
CC       properties of NEW1. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11511346,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9020838}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 37600 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ABC transporter superfamily. ABCF
CC       family. EF3 subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   SUBUNIT.
RX   PubMed=18843051; DOI=10.1091/mbc.E08-01-0103;
RA   Dunn C.D., Tamura Y., Sesaki H., Jensen R.E.;
RT   "Mgr3p and Mgr1p are adaptors for the mitochondrial i-AAA protease
RT   complex.";
RL   Mol. Biol. Cell 19:5387-5397(2008).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Catalytic subunit of the mitochondrial inner membrane i-
CC       AAA protease supercomplex required for mitochondrial inner
CC       membrane protein turnover. The protease is probably ATP-dependent.
CC       Important to maintain the integrity of the mitochondrial
CC       compartment. Required both for the degradation of unassembled
CC       subunit 2 of cytochrome c oxidase (COX2) and for efficient
CC       assembly of mitochondrial respiratory chain. Binds unfolded
CC       substrates in an ATPase-independent manner; binding of folded
CC       COX2, a physiological substrate, requires an active ATPase but
CC       when COX2 is destabilized an active ATPase is no longer necessary.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16267274, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16527490}.
CC   -!- COFACTOR:
CC       Name=Zn(2+); Xref=ChEBI:CHEBI:29105; Evidence={ECO:0000250};
CC       Note=Binds 1 zinc ion per subunit. {ECO:0000250};
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the mitochondrial inner membrane i-AAA
CC       protease supercomplex composed of MGR1, MGR3 and YME1. Interacts
CC       directly with MGR1. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16267274,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18843051}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P25573:MGR1; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-27785, EBI-21740;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Mitochondrion inner membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8355690,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8688560}; Peripheral membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8355690,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8688560}; Matrix side
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8355690,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8688560}. Note=Although this protein does not
CC       have any predicted transmembrane helices it behaves like an
CC       integral membrane protein.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: An increased rate of escape of mtDNA to the
CC       nucleus, no growth on nonfermentable carbon sources at 37 degrees
CC       Celsius, a cold-sensitive defect in growth on fermentable carbon
CC       sources, lethality in rho- (cytoplasmic petite) cells.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:8355690}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 20100 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: In the N-terminal section; belongs to the AAA ATPase
CC       family. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: In the C-terminal section; belongs to the peptidase
CC       M41 family. {ECO:0000305}.

FT                                mutant, retains 20% protease activity in

FT                                protein. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16527490}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Required for mitochondrial fusion as well as normal
CC       mitochondrial morphology by bridging the essential interaction
CC       between FZO1 and MGM1. May coordinate fusion of inner and outer
CC       membranes during mitochondrial fusion.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11257114, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15087460}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with FZO1 through its cytoplasmic domain and
CC       with MGM1 through its mitochondrial intermembrane space domain.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12566426, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12808034,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15087460}.

RN   [11]
RP   IDENTIFICATION BY MASS SPECTROMETRY [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS].
RX   PubMed=22814378; DOI=10.1073/pnas.1210303109;
RA   Van Damme P., Lasa M., Polevoda B., Gazquez C., Elosegui-Artola A.,
RA   Kim D.S., De Juan-Pardo E., Demeyer K., Hole K., Larrea E.,
RA   Timmerman E., Prieto J., Arnesen T., Sherman F., Gevaert K.,
RA   Aldabe R.;
RT   "N-terminal acetylome analyses and functional insights of the N-
RT   terminal acetyltransferase NatB.";
RL   Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 109:12449-12454(2012).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Catalyzes the hydrolysis of phosphoanhydride bonds of
CC       nucleoside tri- and di-phosphates. Has equal high activity toward
CC       ADP/ATP, GDP/GTP, and UDP/UTP and approximately 50% less toward
CC       CDP/CTP and thiamine pyrophosphate. Has no activity toward GMP.
CC       Required for Golgi glycosylation and cell wall integrity. Together
CC       with CDC55, required for adenovirus E4orf4 (early region 4 open
CC       reading frame 4) induced toxicity, the apyrase activity is not
CC       required for this function. Plays a role in sphingolipid
CC       synthesis. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10409709,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16227198, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16702413}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: A nucleoside 5'-triphosphate + 2 H(2)O = a
CC       nucleoside 5'-phosphate + 2 phosphate.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10954728, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16227198}.
CC   -!- COFACTOR:
CC       Name=Ca(2+); Xref=ChEBI:CHEBI:29108; Evidence={ECO:0000250};
CC       Name=Mg(2+); Xref=ChEBI:CHEBI:18420; Evidence={ECO:0000250};
CC       Name=Mn(2+); Xref=ChEBI:CHEBI:29035; Evidence={ECO:0000250};
CC       Note=A divalent cation Ca(2+), Mg(2+) or Mn(2+). {ECO:0000250};
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: Activity is inhibited both by interaction with
CC       VMA13 and by V-ATPase acidification of the lumen. The activity of
CC       VMA13 is not required for YND1 inhibition.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10954728}.
CC   -!- PATHWAY: Protein modification; protein glycosylation.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with activator subunit VMA13 of vacuolar H(+)-
CC       ATPase. Interacts with CDC55; this interaction is disrupted by
CC       adenovirus E4orf4, which remains associated with both YND1 and
CC       CDC55. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10954728, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16227198}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Golgi apparatus
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10409709, ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095}.
CC       Membrane {ECO:0000305}; Single-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Cells are partially resistant to E4orf4 and
CC       can partially suppress the spindle checkpoint defect in CDC55
CC       deletion mutant. Does not suppress the rapamycin-resistance of
CC       CDC55 deletion mutant. YND1 and CDC55 double mutant is fully
CC       resistant to E4orf4. Deletion mutant suppresses the synthetic
CC       lethality of triple mutants, where UPC2 and ECM22 are knocked out
CC       along with either HAP1, ERG6 or ERG28.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16227198, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16702413}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 450 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the GDA1/CD39 NTPase family. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (4.6 ANGSTROMS) OF 2-35 IN COMPLEX WITH GET3,
RP   FUNCTION, SUBUNIT, SUBCELLULAR LOCATION, AND TOPOLOGY.
RX   PubMed=21719644; DOI=10.1126/science.1207125;
RA   Stefer S., Reitz S., Wang F., Wild K., Pang Y.Y., Schwarz D.,
RA   Bomke J., Hein C., Lohr F., Bernhard F., Denic V., Dotsch V.,
RA   Sinning I.;
RT   "Structural basis for tail-anchored membrane protein biogenesis by the
RT   Get3-receptor complex.";
RL   Science 333:758-762(2011).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Required for the post-translational delivery of tail-
CC       anchored (TA) proteins to the endoplasmic reticulum. Together with
CC       GET1, acts as a membrane receptor for soluble GET3, which
CC       recognizes and selectively binds the transmembrane domain of TA
CC       proteins in the cytosol. The GET complex cooperates with the HDEL
CC       receptor ERD2 to mediate the ATP-dependent retrieval of resident
CC       ER proteins that contain a C-terminal H-D-E-L retention signal
CC       from the Golgi to the ER. Involved in DNA replication and DNA
CC       damage response and also in cell wall function.
CC       {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03114, ECO:0000269|PubMed:10929718,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12586695, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12615994,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16269340, ECO:0000269|PubMed:18724936,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:21719644, ECO:0000269|PubMed:21835666}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the Golgi to ER traffic (GET) complex, which
CC       is composed of GET1, GET2 and GET3. {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-
CC       Rule:MF_03114, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11805837,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16269340, ECO:0000269|PubMed:21719644,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:21835666}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P53192:GET1; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-22604, EBI-23722;
CC       Q12154:GET3; NbExp=9; IntAct=EBI-22604, EBI-2989;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Endoplasmic reticulum membrane; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein. Golgi apparatus membrane; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the GET2 family. {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-
CC       Rule:MF_03114}.

RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (2.2 ANGSTROMS) IN COMPLEX WITH FAD AND NAD.
RA   Adachi W., Suzuki K., Tsunoda M., Sekiguchi T., Reed L.J.,
RA   Takenaka A.;
RT   "Crystal structure of yeast lipoamide dehydrogenase complexed with
RT   NAD+.";
RL   Submitted (FEB-2005) to the PDB data bank.
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Lipoamide dehydrogenase is a component of the alpha-
CC       ketoacid dehydrogenase complexes. This includes the pyruvate
CC       dehydrogenase complex, which catalyzes the overall conversion of
CC       pyruvate to acetyl-CoA and CO(2). Acts also as component of the
CC       glycine cleavage system (glycine decarboxylase complex), which
CC       catalyzes the degradation of glycine.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Protein N(6)-(dihydrolipoyl)lysine + NAD(+) =
CC       protein N(6)-(lipoyl)lysine + NADH.
CC   -!- COFACTOR:
CC       Name=FAD; Xref=ChEBI:CHEBI:57692; Evidence={ECO:0000250};
CC       Note=Binds 1 FAD per subunit. {ECO:0000250};
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: LPD1 is a homodimer. Eukaryotic pyruvate dehydrogenase
CC       (PDH) complexes are organized as a core consisting of the
CC       oligomeric dihydrolipoamide acetyl-transferase (E2), around which
CC       are arranged multiple copies of pyruvate dehydrogenase (E1),
CC       dihydrolipoamide dehydrogenase (E3) and protein X (E3BP) bound by
CC       non-covalent bonds. LPD1 is a component of the glycine
CC       decarboxylase complex (GDC), which is composed of four proteins:
CC       P, T, L and H. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:7498764,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9538259, ECO:0000269|Ref.9}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P19262:KGD2; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-5940, EBI-12464;
CC       P19955:YMR31; NbExp=5; IntAct=EBI-5940, EBI-16295;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Mitochondrion matrix.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: The active site is a redox-active disulfide bond.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 24600 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the class-I pyridine nucleotide-disulfide
CC       oxidoreductase family. {ECO:0000305}.

RN   [9]
RP   FUNCTION, AND INTERACTION WITH IGO1.
RX   PubMed=20471941; DOI=10.1016/j.molcel.2010.02.039;
RA   Talarek N., Cameroni E., Jaquenoud M., Luo X., Bontron S., Lippman S.,
RA   Devgan G., Snyder M., Broach J.R., De Virgilio C.;
RT   "Initiation of the TORC1-regulated G0 program requires Igo1/2, which
RT   license specific mRNAs to evade degradation via the 5'-3' mRNA decay
RT   pathway.";
RL   Mol. Cell 38:345-355(2010).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Protein kinase that positively regulates proper entry
CC       into stationary phase of cells under nutrient starvation
CC       conditions. Involved in glycogen and trehalose accumulation,
CC       derepression of stress-induced genes, induction of thermotolerance
CC       and starvation resistance, and proper G1 cell cycle arrest. Also
CC       involved in the activation of a meiotic genes activation pathway.
CC       Phosphorylates IGO1 and IGO2, both involved in the TORC1 control
CC       of gene expression and chronological life span.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16308562, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20471941,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9744870}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: ATP + a protein = ADP + a phosphoprotein.
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: Kinase activity is inhibited by phosphorylation
CC       by cAMP-dependent protein kinase (PKA).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9744870}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with the cyclin-dependent kinase (CDK) PHO85
CC       and IGO1. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:20471941}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P13186:KIN2; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-15150, EBI-9723;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16308562}.
CC       Nucleus {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16308562}.
CC   -!- PTM: Autophosphorylated. Phosphorylation by PKA strongly inhibits
CC       kinase activity. Phosphorylation by cyclin-CDK PHO80-PHO85 under
CC       favorable growth condition causes inactivation of RIM15 by
CC       promoting its export to the cytoplasm.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16308562}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the protein kinase superfamily. Ser/Thr
CC       protein kinase family. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU00159}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Positive regulator of protein phosphatase SIT4. Involved
CC       in directing expression of TOR-repressed genes and in
CC       dephosphorylation of NPR1 in response to nutrient starvation.
CC       Negatively modulates K(+) efflux of the cell by the Na(+)-
CC       K(+)/H(+) antiporter NHA1. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15367655,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15947196}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Associates with the SIT4 protein phosphatase catalytic
CC       subunit in a cell-cycle-dependent manner.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P20604:SIT4; NbExp=9; IntAct=EBI-16370, EBI-13707;
CC       Q12199:TIP41; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-16370, EBI-38123;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095}.
CC   -!- PTM: Hyperphosphorylated in the absence of SIT4.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 5960 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the SAPS family. {ECO:0000305}.

RN   [13]
RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (3.0 ANGSTROMS) OF 80S RIBOSOME, SUBUNIT, AND
RP   SUBCELLULAR LOCATION.
RX   PubMed=22096102; DOI=10.1126/science.1212642;
RA   Ben-Shem A., Garreau de Loubresse N., Melnikov S., Jenner L.,
RA   Yusupova G., Yusupov M.;
RT   "The structure of the eukaryotic ribosome at 3.0 A resolution.";
RL   Science 334:1524-1529(2011).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Component of the ribosome, a large ribonucleoprotein
CC       complex responsible for the synthesis of proteins in the cell. The
CC       small ribosomal subunit (SSU) binds messenger RNAs (mRNAs) and
CC       translates the encoded message by selecting cognate aminoacyl-
CC       transfer RNA (tRNA) molecules. The large subunit (LSU) contains
CC       the ribosomal catalytic site termed the peptidyl transferase
CC       center (PTC), which catalyzes the formation of peptide bonds,
CC       thereby polymerizing the amino acids delivered by tRNAs into a
CC       polypeptide chain. The nascent polypeptides leave the ribosome
CC       through a tunnel in the LSU and interact with protein factors that
CC       function in enzymatic processing, targeting, and the membrane
CC       insertion of nascent chains at the exit of the ribosomal tunnel.
CC       {ECO:0000305|PubMed:22096102}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the large ribosomal subunit (LSU). Mature
CC       yeast ribosomes consist of a small (40S) and a large (60S)
CC       subunit. The 40S small subunit contains 1 molecule of ribosomal
CC       RNA (18S rRNA) and 33 different proteins (encoded by 57 genes).
CC       The large 60S subunit contains 3 rRNA molecules (25S, 5.8S and 5S
CC       rRNA) and 46 different proteins (encoded by 81 genes). uL6 lines
CC       the binding pocket for eukaryotic elongation factor 2 (eEF2)
CC       (PubMed:9559554, PubMed:22096102). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22096102,
CC       ECO:0000305|PubMed:9559554}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22096102}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 52400 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: There are 2 genes for uL6 in yeast. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the universal ribosomal protein uL6 family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Negative regulator of the transcriptional complex INO2-
CC       INO4 in response to phospholipid precursor availability. When
CC       precursors become limiting, OPI1 is retained at the endoplasmic
CC       reticulum (ER) and INO2-INO4 activates INO1 and other genes
CC       required for phospholipid biosynthesis, whereas abundant precursor
CC       availability results in targeting of OPI1 to the nucleus to
CC       repress transcription of these genes. Binds directly to
CC       phosphatidic acid, which is required for ER targeting and may act
CC       as sensing mechanism for precursor availability, as phosphatidic
CC       acid becomes rapidly depleted upon phospholipid biosynthesis.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15192221}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with SCS2. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12727870,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15455074}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P40075:SCS2; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-12555, EBI-16735;
CC       P22579:SIN3; NbExp=6; IntAct=EBI-12555, EBI-17160;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Endoplasmic reticulum
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12727870, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15192221}.
CC       Nucleus {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15192221}. Note=Maintained at the
CC       endoplasmic reticulum by SCS2 (PubMed:12727870). In response to
CC       elevated inositol levels, translocates to the nucleus
CC       (PubMed:15192221).
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The FFAT motif is required for interaction with SCS2 and
CC       proper localization of the protein. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12727870}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 1281 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: ATP dependent phosphorylation of adenosine and other
CC       related nucleoside analogs to monophosphate derivatives. ADO1 does
CC       not play a major role in adenine utilization in yeast. Its
CC       physiological role could primarily be to recycle adenosine
CC       produced by the methyl cycle.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: ATP + adenosine = ADP + AMP.
CC   -!- COFACTOR:
CC       Name=Mg(2+); Xref=ChEBI:CHEBI:18420; Evidence={ECO:0000250};
CC   -!- PATHWAY: Purine metabolism; AMP biosynthesis via salvage pathway;
CC       AMP from adenosine: step 1/1.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 22200 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the carbohydrate kinase PfkB family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Catalyzes the formation of 5-methyl-uridine at position
CC       54 (m5U54) in all tRNA. May also have a role in tRNA stabilization
CC       or maturation. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10864043,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12003492}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: S-adenosyl-L-methionine + uracil(54) in tRNA =
CC       S-adenosyl-L-homocysteine + 5-methyluracil(54) in tRNA.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10864043}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the class I-like SAM-binding
CC       methyltransferase superfamily. RNA M5U methyltransferase family.
CC       {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU01024}.
CC   -!- CAUTION: Was originally thought to be an endo-exonuclease.
CC       {ECO:0000305|PubMed:1408836}.
CC   -!- CAUTION: It is uncertain whether Met-1, Met-38, Met-71, Met-77 or
CC       Met-82 is the initiator. {ECO:0000305}.

CC       formation. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22152483}.
