RA   Agarwal S., Roeder G.S.;
RT   "Zip3 provides a link between recombination enzymes and synaptonemal
RT   complex proteins.";
RL   Cell 102:245-255(2000).
RN   [5]
RP   FUNCTION OF THE SIC COMPLEX, AND SUBCELLULAR LOCATION.
RX   PubMed=15035982; DOI=10.1016/S0092-8674(04)00249-1;
RA   Fung J.C., Rockmill B., Odell M., Roeder G.S.;
RT   "Imposition of crossover interference through the nonrandom
RT   distribution of synapsis initiation complexes.";
RL   Cell 116:795-802(2004).
RN   [6]
RP   FUNCTION OF THE SIC COMPLEX.
RX   PubMed=15070750; DOI=10.1073/pnas.0400843101;
RA   Henderson K.A., Keeney S.;
RT   "Tying synaptonemal complex initiation to the formation and programmed
RT   repair of DNA double-strand breaks.";
RL   Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 101:4519-4524(2004).
RN   [7]
RP   FUNCTION OF THE SIC COMPLEX.
RX   PubMed=15805472; DOI=10.1101/gad.1293605;
RA   Peoples-Holst T.L., Burgess S.M.;
RT   "Multiple branches of the meiotic recombination pathway contribute
RT   independently to homolog pairing and stable juxtaposition during
RT   meiosis in budding yeast.";
RL   Genes Dev. 19:863-874(2005).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Component of the synapsis initiation complex (SIC)
CC       necessary for the synaptonemal complex assembly. Stabilizes the
CC       ZIP2 component to the chromosomes. The SIC complex loads onto
CC       chromosomes and nucleates ZIP1 polymerization, a molecular zipper
CC       that acts to bring homologous chromosomes in close apposition,
CC       which is required for meiotic crossover. May also be involved in
CC       double strand break repair. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10454593,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:10943844, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15035982,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15070750, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15805472}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the synapsis initiation complex composed of
CC       at least ZIP2, ZIP3, MSH4 and MSH5. Interacts also with ZIP1,
CC       MRE11, RAD51 and RAD53. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10943844}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P25301:RAD57; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-30044, EBI-14744;
CC       P31111:ZIP1; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-30044, EBI-29645;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus. Chromosome. Note=Synapsed meiotic
CC       chromosomes.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: Expressed during meiosis.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10943844}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Involved in lipid metabolism and lipid droplet (LD)
CC       morphology, number, and size (PubMed:18093937, PubMed:18250201).
CC       Facilitates initiation of LD formation, and ensures that vectorial
CC       budding of LDs from the ER is directed towards the cytoplasm
CC       (PubMed:25540432). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18093937,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18250201, ECO:0000269|PubMed:25540432}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Self; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-35851, EBI-35851;
CC       P25587:LDB16; NbExp=7; IntAct=EBI-35851, EBI-21668;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Endoplasmic reticulum membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18093937, ECO:0000269|PubMed:18250201}; Multi-
CC       pass membrane protein {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18093937,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18250201}. Note=Concentrates at endoplasmic
CC       reticulum lipid droplet junctions. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18093937}.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: By calcium shortage. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12161108}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Produces supersized LDs that are up to 50
CC       times the volume of those in wild-type cells.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21829381}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 846 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the seipin family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: One of 2 isozymes that catalyze the conversion of HMG-
CC       CoA to mevalonate. It is the rate-limiting enzyme of the sterol
CC       biosynthesis pathway. Involved in ergosterol biosynthesis.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:3526336}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: (R)-mevalonate + CoA + 2 NADP(+) = (S)-3-
CC       hydroxy-3-methylglutaryl-CoA + 2 NADPH. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU10003}.
CC   -!- PATHWAY: Metabolic intermediate biosynthesis; (R)-mevalonate
CC       biosynthesis; (R)-mevalonate from acetyl-CoA: step 3/3.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P12683:HMG1; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-8384, EBI-8377;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Endoplasmic reticulum membrane; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein. Nucleus envelope.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 149 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the HMG-CoA reductase family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

RP   FUNCTION, AND MUTAGENESIS OF GLY-95 AND GLY-123.
RX   PubMed=15118906; DOI=10.1007/s00438-004-1011-y;
RA   Esser K., Jan P.S., Pratje E., Michaelis G.;
RT   "The mitochondrial IMP peptidase of yeast: functional analysis of
RT   domains and identification of Gut2 as a new natural substrate.";
RL   Mol. Genet. Genomics 271:616-626(2004).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Catalytic component of the mitochondrial inner membrane
CC       peptidase (IMP) complex. IMP catalyzes the removal of signal
CC       peptides required for the targeting of proteins from the
CC       mitochondrial matrix, across the inner membrane, into the inter-
CC       membrane space. The two catalytic IMP subunits seem to have non-
CC       overlapping substrate specificities. IMP2 substrates include
CC       nuclear encoded CYB2, mitochondrially encoded COX2 and cytochrome
CC       c1. Required for the stability of IMP1.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15118906}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the mitochondrial inner membrane peptidase
CC       (IMP) complex which at least consists of IMP1, IMP2 and SOM1.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:8132591}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q05930:MDM30; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-9231, EBI-31799;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Mitochondrion inner membrane; Single-pass
CC       membrane protein.
CC   -!- PTM: The N-terminus is blocked.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the peptidase S26 family. IMP2 subfamily.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

RN   [15]
RP   IDENTIFICATION BY MASS SPECTROMETRY [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS].
RX   PubMed=22814378; DOI=10.1073/pnas.1210303109;
RA   Van Damme P., Lasa M., Polevoda B., Gazquez C., Elosegui-Artola A.,
RA   Kim D.S., De Juan-Pardo E., Demeyer K., Hole K., Larrea E.,
RA   Timmerman E., Prieto J., Arnesen T., Sherman F., Gevaert K.,
RA   Aldabe R.;
RT   "N-terminal acetylome analyses and functional insights of the N-
RT   terminal acetyltransferase NatB.";
RL   Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 109:12449-12454(2012).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Forms a channel through the cell membrane that allows
CC       diffusion of small hydrophilic molecules. The channel adopts an
CC       open conformation at low or zero membrane potential and a closed
CC       conformation at potentials above 30-40 mV. The open state has a
CC       weak anion selectivity whereas the closed state is cation-
CC       selective. Is the major permeability factor of the mitochondrial
CC       outer membrane. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9435273}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with AIM5, FCJ1 and MOS1.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21987634}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Mitochondrion outer membrane.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: Consists mainly of membrane-spanning sided beta-sheets. 19
CC       strands distributed along the entire VDAC protein, have the
CC       potential to adopt transmembrane beta pleated sheet structures,
CC       which rolled together may form a "beta-barrel" type structure,
CC       possessing pore dimensions.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the eukaryotic mitochondrial porin family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: PPIases accelerate the folding of proteins. It catalyzes
CC       the cis-trans isomerization of proline imidic peptide bonds in
CC       oligopeptides.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Peptidylproline (omega=180) = peptidylproline
CC       (omega=0).
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with HMO1. Interacts with FAP1.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10049913, ECO:0000269|PubMed:10998178}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P43573:BUD27; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-6961, EBI-22787;
CC       P10869:HOM3; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-6961, EBI-2430;
CC       Q9FR53:TOR (xeno); NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-6961, EBI-1382370;
CC       P35169:TOR1; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-6961, EBI-19374;
CC       P32600:TOR2; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-6961, EBI-19385;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Binds to the immunosuppressant drug FK506 and also
CC       mediates the sensitivity to rapamycin. Rapamycin disrupts
CC       interaction with FAP1.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 43300 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the FKBP-type PPIase family. FKBP1
CC       subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

RN   [18]
RP   FUNCTION, AND MUTAGENESIS OF LEU-461; SER-463 AND THR-464.
RX   PubMed=25829489; DOI=10.1074/jbc.M115.641118;
RA   Onguka O., Calzada E., Ogunbona O.B., Claypool S.M.;
RT   "Phosphatidylserine decarboxylase 1 autocatalysis and function does
RT   not require a mitochondrial-specific factor.";
RL   J. Biol. Chem. 290:12744-12752(2015).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Catalyzes the formation of phosphatidylethanolamine
CC       (PtdEtn) from phosphatidylserine (PtdSer). Plays a central role in
CC       phospholipid metabolism and in the interorganelle trafficking of
CC       phosphatidylserine (PubMed:8227017, PubMed:8407984,
CC       PubMed:17976194, PubMed:23124206, PubMed:25829489).
CC       Phosphatidylethanolamine formed in the mitochondria is exported to
CC       other membranes to fullfill their requirements for PtdEtn
CC       (PubMed:8530379, PubMed:11294902). Required for normal
CC       mitochondrial morphology and proper mitochondrial fusion during
CC       yeast mating (PubMed:23045528). {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03208,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11294902, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17976194,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:23045528, ECO:0000269|PubMed:23124206,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:25829489, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8227017,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8407984, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8530379}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Phosphatidyl-L-serine =
CC       phosphatidylethanolamine + CO(2). {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-
CC       Rule:MF_03208, ECO:0000269|PubMed:23124206,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:6427211, ECO:0000305|PubMed:17976194}.
CC   -!- COFACTOR:
CC       Name=pyruvate; Xref=ChEBI:CHEBI:15361;
CC         Evidence={ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03208};
CC       Note=Binds 1 pyruvoyl group covalently per subunit.
CC       {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03208};
CC   -!- PATHWAY: Phospholipid metabolism; phosphatidylethanolamine
CC       biosynthesis; phosphatidylethanolamine from CDP-diacylglycerol:
CC       step 2/2. {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03208,
CC       ECO:0000305|PubMed:8407984}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Heterodimer of a large membrane-associated beta subunit
CC       and a small pyruvoyl-containing alpha subunit. {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-
CC       Rule:MF_03208}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Phosphatidylserine decarboxylase 1 beta
CC       chain: Mitochondrion inner membrane {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-
CC       Rule:MF_03208, ECO:0000269|PubMed:14576278,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22984266, ECO:0000269|PubMed:23124206,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:3005242}; Single-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03208, ECO:0000305|PubMed:22984266};
CC       Intermembrane side {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03208,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095, ECO:0000269|PubMed:14576278,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22984266, ECO:0000269|PubMed:23124206}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Phosphatidylserine decarboxylase 1 alpha
CC       chain: Mitochondrion inner membrane {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-
CC       Rule:MF_03208, ECO:0000269|PubMed:14576278,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22984266, ECO:0000269|PubMed:23124206,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:3005242}; Peripheral membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03208, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22984266};
CC       Intermembrane side {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03208,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095, ECO:0000269|PubMed:14576278,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22984266, ECO:0000269|PubMed:23124206}.
CC       Note=Anchored to the mitochondrial inner membrane through its
CC       interaction with the integral membrane beta chain.
CC       {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03208, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22984266}.
CC   -!- PTM: The precursor is imported via the TOM complex into
CC       mitochondria, where the N-terminal presequence is cleaved by the
CC       matrix-located proteases MPP (MAS1-MAS2) and OCT1.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22984266, ECO:0000305|PubMed:17976194}.
CC   -!- PTM: Is synthesized initially as an inactive proenzyme. Formation
CC       of the active enzyme involves a self-maturation process in which
CC       the active site pyruvoyl group is generated from an internal
CC       serine residue via an autocatalytic post-translational
CC       modification. Two non-identical subunits are generated from the
CC       proenzyme in this reaction, and the pyruvate is formed at the N-
CC       terminus of the alpha chain, which is derived from the carboxyl
CC       end of the proenzyme (PubMed:25829489). The autoendoproteolytic
CC       cleavage occurs by a canonical serine protease mechanism, in which
CC       the side chain hydroxyl group of the serine supplies its oxygen
CC       atom to form the C-terminus of the beta chain, while the remainder
CC       of the serine residue undergoes an oxidative deamination to
CC       produce ammonia and the pyruvoyl prosthetic group on the alpha
CC       chain. During this reaction, the Ser that is part of the protease
CC       active site of the proenzyme becomes the pyruvoyl prosthetic
CC       group, which constitutes an essential element of the active site
CC       of the mature decarboxylase (By similarity). {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-
CC       Rule:MF_03208, ECO:0000305|PubMed:18644857}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 1080 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the phosphatidylserine decarboxylase
CC       family. PSD-B subfamily. Eukaryotic type I sub-subfamily.
CC       {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03208}.

CC       membranes and the global structure of the mitochondria. Also

RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (4.0 ANGSTROMS) OF 80S RIBOSOME.
RX   PubMed=21109664; DOI=10.1126/science.1194294;
RA   Ben-Shem A., Jenner L., Yusupova G., Yusupov M.;

RN   [13]
RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (3.0 ANGSTROMS) OF 80S RIBOSOME, SUBUNIT, AND
RP   SUBCELLULAR LOCATION.
RX   PubMed=22096102; DOI=10.1126/science.1212642;
RA   Ben-Shem A., Garreau de Loubresse N., Melnikov S., Jenner L.,
RA   Yusupova G., Yusupov M.;
RT   "The structure of the eukaryotic ribosome at 3.0 A resolution.";
RL   Science 334:1524-1529(2011).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Component of the ribosome, a large ribonucleoprotein
CC       complex responsible for the synthesis of proteins in the cell. The
CC       small ribosomal subunit (SSU) binds messenger RNAs (mRNAs) and
CC       translates the encoded message by selecting cognate aminoacyl-
CC       transfer RNA (tRNA) molecules. The large subunit (LSU) contains
CC       the ribosomal catalytic site termed the peptidyl transferase
CC       center (PTC), which catalyzes the formation of peptide bonds,
CC       thereby polymerizing the amino acids delivered by tRNAs into a
CC       polypeptide chain. The nascent polypeptides leave the ribosome
CC       through a tunnel in the LSU and interact with protein factors that
CC       function in enzymatic processing, targeting, and the membrane
CC       insertion of nascent chains at the exit of the ribosomal tunnel.
CC       {ECO:0000305|PubMed:22096102}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the large ribosomal subunit (LSU). Mature
CC       yeast ribosomes consist of a small (40S) and a large (60S)
CC       subunit. The 40S small subunit contains 1 molecule of ribosomal
CC       RNA (18S rRNA) and 33 different proteins (encoded by 57 genes).
CC       The large 60S subunit contains 3 rRNA molecules (25S, 5.8S and 5S
CC       rRNA) and 46 different proteins (encoded by 81 genes). eL20 forms
CC       multiple interactions with RNA and proteins in the central
CC       protuberance, connecting components of core functional centers
CC       that are locatzed far apart (PubMed:9559554, PubMed:22096102).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22096102, ECO:0000305|PubMed:9559554}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22096102}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 54300 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: There are 2 genes for eL20 in yeast. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the eukaryotic ribosomal protein eL20
CC       family. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SEQUENCE CAUTION:
CC       Sequence=CAA88652.1; Type=Erroneous gene model prediction; Evidence={ECO:0000305};

RP   NOMENCLATURE.
RX   PubMed=24524803; DOI=10.1016/j.sbi.2014.01.002;
RA   Ban N., Beckmann R., Cate J.H.D., Dinman J.D., Dragon F., Ellis S.R.,
RA   Lafontaine D.L.J., Lindahl L., Liljas A., Lipton J.M., McAlear M.A.,
RA   Moore P.B., Noller H.F., Ortega J., Panse V.G., Ramakrishnan V.,
RA   Spahn C.M.T., Steitz T.A., Tchorzewski M., Tollervey D., Warren A.J.,
RA   Williamson J.R., Wilson D., Yonath A., Yusupov M.;
RT   "A new system for naming ribosomal proteins.";
RL   Curr. Opin. Struct. Biol. 24:165-169(2014).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Component of the ribosome, a large ribonucleoprotein
CC       complex responsible for the synthesis of proteins in the cell. The
CC       small ribosomal subunit (SSU) binds messenger RNAs (mRNAs) and
CC       translates the encoded message by selecting cognate aminoacyl-
CC       transfer RNA (tRNA) molecules. The large subunit (LSU) contains
CC       the ribosomal catalytic site termed the peptidyl transferase
CC       center (PTC), which catalyzes the formation of peptide bonds,
CC       thereby polymerizing the amino acids delivered by tRNAs into a
CC       polypeptide chain. The nascent polypeptides leave the ribosome
CC       through a tunnel in the LSU and interact with protein factors that
CC       function in enzymatic processing, targeting, and the membrane
CC       insertion of nascent chains at the exit of the ribosomal tunnel.
CC       {ECO:0000305|PubMed:22096102}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the large ribosomal subunit (LSU). Mature
CC       yeast ribosomes consist of a small (40S) and a large (60S)
CC       subunit. The 40S small subunit contains 1 molecule of ribosomal
CC       RNA (18S rRNA) and 33 different proteins (encoded by 57 genes).
CC       The large 60S subunit contains 3 rRNA molecules (25S, 5.8S and 5S
CC       rRNA) and 46 different proteins (encoded by 81 genes). eL20 forms
CC       multiple interactions with RNA and proteins in the central
CC       protuberance, connecting components of core functional centers
CC       that are locatzed far apart (PubMed:9559554, PubMed:22096102).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22096102, ECO:0000305|PubMed:9559554}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22096102}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: There are 2 genes for eL20 in yeast. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the eukaryotic ribosomal protein eL20
CC       family. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SEQUENCE CAUTION:
CC       Sequence=CAA62167.1; Type=Erroneous gene model prediction; Evidence={ECO:0000305};
CC       Sequence=CAA99632.1; Type=Erroneous gene model prediction; Evidence={ECO:0000305};

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Probable ubiquitin ligase protein involved in many
CC       cellular processes, such as transcription regulation, maintenance
CC       of nuclear structure, cell cycle, mRNA export and rRNA maturation.
CC       E3 ubiquitin ligase proteins mediate ubiquitination and subsequent
CC       proteasomal degradation of target proteins. Involved in
CC       transcription regulation by interacting, and probably mediating,
CC       ubiquitination of some subunit of the SAGA complex. Required for
CC       SPT7 ubiquitination. Participates in mRNA export from the nucleus
CC       by regulating the transport of hnRNP proteins. Required for the
CC       shuttling of hnRNP protein NAB2, probably by mediating
CC       ubiquitination of a protein associated with NAB2. Also required
CC       for full induction of the general stress and heat-shock responses.
CC       Involved in 18S rRNA maturation by affecting several early steps
CC       in the rRNA processing pathway. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10395901,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:10660055, ECO:0000269|PubMed:10873801,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11238398, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9753545}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: S-ubiquitinyl-[E2 ubiquitin-conjugating
CC       enzyme]-L-cysteine + [acceptor protein]-L-lysine = [E2 ubiquitin-
CC       conjugating enzyme]-L-cysteine + N(6)-ubiquitinyl-[acceptor
CC       protein]-L-lysine.
CC   -!- PATHWAY: Protein modification; protein ubiquitination.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with the ADA3/NGG1 subunit of the SAGA complex.
CC       Interacts with KRR1. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11027267,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9753545}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus, nucleolus
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10873801, ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 350 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the UPL family. TOM1/PTR1 subfamily.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Catalytic component of ISW1-type complexes, which act by
CC       remodeling the chromatin by catalyzing an ATP-dependent alteration
CC       in the structure of nucleosomal DNA. They are involved in
CC       coordinating transcriptional repression, activation and elongation
CC       phases. The ISW1A complex represses gene expression at initiation
CC       through specific positioning of a promoter proximal dinucleosome.
CC       The ISW1B complex acts within coding regions to control the amount
CC       of RNA polymerase II released into productive elongation and to
CC       coordinate elongation with termination and pre-mRNA processing.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10090725, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11238381,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12482963, ECO:0000269|PubMed:14622597}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the ISW1A complex, which at least consists
CC       of ISW1 and IOC3. Component of the ISW1B complex, which at least
CC       consists of ISW1, IOC2 and IOC4. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10090725,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12482963}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q12072:IOC2; NbExp=6; IntAct=EBI-21087, EBI-30191;
CC       P43596:IOC3; NbExp=11; IntAct=EBI-21087, EBI-22944;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00624, ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 1500 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the SNF2/RAD54 helicase family. ISWI
CC       subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   INTERACTION WITH IGO1.
RX   PubMed=20471941; DOI=10.1016/j.molcel.2010.02.039;
RA   Talarek N., Cameroni E., Jaquenoud M., Luo X., Bontron S., Lippman S.,

RN   [18]
RP   FUNCTION, RNA-BINDING, AND DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE.
RX   PubMed=26098573; DOI=10.1038/ncb3189;
RA   Hu G., McQuiston T., Bernard A., Park Y.D., Qiu J., Vural A.,
RA   Zhang N., Waterman S.R., Blewett N.H., Myers T.G., Maraia R.J.,
RA   Kehrl J.H., Uzel G., Klionsky D.J., Williamson P.R.;
RT   "A conserved mechanism of TOR-dependent RCK-mediated mRNA degradation
RT   regulates autophagy.";
RL   Nat. Cell Biol. 17:930-942(2015).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: ATP-dependent RNA helicase involved in mRNA turnover,
CC       and more specifically in mRNA decapping by activating the
CC       decapping enzyme DCP1 (PubMed:11780629, PubMed:12032091,
CC       PubMed:11696541, PubMed:12730603, PubMed:15703442.
CC       PubMed:15706350). Is involved in G1/S DNA-damage checkpoint
CC       recovery, probably through the regulation of the translational
CC       status of a subset of mRNAs (PubMed:15166134). May also have a
CC       role in translation and mRNA nuclear export (PubMed:12930949).
CC       Required for sporulation (PubMed:12930949). Blocks autophagy in
CC       nutrient-rich conditions by, at least partly, binding and
CC       repressing the expression of a set of ATG genes, including ATG3,
CC       ATG7, ATG8, ATG19, ATG20, ATG22 and SNX4/ATG24 (PubMed:26098573).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11696541, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11780629,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12032091, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12730603,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12930949, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15166134,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15703442, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15706350,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:26098573}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: ATP + H(2)O = ADP + phosphate. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Associated with the CCR4-NOT complex and possibly other
CC       big complexes (PubMed:9504907, PubMed:12930949). Interacts with
CC       CDC39/NOT1 (PubMed:11696541). Interacts with DCP1, LSM1, and POP2
CC       (PubMed:9504907, PubMed:11780629). Interacts with IGO1
CC       (PubMed:20471941). Interacts with PAT1 and with KEM1, the major
CC       5'-3' exonuclease (PubMed:11780629, PubMed:12032091).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11696541, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11780629,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12032091, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12930949,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:20471941, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9504907}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q12517:DCP1; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-158, EBI-38519;
CC       P39998:EDC3; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-158, EBI-22300;
CC       P47017:LSM1; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-158, EBI-174;
CC       P38203:LSM2; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-158, EBI-180;
CC       P40070:LSM4; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-158, EBI-188;
CC       P39016:MPT5; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-158, EBI-2052996;
CC       P25644:PAT1; NbExp=7; IntAct=EBI-158, EBI-204;
CC       P39008:POP2; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-158, EBI-13629;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm, P-body
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12032091, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12730603,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12930949, ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15706350}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The Q motif is unique to and characteristic of the DEAD
CC       box family of RNA helicases and controls ATP binding and
CC       hydrolysis.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Leads to an increased in autophagy flux
CC       (PubMed:26098573). Causes an accumulation of ATG3, ATG7, ATG8,
CC       ATG19, ATG20, ATG22 and SNX4/ATG24 transcripts in nutrient-replete
CC       conditions (PubMed:26098573). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:26098573}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 42900 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the DEAD box helicase family. DDX6/DHH1
CC       subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Acts as catalytic component of the CCR4-NOT core
CC       complex, which in the nucleus seems to be a general transcription
CC       factor, and in the cytoplasm the major mRNA deadenylase involved
CC       in mRNA turnover. CCR4 has 3'-5' RNase activity with a strong
CC       preference for polyadenylated substrates and also low exonuclease
CC       activity towards single-stranded DNA. Discovered because of its
CC       role in the control of ADH2 gene expression. It is required for
CC       the expression of genes involved in non-fermentative growth and it
CC       mediates or is required for the action of the SPT6 and SPT10
CC       genes. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11239395, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11889047,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11889048, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9463387}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Exonucleolytic cleavage of poly(A) to 5'-AMP.
CC   -!- COFACTOR:
CC       Name=Mg(2+); Xref=ChEBI:CHEBI:18420;
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Subunit of the 1.0 MDa CCR4-NOT core complex that
CC       contains CCR4, CAF1, NOT1, NOT2, NOT3, NOT4, NOT5, CAF40 and
CC       CAF130. In the complex interacts with NOT1. The core complex
CC       probably is part of a less characterized 1.9 MDa CCR4-NOT complex.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10490603, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11733989,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9463387}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P53829:CAF40; NbExp=8; IntAct=EBI-4396, EBI-28306;
CC       P25655:CDC39; NbExp=7; IntAct=EBI-4396, EBI-12139;
CC       P34909:MOT2; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-4396, EBI-12174;
CC       P39016:MPT5; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-4396, EBI-2052996;
CC       P39008:POP2; NbExp=9; IntAct=EBI-4396, EBI-13629;
CC       Q01939:RPT6; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-4396, EBI-13914;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11239395}.
CC       Nucleus {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11239395}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The 169 C-terminal residues are important for deadenylase
CC       activity.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 2780 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the CCR4/nocturin family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Associated with repair of damaged DNA and meiosis.
CC       Phosphorylates serine and threonine. Can use casein as a
CC       substrate.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: ATP + a protein = ADP + a phosphoprotein.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with HRI1. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21460040}.

RN   [26]
RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (2.2 ANGSTROMS) OF 174-339, DOMAIN, INTERACTION
RP   WITH HISTONE H3K4ME3, AND MUTAGENESIS OF GLU-220.
RX   PubMed=17433364; DOI=10.1016/j.jmb.2007.03.024;
RA   Flanagan J.F., Blus B.J., Kim D., Clines K.L., Rastinejad F.,
RA   Khorasanizadeh S.;
RT   "Molecular implications of evolutionary differences in CHD double
RT   chromodomains.";
RL   J. Mol. Biol. 369:334-342(2007).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: ATP-dependent chromatin-remodeling factor which
CC       functions as substrate recognition component of the transcription
CC       regulatory histone acetylation (HAT) complexes SAGA and SLIK. It
CC       recognizes H3K4me. SAGA is involved in RNA polymerase II-dependent
CC       transcriptional regulation of approximately 10% of yeast genes. At
CC       the promoters, SAGA is required for recruitment of the basal
CC       transcription machinery. It influences RNA polymerase II
CC       transcriptional activity through different activities such as TBP
CC       interaction (SPT3, SPT8 and SPT20) and promoter selectivity,
CC       interaction with transcription activators (GCN5, ADA2, ADA3 and
CC       TRA1), and chromatin modification through histone acetylation
CC       (GCN5) and deubiquitination (UBP8). SAGA acetylates nucleosomal
CC       histone H3 to some extent (to form H3K9ac, H3K14ac, H3K18ac and
CC       H3K23ac). SAGA interacts with DNA via upstream activating
CC       sequences (UASs). SLIK is proposed to have partly overlapping
CC       functions with SAGA. It preferentially acetylates methylated
CC       histone H3, at least after activation at the GAL1-10 locus. Acts
CC       in opposition to the FACT complex in regulating polymerase II
CC       transcription. Also required for efficient transcription by RNA
CC       polymerase I, and more specifically the pol I transcription
CC       termination step. Regulates negatively DNA replication. Not only
CC       involved in transcription-related chromatin-remodeling, but also
CC       required to maintain a specific chromatin configuration across the
CC       genome. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10026213, ECO:0000269|PubMed:10811623,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12682017, ECO:0000269|PubMed:14585955,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15647753, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16468993,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16606615, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17259992,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17620414, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17949749,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18245327}.
CC   -!- BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES:
CC       Kinetic parameters:
CC         KM=10.2 nM for ATP {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17949749};
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the 1.8 MDa SAGA complex, which consists of
CC       at least of TRA1, CHD1, SPT7, TAF5, ADA3, SGF73, SPT20/ADA5, SPT8,
CC       TAF12, TAF6, HFI1/ADA1, UBP8, GCN5, ADA2, SPT3, SGF29, TAF10,
CC       TAF9, SGF11 and SUS1. TAF5, TAF6, TAF9, TAF19, TAF12 and ADA1 seem
CC       to be present in 2 copies. SAGA is built of 5 distinct domains
CC       with specialized functions. Domain I (containing TRA1) probably
CC       represents the activator interaction surface. Domain II
CC       (containing TAF5 and TAF6, and probably TAF9 and TAF10), domain
CC       III (containing GCN5, TAF10, SPT7, TAF5 and ADA1, and probably
CC       ADA2, ADA3 and TAF12), and domain IV (containing HFI1/ADA1 and
CC       TAF6, and probably TAF9) are believed to play primarily an
CC       architectural role. Domain III also harbors the HAT activity.
CC       Domain V (containing SPT3 and SPT20, and probably SPT8) represents
CC       the TBP-interacting module, which may be associated transiently
CC       with SAGA. Component of the SLIK complex, which consists of at
CC       least TRA1, CHD1, SPT7, TAF5, ADA3, SPT20, RTG2, TAF12, TAF6,
CC       HFI1, UBP8, GCN5, ADA2, SPT3, SGF29, TAF10 and TAF9. Interacts
CC       with RTF1, SPT5 and with the FACT subunits POB3 and SPT16.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12242279, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12446794,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12682017, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15647753,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17433364, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17576814}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus {ECO:0000305|PubMed:12682017}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 1620 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the SNF2/RAD54 helicase family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Binds specifically to cytosolic chaperonin (c-CPN) and
CC       transfers target proteins to it. Binds to nascent polypeptide
CC       chain and promotes folding in an environment in which there are
CC       many competing pathways for nonnative proteins.

CC       type subunits. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9878052}.

CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.

CC       {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Part of the complex catalyzing the transfer of N-
CC       acetylglucosamine from UDP-N-acetylglucosamine to
CC       phosphatidylinositol, the first step of GPI biosynthesis. Involved
CC       in cell wall biosynthesis. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16278447}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: UDP-N-acetyl-D-glucosamine + 1-phosphatidyl-
CC       1D-myo-inositol = UDP + 6-(N-acetyl-alpha-D-glucosaminyl)-1-
CC       phosphatidyl-1D-myo-inositol.
CC   -!- PATHWAY: Glycolipid biosynthesis; glycosylphosphatidylinositol-
CC       anchor biosynthesis.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the phosphatidylinositol N-
CC       acetylglucosaminyltransferase (GPI-GlcNAc transferase) complex
CC       composed of at least GPI1, GPI2, GPI3, GPI15, GPI19 and ERI1
CC       (Probable). Interacts with GPI2 (PubMed:16278447).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16278447, ECO:0000305|PubMed:16278447}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Endoplasmic reticulum membrane
CC       {ECO:0000305}; Multi-pass membrane protein {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 752 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the GPI19 family. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   AND SER-294, AND IDENTIFICATION BY MASS SPECTROMETRY [LARGE SCALE
RP   ANALYSIS].
RX   PubMed=19779198; DOI=10.1126/science.1172867;
RA   Holt L.J., Tuch B.B., Villen J., Johnson A.D., Gygi S.P., Morgan D.O.;
RT   "Global analysis of Cdk1 substrate phosphorylation sites provides
RT   insights into evolution.";
RL   Science 325:1682-1686(2009).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Functions as a component of the nuclear pore complex
CC       (NPC). NPC components, collectively referred to as nucleoporins
CC       (NUPs), can play the role of both NPC structural components and of
CC       docking or interaction partners for transiently associated nuclear
CC       transport factors.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: The nuclear pore complex (NPC) constitutes the exclusive
CC       means of nucleocytoplasmic transport. NPCs allow the passive
CC       diffusion of ions and small molecules and the active, nuclear
CC       transport receptor-mediated bidirectional transport of
CC       macromolecules such as proteins, RNAs, ribonucleoparticles (RNPs),
CC       and ribosomal subunits across the nuclear envelope. The 55-60 MDa
CC       NPC is composed of at least 31 different subunits: ASM4, CDC31,
CC       GLE1, GLE2, NDC1, NIC96, NSP1, NUP1, NUP2, NUP100, NUP116, NUP120,
CC       NUP133, NUP145, NUP157, NUP159, NUP170, NUP188, NUP192, NUP42,
CC       NUP49, NUP53, NUP57, NUP60, NUP82, NUP84, NUP85, POM152, POM34,
CC       SEC13 and SEH1. Due to its 8-fold rotational symmetry, all
CC       subunits are present with 8 copies or multiples thereof.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus, nuclear pore complex. Nucleus
CC       membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein. Note=Central core structure
CC       of the nuclear pore complex.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: The coatomer is a cytosolic protein complex that binds
CC       to dilysine motifs and reversibly associates with Golgi non-
CC       clathrin-coated vesicles, which further mediate biosynthetic
CC       protein transport from the ER, via the Golgi up to the trans Golgi
CC       network. Coatomer complex is required for budding from Golgi
CC       membranes, and is essential for the retrograde Golgi-to-ER
CC       transport of dilysine-tagged proteins (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Oligomeric complex that consists of at least the alpha,
CC       beta, beta', gamma, delta, epsilon and zeta subunits. Interacts
CC       with DSL1. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14504276}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000250}. Golgi apparatus
CC       membrane {ECO:0000250}; Peripheral membrane protein {ECO:0000250};
CC       Cytoplasmic side {ECO:0000250}. Cytoplasmic vesicle, COPI-coated
CC       vesicle membrane {ECO:0000250}; Peripheral membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000250}; Cytoplasmic side {ECO:0000250}. Note=The coatomer
CC       is cytoplasmic or polymerized on the cytoplasmic side of the
CC       Golgi, as well as on the vesicles/buds originating from it.
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 18000 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the adaptor complexes medium subunit
CC       family. Delta-COP subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

CC       either facilitating USO1-dependent and -independent tethering or

RP   IDENTIFICATION BY MASS SPECTROMETRY [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS].
RX   PubMed=22814378; DOI=10.1073/pnas.1210303109;
RA   Van Damme P., Lasa M., Polevoda B., Gazquez C., Elosegui-Artola A.,
RA   Kim D.S., De Juan-Pardo E., Demeyer K., Hole K., Larrea E.,
RA   Timmerman E., Prieto J., Arnesen T., Sherman F., Gevaert K.,
RA   Aldabe R.;
RT   "N-terminal acetylome analyses and functional insights of the N-
RT   terminal acetyltransferase NatB.";
RL   Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 109:12449-12454(2012).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: The coatomer is a cytosolic protein complex that binds
CC       to dilysine motifs and reversibly associates with Golgi non-
CC       clathrin-coated vesicles, which further mediate biosynthetic
CC       protein transport from the ER, via the Golgi up to the trans Golgi
CC       network. Coatomer complex is required for budding from Golgi
CC       membranes, and is essential for the retrograde Golgi-to-ER
CC       transport of dilysine-tagged proteins.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17101773}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Oligomeric complex that consists of at least the alpha,
CC       beta, beta', gamma, delta, epsilon and zeta subunits. Interacts
CC       with the ESCRT-0 subunit VPS27. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17101773}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P53622:COP1; NbExp=18; IntAct=EBI-4898, EBI-4860;
CC       P02829:HSP82; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-4898, EBI-8659;
CC       P40509:SEC28; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-4898, EBI-4884;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000250}. Golgi apparatus
CC       membrane {ECO:0000250}; Peripheral membrane protein {ECO:0000250};
CC       Cytoplasmic side {ECO:0000250}. Cytoplasmic vesicle, COPI-coated
CC       vesicle membrane {ECO:0000250}; Peripheral membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000250}; Cytoplasmic side {ECO:0000250}. Note=The coatomer
CC       is cytoplasmic or polymerized on the cytoplasmic side of the
CC       Golgi, as well as on the vesicles/buds originating from it.
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 129000 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the WD repeat COPB2 family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Involved in the recruitment of clathrin to the Golgi
CC       network and endosomes to form clathrin coated vesicles. Plays a
CC       role in the trafficking of clathrin between the Golgi network and
CC       endosomes. Binds to membranes enriched in phosphatidylinositol-
CC       3,5-bisphosphate (PtdIns(3,5)P2) and, in association with VPS27,
CC       is involved in protein sorting at the multivesicular body (MVB).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12483220, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15107463}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with the clathrin adapter GGA2, and VPS27.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12483220, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15107463}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q04338:VTI1; NbExp=7; IntAct=EBI-25662, EBI-20519;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12483220}.
CC       Golgi apparatus, trans-Golgi network membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12483220}; Peripheral membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12483220}. Cytoplasmic vesicle, clathrin-
CC       coated vesicle membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12483220}; Peripheral
CC       membrane protein {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12483220}. Note=Associates
CC       with the trans Golgi network (TGN) and endosomal clathrin coats.
